phrasal verbs.meaning: to be legally forced to stay inside one's home instead of going to prison
phrasal verbs.example: He was under house arrest while awaiting the final verdict.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to start working or studying seriously with full effort
phrasal verbs.example: You'll need to knuckle down if you want to pass the final exams.
phrasal verbs.translation: bắt tay vào làm việc nghiêm túc

phrasal verbs.meaning: to finally do something that you have intended to do for a long time
phrasal verbs.example: I finally got around to reading that book you lent me.
phrasal verbs.translation: cuối cùng cũng làm được điều gì đó

phrasal verbs.meaning: to dishonestly change financial records to make them appear better than they are
phrasal verbs.example: The accountant was fired for cooking the books to hide the losses.
phrasal verbs.translation: gian lận sổ sách kế toán

phrasal verbs.meaning: to work or study late into the night
phrasal verbs.example: She burned the midnight oil to finish the project on time.
phrasal verbs.translation: thức khuya làm việc hoặc học bài

phrasal verbs.meaning: to rely on someone to do what they say or expect
phrasal verbs.example: You can count on Tom to get the job done well.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to resemble a family member in appearance or behavior
phrasal verbs.example: She really takes after her mother in both looks and attitude.
phrasal verbs.translation: giống ai đó trong gia đình

phrasal verbs.meaning: to leave a place quietly and secretly to avoid being noticed
phrasal verbs.example: He tried to sneak out of the meeting without anyone seeing him.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to enter a place or conversation rudely and unexpectedly
phrasal verbs.example: He barged in without knocking and interrupted our discussion.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to become or make someone become more relaxed and less upset
phrasal verbs.example: It took a few minutes to calm her down after the argument.
phrasal verbs.translation: bình tĩnh lại; làm ai đó bình tĩnh

phrasal verbs.meaning: to stop being friendly with someone after having a disagreement
phrasal verbs.example: After their heated discussion, they fell out and stopped talking.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to raise a child or help them grow into an adult
phrasal verbs.example: He was brought up by his aunt after his parents passed away.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to feel annoyed or tired because of repeated or unpleasant experiences
phrasal verbs.example: She's fed up with working late every day without appreciation.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to be offensive or disrespectful, especially in sensitive situations
phrasal verbs.example: His comment about the tragedy was definitely in bad taste.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to be frequently seen or discussed in the media
phrasal verbs.example: Public figures must accept that they are always in the public eye.
phrasal verbs.translation: bị chú ý bởi công chúng

phrasal verbs.meaning: to refuse or reject an offer, request, or proposal
phrasal verbs.example: She turned down the scholarship because she wanted to stay close to home.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to spend too much time thinking or talking about something negative
phrasal verbs.example: Instead of dwelling on his failures, he focused on future goals.
phrasal verbs.translation: suy nghĩ tiêu cực mãi về

phrasal verbs.meaning: to be excited or happy about something that is going to happen
phrasal verbs.example: I’m looking forward to seeing my family this weekend.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to think that you are better or more important than someone else
phrasal verbs.example: He tends to look down on people who don’t share his opinions.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to keep telling someone what to do in an overly controlling way
phrasal verbs.example: Stop bossing your little brother around all the time.
phrasal verbs.translation: ra lệnh một cách hách dịch

phrasal verbs.meaning: to confront someone and refuse to be treated unfairly by them
phrasal verbs.example: She finally stood up to her boss and demanded respect.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to support or defend someone in a difficult situation
phrasal verbs.example: Her friends backed her up when she spoke out against the manager.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to search for information in a source like a dictionary or online
phrasal verbs.example: I had to look up the recipe online before cooking.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to carefully consider all aspects before making a decision
phrasal verbs.example: He needs to think through the plan before presenting it.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to stop working due to mechanical failure
phrasal verbs.example: My old laptop broke down during the presentation.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to become extremely upset or lose control due to fear or anger
phrasal verbs.example: He freaked out when he lost his phone.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to arrive or appear unexpectedly or after being missing
phrasal verbs.example: She turned up late to the meeting without explanation.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to board a vehicle such as a bus, plane, or bicycle
phrasal verbs.example: We got on the train just before it left the station.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to have no more items available for sale because everything has been bought
phrasal verbs.example: The concert tickets sold out in just ten minutes.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to participate in an activity that others are already doing
phrasal verbs.example: He joined in the game even though he arrived late.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to suddenly become unconscious
phrasal verbs.example: He passed out from exhaustion after the marathon.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to continue an activity that was already in progress
phrasal verbs.example: Despite the noise, she carried on reading her book.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to greatly impress or amaze someone
phrasal verbs.example: Her performance blew everyone away at the talent show.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to make a new product, book, or album available to the public
phrasal verbs.example: They brought out a new smartphone model last week.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to begin making a sound (like an alarm) or to explode suddenly
phrasal verbs.example: The fire alarm went off in the middle of the night.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to wake up later than planned or necessary
phrasal verbs.example: I accidentally slept in and missed the first meeting.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to spend time relaxing with someone or at a place
phrasal verbs.example: They often hang out at the coffee shop near campus.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to charge someone too much or cheat them financially
phrasal verbs.example: Tourists are often ripped off at local markets.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to be cautious or careful of possible danger or problems
phrasal verbs.example: Watch out for slippery floors after it rains.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to no longer have something because it has been used up
phrasal verbs.example: We ran out of coffee during the meeting.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to convince or persuade someone to do something
phrasal verbs.example: She talked me into applying for the internship.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to meet someone unexpectedly by chance
phrasal verbs.example: I ran into my old professor at the bookstore.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to vomit suddenly
phrasal verbs.example: He felt dizzy and threw up after the rollercoaster ride.

phrasal verbs.word: break up / break up with somebody [transitive/intransitive]
phrasal verbs.meaning: to end a romantic relationship
phrasal verbs.example: They broke up after five years together.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to act in a way that draws attention or admiration to oneself
phrasal verbs.example: He always shows off his expensive gadgets.

phrasal verbs.word: split up / split up with somebody [transitive/intransitive]
phrasal verbs.meaning: to end a relationship or marriage
phrasal verbs.example: The couple decided to split up after years of disagreement.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to begin living in a new house or with someone
phrasal verbs.example: They moved in together after getting engaged.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to flirt with someone in a romantic or sexual way
phrasal verbs.example: He was hitting on her all night at the party.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to continue doing something persistently, often annoyingly
phrasal verbs.example: She kept on talking even after the class had ended.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to act playfully or not take things seriously
phrasal verbs.example: He was just joking around and didn’t mean any harm.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to leave a house or apartment permanently
phrasal verbs.example: She moved out last week and found her own place.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to recover from emotional pain or stop being upset about something
phrasal verbs.example: It took her months to get over the breakup.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to start wearing clothes or to gain weight
phrasal verbs.example: She put on a warm jacket before going outside.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to return to a previous activity or habit
phrasal verbs.example: He's getting back into painting after a long break.
phrasal verbs.translation: quay lại với điều gì đó

phrasal verbs.meaning: to stop a habit or regular activity
phrasal verbs.example: She's decided to give up drinking coffee for a month.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to reduce the use or intake of something
phrasal verbs.example: I'm trying to cut down on sugar this month.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to have a meal at a restaurant instead of at home
phrasal verbs.example: We usually eat out on the weekends.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to put aside money for a purpose
phrasal verbs.example: He's saving up to buy a new laptop.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to dispose of or discard something
phrasal verbs.example: I threw out the old magazines to make space.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to understand or solve something
phrasal verbs.example: We need to figure out why the system keeps crashing.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to establish a business or organization
phrasal verbs.example: They set up a new startup focused on education.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to visit someone's house casually
phrasal verbs.example: My aunt called around yesterday to say hello.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to take care of someone or something
phrasal verbs.example: Can you look after my dog while I’m away?

phrasal verbs.meaning: to reach a final or unexpected situation
phrasal verbs.example: We ended up going to a different restaurant.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to maintain the same pace or level
phrasal verbs.example: I couldn’t keep up with the fast runners.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to stay awake until someone arrives
phrasal verbs.example: She waited up for her son to get home.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to return to a place
phrasal verbs.example: What time did you get back from work?

phrasal verbs.meaning: to move away from a place without permission or direction
phrasal verbs.example: The toddler wandered off while we were distracted.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to make something untidy or dirty
phrasal verbs.example: He messed up the kitchen while cooking.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to return something that was borrowed
phrasal verbs.example: Don't forget to give back the book you borrowed.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to not experience or take part in something
phrasal verbs.example: She missed out on the concert because of work.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to reconnect and update with someone after a while
phrasal verbs.example: We finally caught up over lunch last weekend.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to meet with someone to spend time together.
phrasal verbs.example: - I wanted to meet up sooner, but I didn't feel up to it. - I meet up with my friends every Friday night.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to feel capable of doing something.
phrasal verbs.example: - I wanted to meet up sooner, but I didn't feel up to it. - Do you feel up to walking in the park?

phrasal verbs.meaning: to fail to happen or be unsuccessful.
phrasal verbs.example: - I wanted to meet up sooner, but I didn't feel up to it. - Do you feel up to walking in the park?

phrasal verbs.meaning: to give something to someone for free because you don't need it anymore or to distribute something for free, often for promotional purposes.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. Another New Year's resolution is to give away all the clothes I don't use anymore. 2. I gave a lot of my old music records for free to the charity shop.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to start learning something new, like a new hobby or pastime.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. This year my main resolution is to take up a musical instrument, maybe the guitar. 2. She took up dancing at the age of 10 and now she is a professional dancer.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to continue doing something despite difficulties or not wanting to, to not give up or quit.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. My second resolution is to stick at the first resolution, even if it's difficult. 2. He found learning English difficult, but he stuck at it and now he speaks fluently.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to quit or stop attending a course, class, or sports team.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. To be honest, I am not enjoying it. I am thinking of dropping out! 2. Steve Jobs dropped out of college to start Apple Computers.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to continue for a longer time than expected or desired.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. Lectures seem to last forever. 2. The meeting dragged on for 3 hours. It should have been 1 hour.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to stop paying attention and become lost in one's thoughts.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. I'm constantly zoning out in class. 2. I zoned out in the middle of the meeting and didn't hear what my boss asked me to do.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to write something down on paper.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. It is also quite stressful because we have to take down so many notes in class. 2. The police officer took down the driver's information.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to become 'not up to date' or behind with something, such as work or payments.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. If you miss a day, it is very difficult to catch up. 2. Bob stayed in the office until nighttime to catch up on work.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to start to fall asleep.
phrasal verbs.example: I couldn't help drifting off in the middle of that lecture - it was so boring!

phrasal verbs.meaning: to make a great effort on a task, to concentrate and work hard on something.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. In the beginning, all the students were interested, but now they are all drifting off in class. 2. Paul was tired and drifted off in the middle of the movie.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to bring something for someone from another country or to return something that has been borrowed.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. They just told me I need to knuckle down! 2. The boss told his employees to knuckle down and finish the project.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if something or someone grows on you, you start to like them more.
phrasal verbs.example: I wasn't sure about this album when I bought it, but it's really grown on me.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to become more mature or an adult.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. Anyway, eventually it grew on me, and by the end, I was very sad to leave. 2. I didn't like my sister's boyfriend in the beginning, but he is growing on me. 1. It's a great experience; it made me grow up a lot. 2. Living alone when I went to university made me grow up a lot.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to resolve a problem or to organize or make arrangements for something.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. I am happy to be home, but I'm still trying to sort out everything at the moment. 2. Have you sorted out your accommodation for University yet?

phrasal verbs.meaning: to search for someone or something.
phrasal verbs.example: One thing that employers always look for in a candidate is a strong work ethic.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to replace someone in a job or position temporarily.
phrasal verbs.example: I still spend most of my time on the internet looking up potential clients. I didn't know the meaning of "silly," so I had to look the meaning up in the dictionary.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to have just enough money to buy the things you need - to survive financially.
phrasal verbs.example: So I'm getting by, but I really need to find a permanent job as soon as possible. Mary has 2 children and she works part-time. It is difficult for her to get by.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to return money you borrowed from someone (a bank or a friend).
phrasal verbs.example: I have to start paying back my student loans next month! Mike is still paying back the money he borrowed for his car.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to arrange for two people who you know to go out together on a date because you think they might like each other.
phrasal verbs.example: I've have a friend I want to set you up with.   My sister is always trying to set me up with her friends.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to have a good relationship with someone or to like a person.
phrasal verbs.example: I think you'd get on really well.  I have a good relationship with my new classmates.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to be successful, to end with a desired result, or to happen as planned.
phrasal verbs.example: I know you said you'd given up on dating after it didn't work out with Lucy.  My plan to hitchhike to the music festival wasn't successful/didn't happen as planned.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to change the subject of conversation, to change the company you work in, or to find another romantic partner after you have broken up with someone.
phrasal verbs.example: It's been almost a year since you broke up, and it's time to move on.   After 10 years working for the same company, I decided it was time to move on.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to become happier or less sad, or to make someone feel happier or less sad.
phrasal verbs.example: I think it's a really good idea, you need something to cheer you up.   Feel happier/Be less sad! It is not the end of the world.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to become attracted to somebody or start to fall in love with someone.
phrasal verbs.example: I know you will fall for her when you see her.  She fell in love with a younger man, and they got married.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to invite someone for a date.
phrasal verbs.example: Just give her a call and ask her out.  Kate always complains that no one ever asks her out.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to talk to someone you are romantically interested in to try to make them interested in you or to flirt with someone.
phrasal verbs.example: At least give it a chance, it's been months since you even chatted anyone up.   He spent the whole night talking to/flirting with a girl he liked.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to withdraw from a commitment, arrangement, or promise, or to cancel or decide not to do something because you are afraid.
phrasal verbs.example: Just turn up and see how things go - and don't back out at the last minute!   Paul was supposed to come on holidays with us, but he backed out.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to have an idea for something or to think of, create, invent, or discover something new.
phrasal verbs.example: If it doesn't go well, you can always come up with an excuse and leave early.   How did you think of the name for the band?

phrasal verbs.meaning: to return from somewhere with something
phrasal verbs.example: 1. I brought back a present for you; it's in my house. 2. My brother borrowed my car yesterday and hasn't brought it back yet.

phrasal verbs.meaning: If you fall behind, you do not make progress or move forward as fast as other people. f you fall behind, you do not make progress or move forward as fast as other people.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. Now, I have fallen behind so much! 2. She fell behind on her mortgage repayments, and now the bank wants to take her house.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to think about or try to understand something that is confusing or perplexing.
phrasal verbs.example: For centuries, historians and archaeologists have puzzled over the many mysteries of Stonehenge, a prehistoric monument that took an estimated 1,500 years to erect.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to be made up or composed of something; to consist of.
phrasal verbs.example: Located on Salisbury Plain in southern England, it is comprised of roughly 100 massive upright stones placed in a circular layout. The committee is comprised of five members.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To arrange for two people to go on a date together or start a romantic relationship.
phrasal verbs.example: I set up my best friend with a lady that I work with, and now they are happily married.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To have the opportunity to become famous and/or successful.
phrasal verbs.example: Many people work hard for years searching and waiting for their big break, but never quite find it.

phrasal verbs.meaning: Competition for power or influence in an office between different people. Considered usually to be negative.
phrasal verbs.example: People who retire often remark that they miss the camaraderie of working with people every day, but are glad to be free of office politics.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To find faults, flaws, or weaknesses in something, often by criticizing or scrutinizing it.
phrasal verbs.example: Instead of constantly picking holes in others' work, let's focus on constructive feedback and improvement. The reviewer seemed determined to pick holes in the author's argument rather than appreciating the overall message.

phrasal verbs.word: Get your foot in the door
phrasal verbs.meaning: To establish an initial connection or opportunity that may lead to further success or advancement.
phrasal verbs.example: 1. I managed to get my foot in the door at that company by starting as an intern.. Networking events are a great way to get your foot in the door and meet potential employers.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To agree or have the same opinion as someone else.
phrasal verbs.example: We don't always see eye to eye, but we respect each other's perspectives.t's important for team members to see eye to eye on the project's objectives.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To pay someone secretly or illegally, usually to avoid taxes or regulations. (Trả tiền chui, trả lương không khai báo để né thuế hoặc quy định pháp luật.)
phrasal verbs.example: It's illegal to pay workers under the table in many countries.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To discuss work-related topics or engage in conversation about one's profession or industry.
phrasal verbs.example: Whenever we meet up, we always end up talking shop and sharing industry insights.et's grab a coffee and talk shop sometime.

phrasal verbs.word: Put something on the back burner
phrasal verbs.meaning: To postpone or delay something, usually a task or project, in order to focus on more immediate or pressing matters.   I had to put my plans to start a business on the back burner because of other commitments.he company decided to put the new product development on the back burner until the market conditions improved.
phrasal verbs.example: She put her travel plans on the back burner while she focused on finishing her thesis.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To give up or surrender; to admit defeat.
phrasal verbs.example: After struggling for hours, he finally threw in the towel and accepted that he couldn't solve the problem.It's important to persevere and not throw in the towel when faced with challenges.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To put in additional effort or do more than what is expected.
phrasal verbs.example: If you want to succeed, you need to be willing to go the extra mile and exceed expectations.The employee always goes the extra mile to ensure customer satisfaction.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To think creatively or unconventionally; to approach a problem or situation in an innovative way.
phrasal verbs.example: In order to find a solution, we need to think outside of the box and consider alternative approaches.The company encourages its employees to think outside of the box and come up with fresh ideas.

phrasal verbs.word: Get off on the wrong foot
phrasal verbs.meaning: To start a relationship or situation in a negative or unfavorable way.
phrasal verbs.example: We got off on the wrong foot when we had a misunderstanding during our first meeting.It's important to establish a positive first impression and avoid getting off on the wrong foot.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To maintain one's position, opinions, or beliefs firmly, especially in the face of opposition or pressure.
phrasal verbs.example: Even when others disagree, it's important to stand your ground if you truly believe in something.The negotiator stood his ground and refused to compromise on the key terms of the agreement.

phrasal verbs.word: Run around like a headless chicken
phrasal verbs.meaning: To act in a frantic, disorganized, or chaotic manner.
phrasal verbs.example: When the deadline was approaching, everyone was running around like headless chickens trying to get everything done.Instead of panicking and running around like headless chickens, let's approach the situation calmly and systematically.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To get to the main point or important information without wasting time on unnecessary details.
phrasal verbs.example: We don't have much time, so let's cut to the chase and discuss the key issues.Instead of beating around the bush, it's better to cut to the chase and address the core problem.

phrasal verbs.meaning: Something that initially appears to be negative or unfortunate but turns out to be beneficial or advantageous.
phrasal verbs.example: Losing my job was a blessing in disguise because it pushed me to pursue a career I truly love.Sometimes, setbacks can be a blessing in disguise and lead to unexpected opportunities.

phrasal verbs.word: Cost an arm and a leg
phrasal verbs.meaning: To be very expensive; to cost a lot of money.
phrasal verbs.example: The new smartphone model looks great, but it costs an arm and a leg.Traveling during peak season can be expensive and may cost you an arm and a leg.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To learn the basic skills or procedures of a job or activity.
phrasal verbs.example: As a new employee, it takes time to learn the ropes and become familiar with the company's processes.It's important to have a mentor who can help you learn the ropes in your chosen field.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To manipulate financial records or accounts dishonestly, usually for personal gain or to deceive others.
phrasal verbs.example: The company was caught cooking the books to inflate their profits and mislead investors.It's illegal and unethical to cook the books in order to evade taxes or deceive stakeholders.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To make an unsolicited phone call or visit to someone, typically for sales or business purposes.
phrasal verbs.example: As a salesperson, you need to be prepared when making cold calls to potential clients.Making cold calls can be challenging, but it can also lead to new business opportunities.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To receive approval or permission to proceed with a project, plan, or action.
phrasal verbs.example: After presenting our proposal, we finally got the green light to start the project.The team can't start the development until they get the green light from the management.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To persuade or convince someone to do something, often through persistent or forceful means.
phrasal verbs.example: I had to twist his arm to get him to join us for the team outing.The salesperson managed to twist my arm and convince me to buy the product.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To operate with a very limited budget or resources.
phrasal verbs.example: As a startup, we had to run on a shoestring budget until we secured more funding.The nonprofit organization manages to run on a shoestring and still make a positive impact.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To be overwhelmed or swamped with a large amount of work or responsibilities.
phrasal verbs.example: I can't meet for lunch today; I'm snowed under with deadlines.During the holiday season, retail workers are often snowed under with customer demands.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To be in a state of financial loss (in the red) or profit (in the black).
phrasal verbs.example: The company has been struggling and is currently in the red.Thanks to increased sales, the business is finally back in the black.

phrasal verbs.word: Be a big fish in a small pond
phrasal verbs.meaning: To be important or influential in a small or limited environment or context.
phrasal verbs.example: He enjoys being a big fish in a small pond in his hometown, but he wants to explore bigger opportunities.Some people prefer to be a big fish in a small pond rather than a small fish in a big pond.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To be more advanced, innovative, or knowledgeable than others in a particular area.
phrasal verbs.example: The company invests in research and development to stay ahead of the curve in the industry.By constantly learning and adapting, you can stay ahead of the curve in your career.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To remain well-informed, organized, and in control of a situation or tasks.
phrasal verbs.example: It's important to stay on top of things to ensure nothing falls through the cracks.With effective time management, you can stay on top of things and avoid feeling overwhelmed.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To handle a situation or make decisions as it unfolds, without a predetermined plan.
phrasal verbs.example: We don't have a fixed agenda for the meeting, so let's play it by ear and see how the discussion goes.When traveling, it's sometimes more exciting to play things by ear and be open to unexpected opportunities.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To ask someone for advice, information, or opinions on a particular topic.
phrasal verbs.example: I need to pick your brains about the best practices in project management.The new intern is eager to pick the experienced team members' brains and learn from their expertise.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To take shortcuts or bypass proper procedures in order to save time, effort, or money.
phrasal verbs.example: Cutting corners in quality control can lead to product defects and customer dissatisfaction.It's important to follow the established guidelines and not cut corners when it comes to safety.

phrasal verbs.word: Take the bull by the horns
phrasal verbs.meaning: To confront or tackle a difficult or challenging situation directly and with determination.
phrasal verbs.example: Instead of avoiding the problem, it's time to take the bull by the horns and find a solution.The team leader decided to take the bull by the horns and address the team's performance issues.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To be dismissed or lose one's job, usually due to poor performance, misconduct, or downsizing.
phrasal verbs.example: He got fired for consistently arriving late to work.Getting fired can be a difficult experience, but it can also be an opportunity for growth and change.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To be unproductive, ineffective, or no longer useful in a particular role or organization.
phrasal verbs.example: The company had to let go of employees who were considered dead wood and not contributing to the team.It's important to continuously develop new skills and stay relevant to avoid becoming dead wood in your career.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To leave a stressful, competitive, and demanding job or lifestyle in pursuit of a simpler, more fulfilling life.
phrasal verbs.example: After years of working in the corporate world, she decided to quit the rat race and start her own business.Many people dream of quitting the rat race and finding a better work-life balance.

phrasal verbs.word: Go back to the drawing board
phrasal verbs.meaning: To start over or reconsider a plan, idea, or design because it is not working or needs improvement.
phrasal verbs.example: The initial concept was not well-received, so we had to go back to the drawing board and come up with a new approach.Sometimes, it's necessary to go back to the drawing board and make revisions to achieve better results.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To miss an opportunity or fail to take advantage of a favorable situation.
phrasal verbs.example: I missed the boat on investing in that company, and now their stock price has skyrocketed.It's important to stay alert and seize opportunities; otherwise, you may miss the boat.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To act prematurely or before the appropriate time; to start or do something too soon.
phrasal verbs.example: Let's not jump the gun and make a decision without considering all the facts.The team announced the product launch date, but they jumped the gun as the development was not yet complete.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To be informed or included in a group or situation where important information is shared.
phrasal verbs.example: As a project manager, it's crucial to be in the loop and aware of any updates or changes.The team members meet regularly to ensure everyone is in the loop and aligned with the project goals.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To change the rules, requirements, or expectations of a situation or agreement, often to make it more difficult for someone to succeed.
phrasal verbs.example: The company kept moving the goalposts, making it challenging for the employees to meet their targets.It's important to establish clear expectations and not move the goalposts during a project.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To become well-known, recognized, or famous, especially in a particular field or location.
phrasal verbs.example: The success of their latest product launch put the company on the map in the tech industry.The city's vibrant art scene has put it on the map as a cultural destination.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To do the hard, tedious, or laborious tasks or groundwork that are necessary but not glamorous.
phrasal verbs.example: The interns were assigned to do the donkey work, such as data entry and filing.Before the event, the team had to do the donkey work of setting up the venue and arranging logistics.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To join or support a popular trend, movement, or opinion, often without considering it critically.
phrasal verbs.example: Many companies jumped on the bandwagon and started offering subscription-based services.It's important to evaluate the pros and cons before jumping on the bandwagon of a new investment trend.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To maintain control or responsibility for a situation or place while someone is temporarily absent.
phrasal verbs.example: I need to step out for a meeting; can you hold the fort until I return.The manager asked the team to hold the fort while she was on vacation.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To yield positive results or benefits over time, often as a result of an investment or effort.
phrasal verbs.example: Regular exercise and a healthy diet pay dividends in terms of improved overall well-being.Investing in employee training and development can pay dividends in the form of increased productivity.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To have all the advantages, power, or control in a situation.
phrasal verbs.example: With their extensive network and resources, they hold all the aces in the industry.The team with the most data and insights holds all the aces when it comes to making informed decisions.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To quit or retire from a situation or endeavor, often referring to leaving a job or ending a career.
phrasal verbs.example: After working for decades, he decided to cash in his chips and enjoy his retirement.It's important to plan for the future and have financial security before cashing in your chips.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To consider, accept, or incorporate something, such as feedback, suggestions, or ideas.
phrasal verbs.example: The manager took our concerns on board and implemented changes to improve the work environment.It's important to be open-minded and take constructive criticism on board for personal growth.

phrasal verbs.meaning: To stop working or end an activity for the day.
phrasal verbs.example: After working for hours, we decided to call it a day and go home. We couldn't finish the project today, so let's call it a day and continue tomorrow. Translation (Vietnamese): Kết thúc một ngày làm việc (hoặc một hoạt động nào đó).

phrasal verbs.meaning: combine to produce a particular result or effect: tương đương với
phrasal verbs.example: These new measures do not add up to genuine reform.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if separate amounts add up to a total amount, together they form that total: tổng cộng lên tới
phrasal verbs.example: His business expenses add up to around £4,000 a year.

phrasal verbs.meaning: reply rudely to someone who has more authority than you: cãi lại
phrasal verbs.example: I got into trouble for answering the teacher back.

phrasal verbs.meaning: invite someone to go with you to a cinema, restaurant, etc., to start a romantic or sexual relationship with them: rủ đi chơi
phrasal verbs.example: Fred asked Vanessa to go out with him but she said no.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop asking for something or stop saying that you will do something, because a lot of people oppose you: rút lại ý kiến
phrasal verbs.example: I’m not going to back down just because a few people disagree with me.

phrasal verbs.meaning: give support to someone by telling other people that you agree with them: ủng hộ
phrasal verbs.example: I didn’t believe Simon’s story until Janice backed him up.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make a copy of information on your computer: sao lưu dữ liệu
phrasal verbs.example: Make sure you back all your data up, just in case you get a virus.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make a place dark by turning off all the lights: làm đen kịt, tối om
phrasal verbs.example: The whole city was blacked out for nights on end during the war.

phrasal verbs.meaning: suddenly become unconscious: ngất lịm
phrasal verbs.example: He had blacked out as his car hit the tree.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make something happen, especially to cause changes in a situation: gây ra - negative, giải quyết xong - positive
phrasal verbs.example: It’s not something we can bring about overnight.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make someone or something show a quality that they have: làm nổi bật
phrasal verbs.example: That dress really brings out the green in your eyes.

phrasal verbs.meaning: produce a new product and start to sell it: phát hành
phrasal verbs.example: They’ve brought out a new 3D video camera.

phrasal verbs.meaning: create a situation in which people meet and do something together: làm (một nhóm) gắn nhau hơn
phrasal verbs.example: The attack on the city really brought people together.

phrasal verbs.meaning: practise and improve your skills or knowledge of something: ôn lại, trau chuốt
phrasal verbs.example: I took a class to brush up on my German before the trip.

phrasal verbs.meaning: gradually develop: gây dựng, phát triển
phrasal verbs.example: Many popular writers built up their reputations during the war.

phrasal verbs.meaning: increase or make something increase: tăng lên
phrasal verbs.example: The food industry needs to build up consumer confidence again.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make someone bigger, healthier, and stronger by making them eat more: lớn lên, phát triển
phrasal verbs.example: You need lots of fresh fruit to help build you up.

phrasal verbs.meaning: accidentally hit against something: va phải
phrasal verbs.example: It was a surprise when I bumped into her downtown.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if someone or something blends in, they are similar to the other people, objects, buildings, etc around them, and so they seem appropriate or you do not notice them: hòa nhập.
phrasal verbs.example: The building doesn’t really blend in very well with the others around it.

phrasal verbs.meaning: say something suddenly and without thinking about the effect it will have, usually because you are nervous or excited: thốt ra.
phrasal verbs.example: She blurted out his name, then gasped as she realised what she’d done.

phrasal verbs.meaning: cover a window or door with wooden boards: bịt kín.
phrasal verbs.example: We boarded the house up because we knew a bad storm was coming.

phrasal verbs.meaning: break something to make smaller pieces: đập bé.
phrasal verbs.example: The amount doesn’t seem quite so bad when you break it down into monthly payments.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if a meeting or other event breaks up, or if you break it up, it ends and people leave: kết thúc.
phrasal verbs.example: The meeting finally broke up after three hours.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if two people break up, they end their relationship: chia tay.
phrasal verbs.example: When did Diana and James break up?

phrasal verbs.meaning: if the weather brightens up, it becomes sunnier: trở nên tốt hơn.
phrasal verbs.example: It’s brightening up, at last.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start looking or feeling happier: trở nên rạng rõ hơn.
phrasal verbs.example: Sarah brightened up considerably as she thought of Emily’s words.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start to have more colour or light, give something more colour or light: trở nên đẹp/hấp dẫn hơn.
phrasal verbs.example: You could brighten up that skirt with a red blouse.

phrasal verbs.meaning: meet someone unexpectedly: tình cờ gặp.
phrasal verbs.example: Guess who I bumped into in town?

phrasal verbs.meaning: give someone money so that they do not act against you: đút lót.
phrasal verbs.example: Efforts to buy her off have failed.

phrasal verbs.meaning: pay money to your business partner so that you can control all of a business you previously owned together: mua lại.
phrasal verbs.example: The other directors have offered to buy me out.

phrasal verbs.meaning: buy large amounts of something or all of it that is available: mua hết, mua sạch.
phrasal verbs.example: Developers have been buying up old theatres and converting them into cinemas.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop something from having any effect: triệt tiêu.
phrasal verbs.example: These headphones cancel out any other noise so all you can hear is the music.

phrasal verbs.meaning: take something that you earn or are given in one year or period of time into the next one: kéo dài, chuyển sang.
phrasal verbs.example: You are not allowed to carry over holiday entitlement from one year into the next.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become popular or fashionable: trở thành mốt.
phrasal verbs.example: Sports drinks have caught on as consumers have become more health-conscious.

phrasal verbs.meaning: understand: hiểu.
phrasal verbs.example: He didn’t catch on at first.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if something centres around someone or something, or you centre something around them, they are its main subject of attention or interest: xoay quanh.
phrasal verbs.example: The book centres around a woman who becomes an astronaut.

phrasal verbs.meaning: find or see someone or something when you did not expect to: tình cờ tìm thấy.
phrasal verbs.example: We chanced upon a charming little restaurant.

phrasal verbs.meaning: move things so that they are in different places or positions: di chuyển đồ vật.
phrasal verbs.example: My friends had changed all the furniture in my room around as a joke.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop being in one state, condition or form and start being in another, or make something do this: biến đổi thành.
phrasal verbs.example: The film was about a man who changes into a werewolf during the full moon.

phrasal verbs.meaning: take off the clothes or a piece of clothing you are wearing and put on different ones: thay (quần áo) ra.
phrasal verbs.example: Let me just change into something a bit more comfortable.

phrasal verbs.meaning: take off the clothes or a piece of clothing you are wearing and put on different ones: thay (quần áo) ra.
phrasal verbs.example: Come inside and change out of those wet things.

phrasal verbs.meaning: examine someone or something in order to be certain that everything is correct, true or satisfactory: kiểm tra, rà soát.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve been taking lots of photographs, just to check out the camera.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if information checks out, you feel that it is true after examining it: đúng sự thật.
phrasal verbs.example: Their story just didn’t check out.

phrasal verbs.meaning: reach a particular number or amount: đạt mức.
phrasal verbs.example: Mr. Dawson has clocked up 34 years as a police officer.

phrasal verbs.meaning: lock the doors of a building or business: khóa lại, đóng lại.
phrasal verbs.example: The newsagent was closing up for the evening.

phrasal verbs.meaning: share the cost of something, each of the people giving some of the money: góp tiền.
phrasal verbs.example: Let’s all club together and buy her a nice present.

phrasal verbs.meaning: meet someone or find something by chance: tình cờ gặp.
phrasal verbs.example: I came across a reference to my grandfather in an old book.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change your opinion or decision because someone has persuaded you to agree with them: thay đổi quan điểm.
phrasal verbs.example: I didn’t agree at first but I’ve come (a)round to the idea now.

phrasal verbs.meaning: cause a disagreement or argument between people: xen vào, gây mâu thuẫn.
phrasal verbs.example: I would never let anything come between us.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be removed from something such as clothing or cloth by washing or rubbing; bị xóa, biến khỏi.
phrasal verbs.example: The stain finally came off, but I had to wash the T-shirt three times.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be spoken, heard or understood in a particular way: được hiểu.
phrasal verbs.example: That came out wrong. Let me rephrase it.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become available to buy or see: được phát hành.
phrasal verbs.example: The magazine comes out every Thursday.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become easy to notice: được lộ.
phrasal verbs.example: These differences don’t come out until you put the two groups in a room together.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become known: được công khai.
phrasal verbs.example: He said it’ll all come out in court.

phrasal verbs.meaning: have a particular result or end in a particular way: kết quả.
phrasal verbs.example: Everything came out all right in the end.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become conscious again after being unconscious: tỉnh lại.
phrasal verbs.example: I felt sick when I came round after the operation.

phrasal verbs.meaning: meet someone or find something by chance: tình cờ gặp.
phrasal verbs.example: I came across a reference to my grandfather in an old book.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change your opinion or decision because someone has persuaded you to agree with them: thay đổi quan điểm.
phrasal verbs.example: I didn’t agree at first but I’ve come (a)round to the idea now.

phrasal verbs.meaning: cause a disagreement or argument between people: gây mâu thuẫn.
phrasal verbs.example: I would never let anything come between us.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be removed from something such as clothing or cloth by washing or rubbing: bị xóa, biến khỏi.
phrasal verbs.example: The stain finally came out, but I had to wash the T-shirt three times.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be spoken, heard or understood in a particular way: được hiểu.
phrasal verbs.example: That came out wrong. Let me rephrase it.

phrasal verbs.meaning: think of something such as an idea or a plan: nghĩ ra.
phrasal verbs.example: He came up with a great plan to solve the issue.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop people from entering an area by putting something such as a rope around it: chặn đường.
phrasal verbs.example: The police cordoned off the crime scene.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start dealing with someone or something much more strictly: trừng trị.
phrasal verbs.example: It’s about time they cracked down on people who drop litter.

phrasal verbs.meaning: move towards someone quietly and slowly, especially because you want to surprise them: lén tiếp cận.
phrasal verbs.example: Watch out as it crept up on a bird.

phrasal verbs.meaning: reduce the amount of something, especially money that you spend: cắt giảm.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m trying to cut back on eating out to save money.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop eating or doing something, especially because it is bad for your health: cắt giảm.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m going to have to cut coffee out because it gives me indigestion.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become weaker or less common and then disappear completely: biến mất hoàn toàn.
phrasal verbs.example: Some old traditions die out, but others survive.

phrasal verbs.meaning: find information by searching carefully: tìm kiếm kỹ.
phrasal verbs.example: See what you can dig up on the Internet on Mr. Anderson.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become cooler, or make something cooler: hạ nhiệt.
phrasal verbs.example: It’s cooler now after the rain; we should cool down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: go to a place where someone is, especially their house, in order to visit them: ghé thăm.
phrasal verbs.example: Why don’t you come round for lunch?

phrasal verbs.meaning: if a regular event comes round, it happens again: tái diễn.
phrasal verbs.example: Jean’s annual garden party must be coming round soon.

phrasal verbs.meaning: examine someone or something in order to be certain that everything is correct, true or satisfactory: kiểm tra, rà soát.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve been taking lots of photographs just to check out the camera.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to find and remind someone to do something: đuổi theo.
phrasal verbs.example: The detectives chased up all leads to track the suspect.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to gather closely in a group around someone: tụ tập quanh.
phrasal verbs.example: Everyone crowded around the star for autographs.

phrasal verbs.meaning: arrive and register at a hotel or airport: đăng ký.
phrasal verbs.example: We checked in two hours before our flight.

phrasal verbs.meaning: remove something from under the ground by digging: khai quật
phrasal verbs.example: Archaeologists have dug up a bag of coins from Roman times.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start doing something in a very enthusiastic way: bắt đầu làm một cách say mê
phrasal verbs.example: Sometimes you’ve just got to take a chance and dive in.

phrasal verbs.meaning: get rid of: loại bỏ
phrasal verbs.example: Did you hear that they’re going to do away with private universities altogether?

phrasal verbs.meaning: fasten (an item of clothing): cài
phrasal verbs.example: Do your coat up or you’ll catch cold.

phrasal verbs.meaning: try to make people support you or buy something from you: lôi kéo khách hàng cho
phrasal verbs.example: Advertisements should help to drum up some business.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if something dries up or is dried up, all the water comes out of it: cạn khô, ráo nước
phrasal verbs.example: The river has completely dried up.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop being available: hết
phrasal verbs.example: I’m a TV repairman, but work seems to have dried up lately.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be in a particular place or state after doing something or because of doing it: có kết cục/ kết thúc
phrasal verbs.example: Keep on doing that and you’ll end up in serious trouble.

phrasal verbs.meaning: accept something and try to deal with it: đường đầu, đối mặt
phrasal verbs.example: He was the only one who faced up to the problem.

phrasal verbs.meaning: disappear slowly: dần biến mất
phrasal verbs.example: To my amazement, the letters on the page slowly faded away.

phrasal verbs.meaning: disappear slowly: dần biến mất
phrasal verbs.example: To my amazement, the letters on the page slowly faded away.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make less progress or be less successful than other people who are doing a similar job or activity: tụt hậu
phrasal verbs.example: I was off school for two months with my illness and I fell behind the others.

phrasal verbs.meaning: move more slowly than other people so that you are behind them: tụt lại phía sau
phrasal verbs.example: I got tired on the walk and gradually fell behind the rest.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be able to understand something or solve a problem or understand what someone is like and why they behave in the way they do: hiểu được, tìm ra
phrasal verbs.example: We had to figure out the connection between the two events.

phrasal verbs.meaning: clean, repair or decorate something: sửa chữa, phục hồi
phrasal verbs.example: Why don’t we try to fix up that old bike of yours?

phrasal verbs.meaning: check the health of someone who has received medical treatment in order to be certain that it was effective: theo dõi sức khỏe
phrasal verbs.example: The study followed up over 200 heart patients.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to deal with it: điều tra thêm
phrasal verbs.example: The police are now following up some new leads.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make people understand something: truyền đạt
phrasal verbs.example: We’ve got to get the message across more clearly.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if news gets (a)round, a lot of people hear it: trở nên phổ biến
phrasal verbs.example: The rumours got around town very quickly, didn’t they?

phrasal verbs.meaning: make someone feel sad or lose hope, start feeling sad or losing hope: làm buồn/ thất vọng
phrasal verbs.example: Doing the same thing every day can get you down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be elected for a political job: được bầu chọn
phrasal verbs.example: If I get in, there’ll be a few changes around here.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become involved in a bad situation: dính phải, vướng vào
phrasal verbs.example: Craig started to get into crime while he was still at school.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if a train, plane, etc. gets into a place, it arrives there: đến nơi
phrasal verbs.example: What time do we get into Norwich?

phrasal verbs.meaning: start enjoying something or become enthusiastic about it: bắt đầu thích
phrasal verbs.example: It took me a while to get into this CD, but now I listen to it all the time.

phrasal verbs.meaning: have a particular period of time as a holiday: được nghỉ vào dịp
phrasal verbs.example: Will you get Easter off?

phrasal verbs.meaning: not be punished severely or at all for something you have been accused of in court: thoát tội
phrasal verbs.example: I can’t believe he got off when there was so much evidence against him.

phrasal verbs.meaning: send something, for example in the post: gửi
phrasal verbs.example: I’ll get those invitations off tomorrow.

phrasal verbs.meaning: find a way to solve or deal with a difficult problem: giải quyết
phrasal verbs.example: There are many hurdles still to get over before the new restaurant can open.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start to feel happy or well again after something bad has happened to you, start to forget someone and feel happy again after a relationship has ended: vượt qua (chuyện buồn)
phrasal verbs.example: It can take weeks to get over an illness like that.

phrasal verbs.meaning: finish dealing with some work, a subject, etc: hoàn thành
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve got a lot of work to get through.

phrasal verbs.meaning: manage to deal with a difficult situation or stay alive until it is over: thoát được khỏi, sống sót
phrasal verbs.example: How we got through it I’ll never know.

phrasal verbs.meaning: use or finish something: dùng, sử dụng
phrasal verbs.example: We get through a litre of milk a day.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be connected to a place by telephone: được nối máy
phrasal verbs.example: I tried calling him but I couldn’t get through for some reason.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make someone understand what you are trying to say: truyền đạt, giải thích
phrasal verbs.example: The teacher feels he is not getting through to some of the kids in his class.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if you give in to something, you can no longer control the feeling of wanting it: thỏa hiệp
phrasal verbs.example: I finally gave in and had a cream cake.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop competing or arguing and accept that you cannot win: chịu thua
phrasal verbs.example: In the end, I gave in and accepted that she was right.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become lost or go to the wrong place: bị lạc đường
phrasal verbs.example: We went astray but soon found our way again.

phrasal verbs.meaning: produce a particular reaction: (không) được đón nhận (bởi ai)
phrasal verbs.example: The plan to put rents up has not gone down well with tenants.

phrasal verbs.meaning: choose something as a subject of study or as your career: theo đuổi ngành/nghề
phrasal verbs.example: I’m going to go in for dentistry.

phrasal verbs.meaning: enjoy a particular thing or activity: thích, hưởng ứng
phrasal verbs.example: My dad doesn’t really go in for parties.

phrasal verbs.meaning: explode or be fired: phát nổ
phrasal verbs.example: A bomb has gone off in the shopping mall.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if food or drink goes off, it is no longer fresh: bị ôi thiu
phrasal verbs.example: Does this milk smell like it’s gone off to you?

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave a place, especially for a particular purpose: rời đi
phrasal verbs.example: Pete’s just gone off to get some chewing gum.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop liking someone or something: chán, không còn ưa thích
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve gone off peanuts, for some reason.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if two or more things go together, they frequently exist together: đi liền với nhau
phrasal verbs.example: Why do poverty and crime go together so often?

phrasal verbs.meaning: if two things go together, they seem good, natural or attractive in combination with each other: phù hợp
phrasal verbs.example: Do this skirt and this top go together?

phrasal verbs.meaning: if something or someone grows on you, you start to like them more: khiến ai bắt đầu thích
phrasal verbs.example: I didn’t like that painting at first, but it’s growing on me.

phrasal verbs.meaning: lean out of a window so that the top part of your body is outside: thò đầu/ người ra khỏi (cửa sổ)
phrasal verbs.example: Don’t hang out of the window or you’ll fall!

phrasal verbs.meaning: spend time in a particular place or with particular people: hẹn hò, đi chơi
phrasal verbs.example: We often just hang out at each other’s houses.

phrasal verbs.meaning: prevent someone from going somewhere by getting in front of them: chặn đường
phrasal verbs.example: One police officer chased the robber while the other went to head him off.

phrasal verbs.meaning: prevent something from taking place: ngăn chặn
phrasal verbs.example: The UN has sent emergency aid into the area to head off a catastrophe.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make something hot; become hot: (làm) nóng lên
phrasal verbs.example: Heat up the baby’s milk, would you?

phrasal verbs.meaning: criticise someone who has criticised you: phản pháo
phrasal verbs.example: The Minister hit back at his critics.

phrasal verbs.meaning: deliberately hurt someone who has hurt you: trả đòn
phrasal verbs.example: If someone hits you, think before you hit back next time.

phrasal verbs.meaning: destroy a building or wall: đổ bỏ, phá hủy
phrasal verbs.example: I see they’ve finally knocked the old factory down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start working hard, especially when you should have done this earlier: bắt tay vào làm, nỗ lực
phrasal verbs.example: It’s time for me to knuckle down and get this finished.

phrasal verbs.meaning: speak angrily to or against someone: chỉ trích, đả kích
phrasal verbs.example: They lashed out at the council’s move to stop free parking.

phrasal verbs.meaning: try to hit or attack someone suddenly and violently: tấn công
phrasal verbs.example: Occasionally the patients will lash out at the nurses.

phrasal verbs.meaning: end someone’s employment, especially temporarily, because there is not enough work for them: sa thải
phrasal verbs.example: They’ve had to cut back production and lay off workers.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop doing or using something, especially for a short period of time: ngừng
phrasal verbs.example: Lay off teasing your brother, Julie!

phrasal verbs.meaning: relax and enjoy yourself, doing no work: nghỉ xả hơi
phrasal verbs.example: I’m just planning to laze around this weekend.

phrasal verbs.meaning: talk about something that is intended to be a secret: tiết lộ
phrasal verbs.example: He knows more than he lets on.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if something lies ahead, it is going to happen to you in the future: trước mắt, ở tương lai
phrasal verbs.example: A bright future lies ahead of him.

phrasal verbs.meaning: give something a more interesting appearance, taste or other quality: làm đẹp hơn
phrasal verbs.example: You can liven up a plain shirt with a colourful scarf.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make something more interesting or exciting, or become more interesting or exciting: làm thú vị hơn, cải thiện
phrasal verbs.example: What we needed was some music to liven things up.

phrasal verbs.meaning: discover something by chance: tình cờ phát hiện. She was scared he might hit upon the truth.
phrasal verbs.example: She was scared he might hit upon the truth.

phrasal verbs.meaning: suddenly have an idea: chợt nghĩ ra. They hit upon the idea of celebrating the occasion with a concert.
phrasal verbs.example: They hit upon the idea of celebrating the occasion with a concert.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop someone or something from moving forwards: giữ lại. The police held back the crowd.
phrasal verbs.example: The police held back the crowd.

phrasal verbs.meaning: continue to do something: tiếp tục. I don’t think I can afford to keep up my piano lessons.
phrasal verbs.example: I don’t think I can afford to keep up my piano lessons.

phrasal verbs.meaning: move at the same speed as someone or something: theo kịp. Dan walks so fast that it’s not easy to keep up with him.
phrasal verbs.example: Dan walks so fast that it’s not easy to keep up with him.

phrasal verbs.meaning: put information into a computer or other electronic machine using keys or a keyboard: nhập liệu, đánh máy. All you have to do is key your details in and the computer does the rest.
phrasal verbs.example: All you have to do is key your details in and the computer does the rest.

phrasal verbs.meaning: begin (with): bắt đầu. I’d like to kick off with a quick look at last month’s sales figures.
phrasal verbs.example: I’d like to kick off with a quick look at last month’s sales figures.

phrasal verbs.meaning: destroy living things so that most or all of them are dead: tàn sát. The pollution killed off all the fish in the lake.
phrasal verbs.example: The pollution killed off all the fish in the lake.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop working: ngừng làm việc. Do you want to knock off early tonight?
phrasal verbs.example: Do you want to knock off early tonight?

phrasal verbs.meaning: lock all the doors and windows of a building so that no one can get in: khóa toàn bộ cửa. I must have forgotten to lock up when I left this morning.
phrasal verbs.example: I must have forgotten to lock up when I left this morning.

phrasal verbs.meaning: put someone in a prison: tống giam.
phrasal verbs.example: They should lock him up for a very long time, if you ask me.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change someone or something so that they become something else: biến đổi thành. It’s as if my parents are trying to make me into the ideal student, so I’m under a lot of pressure.
phrasal verbs.example: It’s as if my parents are trying to make me into the ideal student, so I’m under a lot of pressure.

phrasal verbs.meaning: see, hear or understand someone or something with difficulty: nhận ra, xác định. Can you make out a face here in the photograph?
phrasal verbs.example: Can you make out a face here in the photograph?

phrasal verbs.meaning: change or improve the appearance of someone or something makeover (n): chỉnh trang, thay đổi diện mạo. They made over three contestants on the show. When they’d finished, they looked completely different.
phrasal verbs.example: They made over three contestants on the show. When they’d finished, they looked completely different.

phrasal verbs.meaning: work at different times from usual because you have not worked enough at the normal times: bù vào. Sorry I’m late; I’ll make up the time this evening.
phrasal verbs.example: Sorry I’m late; I’ll make up the time this evening.

phrasal verbs.meaning: come together with someone, either unexpectedly or as planned: gặp gỡ. Why don’t we meet up when I’m in Berlin, since it’s not far from you?
phrasal verbs.example: Why don’t we meet up when I’m in Berlin, since it’s not far from you?

phrasal verbs.meaning: behave in a silly way: hành xử ngớ ngẩn. Mrs Evans asked the children to stop messing around.
phrasal verbs.example: Mrs Evans asked the children to stop messing around.

phrasal verbs.meaning: move so that sb can pass you: nhường đường.
phrasal verbs.example: We stepped aside to let someone in a wheelchair through.

phrasal verbs.meaning: visit somewhere before continuing to another place: nghỉ giữa đường.
phrasal verbs.example: We can stop off at the bakery on the way to school.

phrasal verbs.meaning: do something that will cause problems in the future: tích lũy, dồn nén.
phrasal verbs.example: If you ignore it, you’re just storing up problems for the future.

phrasal verbs.meaning: keep a lot of something so that you can use it later: tích trữ.
phrasal verbs.example: Squirrel store up nuts for the winter.

phrasal verbs.meaning: manage to produce a quality or a reaction that helps you deal with a difficult situation: dồn hết can đảm/ sức lực để làm gì.
phrasal verbs.example: He couldn’t summon up the strength to carry on fighting.

phrasal verbs.meaning: study something very hard, especially for an examination: học gạo.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve got to swot up on the French Revolution for tomorrow’s test.

phrasal verbs.meaning: look or behave like an older relative: giống.
phrasal verbs.example: Doesn’t she take after her mother?

phrasal verbs.meaning: separate an object into pieces: tách rời, tách nhỏ.
phrasal verbs.example: I took my computer apart completely, but I still didn’t find the problem.

phrasal verbs.meaning: remove one number or quantity from another number or quantity: trừ, bớt đi.
phrasal verbs.example: If you take three away from five, you’re left with two.

phrasal verbs.meaning: separate a large structure into pieces: tháo dỡ.
phrasal verbs.example: After the play, we had to take down all the scenery.

phrasal verbs.meaning: write down information or a statement: ghi chép lại.
phrasal verbs.example: The police took down my details.

phrasal verbs.meaning: accept something as real or true: chấp nhận.
phrasal verbs.example: He still hasn’t really taken in his father’s death.

phrasal verbs.meaning: include something: bao gồm.
phrasal verbs.example: The tour takes in some incredible scenery.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become successful or popular very fast: phát lên.
phrasal verbs.example: The new design took off immediately.

phrasal verbs.meaning: accept some work or responsibility: nhận nhiệm vụ.
phrasal verbs.example: I can’t take on any more work at the moment.

phrasal verbs.meaning: take someone to a place like a cinema or a restaurant and usually pay for them: đưa đi chơi.
phrasal verbs.example: On my birthday, he took me out for dinner.

phrasal verbs.meaning: begin to do something that someone else was doing: tiếp quản.
phrasal verbs.example: When my dad retired, I took over the business.

phrasal verbs.meaning: gain control of something: nắm quyền kiểm soát.
phrasal verbs.example: Whenever we start organising something, you always want to take over.

phrasal verbs.meaning: begin to like someone or something: bắt đầu thích.
phrasal verbs.example: I didn’t take to living here straight away.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start doing something as a habit: bắt đầu thói quen.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve taken to getting up much earlier.

phrasal verbs.meaning: talk to someone as if they are not as clever or important as you are: lên giọng kể cả.
phrasal verbs.example: I hate the way Belinda talks down to people.

phrasal verbs.meaning: discuss a problem or a plan: thảo luận.
phrasal verbs.example: Let’s talk it over tonight.

phrasal verbs.meaning: succeed in persuading someone to agree to something: thuyết phục được.
phrasal verbs.example: I can talk her round.

phrasal verbs.meaning: try using something such as a machine or product to find out whether it works correctly or is satisfactory: thử nghiệm.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m taking my new model aeroplane to the park to test it out.

phrasal verbs.meaning: consider a problem or decision carefully: cân nhắc kỹ.
phrasal verbs.example: Let’s think over his proposal before we see him again.

phrasal verbs.meaning: consider the facts about something in an organised and thorough way: xem xét.
phrasal verbs.example: Have you thought things through?

phrasal verbs.meaning: invent or imagine something, especially an excuse: bịa ra.
phrasal verbs.example: She’d have to think up a good reason for being late.

phrasal verbs.meaning: force someone to leave a place or group: đuổi, tống cổ.
phrasal verbs.example: Charlie was thrown out of the Scouts.

phrasal verbs.meaning: get rid of something that you no longer want, for example by putting it in a dustbin: vứt bỏ.
phrasal verbs.example: We’re throwing these things out.

phrasal verbs.meaning: cause something such as dust or water to rise into the air: làm bắn tung lên.
phrasal verbs.example: As the helicopter landed, it threw up a lot of dust.

phrasal verbs.meaning: produce something new or unexpected: tạo ra bất ngờ.
phrasal verbs.example: The new rules have thrown up a few problems.

phrasal verbs.meaning: help someone to get to the end of a difficult period of time, especially by giving them enough money: giúp vượt qua khó khăn.
phrasal verbs.example: Ed lent me £50 to tide me over until payday.

phrasal verbs.meaning: (of an object) have one end move upwards, especially because something heavy has been put at the other end: nghiêng.
phrasal verbs.example: The bench began to tip up and he sat on it.

phrasal verbs.meaning: turn a container upside down so that the things inside it come out: lật úp.
phrasal verbs.example: He picked the box up and emptied everything onto the table.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make a surface look better with small improvements: trau chuốt, sửa sang.
phrasal verbs.example: Touch up the paintwork before you try to sell the house.

phrasal verbs.meaning: test something to see how it works: dùng thử.
phrasal verbs.example: We’re trying out the new system.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change or develop into something different: chuyển thành.
phrasal verbs.example: The sofa turns into a bed, so you can stay with us, if you like.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change or develop into something different: biến thành.
phrasal verbs.example: They’ve turned the old factory into luxury flats.

phrasal verbs.meaning: use all of a supply of something: dùng hết, dùng cạn sạch.
phrasal verbs.example: Did you use the butter up when you were making cakes?

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave a meeting, performance, etc. before the end, usually because you are angry or bored: rời đi (vì giận).
phrasal verbs.example: I walked out halfway through the film.

phrasal verbs.meaning: suddenly leave a relationship, your family, your job, etc: dứt ngọt bỏ đi, rời khỏi.
phrasal verbs.example: You can’t just walk out like this!

phrasal verbs.meaning: do something to prevent someone or something from harming you: phòng ngừa.
phrasal verbs.example: Sheila carried a knife to ward off attacks.

phrasal verbs.meaning: prepare for a sport or activity by doing gentle exercises or practising just before it starts warm-up (n): khởi động.
phrasal verbs.example: It’s very important to warm up before you exercise.

phrasal verbs.meaning: gradually become thinner and weaker over a period of time, usually because of an illness: dần trở nên gầy gò.
phrasal verbs.example: He hadn’t eaten properly for weeks and was starting to waste away.

phrasal verbs.meaning: add water to a drink or liquid in order to make it less strong, dilute: pha loãng.
phrasal verbs.example: If it’s too strong, water it down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make something such as a statement or newspaper article less offensive, powerful or detailed: làm dịu.
phrasal verbs.example: The editor watered my article down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make someone gradually lose their energy or confidence: làm hao mòn.
phrasal verbs.example: This constant criticism at work is really wearing me down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make something gradually disappear or become thinner by using or rubbing it: hư mòn.
phrasal verbs.example: These shoes are uncomfortable because the heel has worn down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: use something a lot so that it no longer works, or can no longer be used: làm món cũ, hư hỏng.
phrasal verbs.example: On my walking holiday, I wore out three pairs of boots.

phrasal verbs.meaning: cause problems for someone or something or make someone worried: đè nén, gây lo âu.
phrasal verbs.example: The entire industry has been weighed down by economic uncertainty.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make someone heavy and unable to move easily: đè nặng lên.
phrasal verbs.example: The waiters were weighed down by huge trays of food.

phrasal verbs.meaning: spend time in a relaxed way when you have nothing else to do: giết thời gian.
phrasal verbs.example: We whiled away the Saturday afternoon sitting by the lake.

phrasal verbs.meaning: end or finish something gradually: dần tàn, dần chấm dứt.
phrasal verbs.example: The party started to wind down around 2 a.m.

phrasal verbs.meaning: gradually reduce work before stopping completely: dần đóng cửa.
phrasal verbs.example: The factory will wind down production before closing next year.

phrasal verbs.meaning: relax after a period of excitement or worry: thả giãn, xả hơi.
phrasal verbs.example: It’s hard to wind down after doing such a stressful job all day.

phrasal verbs.meaning: damage a vehicle so badly that it is not worth repairing: làm hỏng nặng.
phrasal verbs.example: My uncle wrote his car off in an accident last weekend.

phrasal verbs.meaning: decide that someone or something will not succeed and stop giving them your attention and energy: từ bỏ, xóa sổ.
phrasal verbs.example: He felt hopeless; his teachers had written him off.

phrasal verbs.meaning: punish someone very severely: trừng phạt ai đó thật nghiêm khắc.
phrasal verbs.example: They’ll really throw the book at him this time.

phrasal verbs.meaning: large sum/amount: khoản lớn.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve managed to put away a tidy sum this year.

phrasal verbs.meaning: used when you have said that you have had good luck in order to prevent bad luck from happening to you: phỉ phui, trộm vía.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ll find a new job before too long, touch wood.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change your life by starting to be a better person or stopping a bad habit: có một khởi đầu mới.
phrasal verbs.example: Ralph seems to have turned over a new leaf this term.

phrasal verbs.meaning: completely controlled by someone else: không thoát khỏi bàn tay của ai.
phrasal verbs.example: I became self-employed because I was sick of being under someone’s thumb.

phrasal verbs.meaning: angry and complaining about something: buồn bực, tức giận vì điều gì.
phrasal verbs.example: Everyone in the office is up in arms about having to work next weekend.

phrasal verbs.word: variety is the spice of life
phrasal verbs.meaning: used for saying that different experiences and situations make life enjoyable or interesting: sự đa dạng là gia vị cuộc sống.
phrasal verbs.example: I do a million different things at work, but I suppose variety is the spice of life.

phrasal verbs.meaning: your relative: họ hàng thân thuộc.
phrasal verbs.example: My family is very important to me because, after all, they’re my flesh and blood.

phrasal verbs.meaning: happening in a way that is sudden and unexpected: hoàn toàn bất ngờ.
phrasal verbs.example: Then, suddenly, out of the blue, she said she wanted a divorce.

phrasal verbs.meaning: extremely good or impressive: tuyệt vời, không thể nào tốt hơn được.
phrasal verbs.example: The food at that restaurant is out of this world!

phrasal verbs.meaning: more than what is considered normal or suitable: quá mức, vượt xa.
phrasal verbs.example: Don’t think spending 500 euros on a dress was a bit over the top?

phrasal verbs.meaning: the place that is most central or important: vị trí cao quý.
phrasal verbs.example: This stamp’s extremely rare, and takes pride of place in my stamp collection.

phrasal verbs.meaning: use your influence in order to get something you want or to help someone: nhờ vả mối quan hệ.
phrasal verbs.example: I don’t think it’s fair to pull strings in order to get a job.

phrasal verbs.meaning: provide a sensible way of judging how good, bad, important, etc., something is in comparison to other things: nhận xét, đánh giá đúng vị trí.
phrasal verbs.example: My illness has certainly put everything else in perspective.

phrasal verbs.meaning: guess what is happening or what something means based on what you have seen or heard: đoán trước sự việc.
phrasal verbs.example: He didn’t tell us he was retiring, but we could all put two and two together.

phrasal verbs.meaning: sit down and relax, especially with your feet raised off the ground: thư giãn.
phrasal verbs.example: Put your feet up and I’ll make dinner.

phrasal verbs.meaning: taking a very short/long time to understand or realise something: hiểu nhanh/chậm.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m sure Chad understood what you were suggesting; he’s very quick on the uptake.

phrasal verbs.meaning: rest after being very busy, so that you will be ready to start working again: sạc pin, nạp năng lượng.
phrasal verbs.example: Why don’t you take a week off work to recharge your batteries?

phrasal verbs.meaning: documents, rules, or processes that cause delays: thủ tục giấy tờ.
phrasal verbs.example: Is there a lot of red tape involved in getting a passport?

phrasal verbs.meaning: waste time and effort trying to do something that someone else has already done well: phí công tái tạo.
phrasal verbs.example: Just use the same document you used last time, because there’s no point reinventing the wheel.

phrasal verbs.meaning: something that rings a bell sounds familiar to you, although you cannot remember the exact details: nghe hơi quen.
phrasal verbs.example: The name rings a bell but I’m not sure if I’ve ever met her.

phrasal verbs.meaning: crazy: điên rồi.
phrasal verbs.example: That noise is driving me round the bend.

phrasal verbs.meaning: town or city that is close to and depends on a larger city: thành phố vệ tinh.
phrasal verbs.example: Brentwood is a satellite town just outside London.

phrasal verbs.meaning: used for saying someone has been weak in their behaviour, as everyone makes mistakes: ai đó cũng chỉ là người thôi.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m sorry I made a mistake, but I’m only human.

phrasal verbs.meaning: agree with someone or have the same opinion as them: đồng tình với ai.
phrasal verbs.example: Imogen and I have never really seen eye to eye.

phrasal verbs.meaning: decide that you want something very much: mong muốn điều gì đó xảy ra.
phrasal verbs.example: I had set my heart on getting married on the beach, but the bad weather meant we couldn’t.

phrasal verbs.word: sick of one (and) half a dozen of the other
phrasal verbs.meaning: used for saying that two things are equally good or bad: kẻ tám lạng, người nửa cân.
phrasal verbs.example: It’s six of one and half a dozen of the other, really.

phrasal verbs.meaning: provide a lot of information, especially in an indirect way: biểu lộ sự thật mà không cần nói ra.
phrasal verbs.example: What he said to Mandy speaks volumes about the way he treats his staff.

phrasal verbs.meaning: argue or worry about very small details or differences that are not important: cãi nhau vì những điều không quan trọng.
