phrasal verbs.example: Whether you call them ‘terrorists’ or ‘freedom fighters’ is just splitting hairs – the point is that they’re killing people!

phrasal verbs.meaning: receive a lot of attention because you give the best performance in a show or other event: chiếm sóng, đột phá.
phrasal verbs.example: There was one comedian who really stole the show. She was fantastic!

phrasal verbs.meaning: refuse to change what you are saying or doing despite the opposition or criticism of other people: giữ vững niềm tin.
phrasal verbs.example: I admire Kelly for the way she always sticks to her guns.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop moving or reacting suddenly, for example because you are surprised: dừng đột ngột.
phrasal verbs.example: When I heard the gunshot, I stopped dead in my tracks.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to follow a path that is quicker and shorter than the usual way: đi đường tắt.
phrasal verbs.example: I walked to school and I used to take a short cut along the canal.

phrasal verbs.meaning: spend time thinking about the situation you are in before you decide what to do next: dành nhiều thời gian để nghĩ bước tiếp theo.
phrasal verbs.example: Let’s take a couple of days to take stock of the situation and then we’ll make a decision.

phrasal verbs.word: take the law into your own hands
phrasal verbs.meaning: punish someone in your own way without involving the police or courts: tự thi hành luật rừng.
phrasal verbs.example: I know you’re angry, but that’s no reason to take the law into your own hands.

phrasal verbs.meaning: follow a longer path than usual because it is more attractive: đi đường vòng để ngắm cảnh.
phrasal verbs.example: We’re not lost – we’re just taking the scenic route.

phrasal verbs.meaning: tell someone in authority bad things that someone else has done: mách lẻo, đặt điều.
phrasal verbs.example: Toby, stop telling tales about your classmates.

phrasal verbs.meaning: an advantage that makes someone or something more successful than other people or things: lợi thế hơn so với ai.
phrasal verbs.example: Our product’s got the edge over the competition because it’s so lightweight.

phrasal verbs.meaning: used for saying people have limited control over what life brings them: hên xui.
phrasal verbs.example: I never wanted to become a butcher, but I guess that’s the luck of the draw.

phrasal verbs.meaning: recently: một hôm, gần đây.
phrasal verbs.example: There was an interesting item on the news the other day.

phrasal verbs.meaning: people who control a situation: người nắm quyền.
phrasal verbs.example: I don’t know if the powers that be will agree to that.

phrasal verbs.meaning: the skills and equipment you need in order to do your job: các công cụ, đồ nghề.
phrasal verbs.example: A good bedside manner is one of the tools of the trade for a doctor.

phrasal verbs.meaning: used for saying that you should accept other people’s beliefs and way of life: sống để mà dễ sống.
phrasal verbs.example: I don’t agree with what he’s doing, but live and let live, I say.

phrasal verbs.meaning: including everything: tất thảy.
phrasal verbs.example: They’ve sold all their possessions, lock, stock and barrel.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become confused about where you are: hoang mang, mất phương hướng.
phrasal verbs.example: I lost my bearings for a moment, but then realised where I was.

phrasal verbs.meaning: go towards someone or something in the quickest and most direct way: tiến thẳng về phía ai/cái gì.
phrasal verbs.example: As soon as we arrived at the hotel, Molly made a beeline for the manager to complain.

phrasal verbs.meaning: feel relaxed and behave in the same way as in your home: cư xử như ở nhà.
phrasal verbs.example: Charles will be down in a moment, so please make yourselves at home.

phrasal verbs.word: never/don’t look a gift horse in the mouth
phrasal verbs.meaning: if you are given something good, you should not complain about it: đừng xét nét quà tặng.
phrasal verbs.example: The flat wasn’t in very good condition, but we were staying there rent-free, and you should never look a gift horse in the mouth, should you?

phrasal verbs.meaning: for emphasising that there is no reason or explanation: chẳng ra sao, vô lý.
phrasal verbs.example: There seems to be no rhyme or reason for the decision.

phrasal verbs.word: not have a leg to stand on
phrasal verbs.meaning: not have any way of proving that you are right about something: không thể nào chứng minh mình đúng.
phrasal verbs.example: George tried to argue that the world was flat, but of course he didn’t have a leg to stand on.

phrasal verbs.word: not see the wood for the trees
phrasal verbs.meaning: used for saying that someone cannot understand what is important in a situation: chỉ thấy cây mà không thấy rừng.
phrasal verbs.example: Many people can’t see the wood for the trees when talking about joining the eurozone; they just think about what’s on the notes and coins and don’t think about the economic benefits.

phrasal verbs.meaning: away from populated areas or areas popular with tourists: nơi ít người biết đến.
phrasal verbs.example: We like to get off the beaten track when we go on holiday.

phrasal verbs.meaning: have a good relationship with someone: có mối quan hệ tốt với.
phrasal verbs.example: When I left the job, I was still on good terms with everyone in the office.

phrasal verbs.word: on the spur of the moment
phrasal verbs.meaning: do something suddenly without planning: nổi hứng làm gì.
phrasal verbs.example: We booked the holiday on the spur of the moment. We hadn’t been planning to take a break at all this summer.

phrasal verbs.meaning: with no place to live: vô gia cư.
phrasal verbs.example: Life is hard on the street.

phrasal verbs.meaning: spending the evening enjoying yourself in bars, clubs, theatres: đi chơi tận hưởng.
phrasal verbs.example: Did you go out on the town on your birthday?

phrasal verbs.meaning: very rarely: hiếm khi.
phrasal verbs.example: To be honest, I only go to museums once in a blue moon. I just don’t have time usually.

phrasal verbs.meaning: extremely happy: cực kỳ vui sướng.
phrasal verbs.example: She was over the moon about her results.

phrasal verbs.meaning: an essential part of something: phần không thể thiếu.
phrasal verbs.example: Working irregular hours is all part and parcel of being a journalist.

phrasal verbs.meaning: pass responsibility for a problem to someone else: đùn đẩy trách nhiệm.
phrasal verbs.example: The minister tried to pass the buck by blaming his civil servants for the mistake.

phrasal verbs.meaning: deal with a situation as it develops: tùy cơ ứng biến.
phrasal verbs.example: We can’t make a decision yet. Let’s just play it by ear.

phrasal verbs.meaning: get satisfaction from something that you do well: tự hào về điều gì.
phrasal verbs.example: Emily prides herself on her skills as a negotiator.

phrasal verbs.meaning: trick someone: lừa đảo.
phrasal verbs.example: You paid £200 for that? He really pulled a fast one on you!

phrasal verbs.word: put your cards on the table
phrasal verbs.meaning: tell people exactly what you are thinking or intending to do: thẳng thắn nói rõ.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m going to lay my cards on the table and offer you an extra £1,000. But that’s my final offer!

phrasal verbs.meaning: sit down and relax: nghỉ ngơi, thư giãn.
phrasal verbs.example: Put your feet up for half an hour – you look absolutely exhausted.

phrasal verbs.word: put your money where your mouth is
phrasal verbs.meaning: show by action that you support or believe something: thể hiện niềm tin bằng hành động.
phrasal verbs.example: If you’re really serious about quitting your job, it’s time to put your money where your mouth is and hand in your resignation.

phrasal verbs.word: put yourself in someone else’s shoes
phrasal verbs.meaning: imagine what it would be like to be in someone else’s situation: đặt mình vào vị trí người khác.
phrasal verbs.example: Try to put yourself in her shoes – how would you feel if your boss spoke to you like that?

phrasal verbs.meaning: find a hidden meaning in something that is not said openly: đọc giữa các dòng.
phrasal verbs.example: He didn’t seem too upset, but I suppose you have to read between the lines.

phrasal verbs.meaning: something that takes people’s attention away from what is important: đánh lạc hướng.
phrasal verbs.example: His remarks about the Prime Minister were just a red herring to distract attention from the main issue.

phrasal verbs.meaning: a very important or exciting day: ngày đáng nhớ.
phrasal verbs.example: It was a red-letter day when we moved into our new house.

phrasal verbs.meaning: waste time and effort doing something that has already been done well: phí công tái tạo.
phrasal verbs.example: Just use the same document you used last time, because there’s no point reinventing the wheel.

phrasal verbs.meaning: sound familiar to you: nghe quen quen.
phrasal verbs.example: The name rings a bell, but I’m not sure if I’ve ever met her.

phrasal verbs.meaning: because of a sudden feeling that you must do or say something: làm chuyện gì một cách ngẫu hứng.
phrasal verbs.example: Wendy decided on a whim to redecorate the whole house.

phrasal verbs.meaning: having a long period of difficulty finding work or earning money: gặp khó khăn.
phrasal verbs.example: The man was work and earning money, obviously down on his luck, so I gave him a little money.

phrasal verbs.meaning: say that you definitely will not allow or accept something: không đồng ý hoàn toàn.
phrasal verbs.example: I don’t mind you asking if you can borrow some money, but I draw the line at you taking it out of my purse without asking first.

phrasal verbs.meaning: suddenly become extremely angry without a good reason: nổi khùng.
phrasal verbs.example: Whatever she says, don’t fly off the handle. Stay calm!

phrasal verbs.meaning: full of enthusiasm
phrasal verbs.example: Last spring, a zealous political activist lived in a tree to ensure it wouldn't be cut down.

phrasal verbs.meaning: go straight forward, without turning: cứ đi thẳng đường rẽ.
phrasal verbs.example: Once you go past the traffic lights, just follow your nose.

phrasal verbs.meaning: highest point
phrasal verbs.example: The zenith of Bert's career was when he sang on stage at the Grand Old Opry.

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave a job so that sb can take over (về hưu)
phrasal verbs.example: The chairman stepped aside to allow a younger person to take over

phrasal verbs.meaning: for now: trong lúc này.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m staying in rented accommodation for the time being, but hope to buy a place early next year.

phrasal verbs.meaning: improve the appearance of st, e.g. by cleaning up or painting (cải thiiện bề ngoài, cải tạo)
phrasal verbs.example: This room needs smartening up.

phrasal verbs.meaning: sometimes, but not often: đôi khi.
phrasal verbs.example: We see Brian from time to time, but not regularly.

phrasal verbs.meaning: take control or advantage over a person or situation: đoạt quyền kiểm soát hoặc lợi ích hơn.
phrasal verbs.example: It looked like Ivor was going to win the game, but I soon got the upper hand.

phrasal verbs.word: get on like a house on fire
phrasal verbs.meaning: become good friends very quickly and have a lot to talk to each other about: có quan hệ hòa thuận.
phrasal verbs.example: George and Isabelle seem to be getting on like a house on fire, don’t they?

phrasal verbs.meaning: talk to someone about something that has been worrying you: giãi bày tâm sự.
phrasal verbs.example: It feels such a relief to have got this off my chest.

phrasal verbs.word: get the wrong end of the stick
phrasal verbs.meaning: understand something completely wrongly: hiểu lầm.
phrasal verbs.example: Don said he was going to France and I got the wrong end of the stick and thought he was moving there forever.

phrasal verbs.meaning: understand the basic meaning: nắm được ý chính.
phrasal verbs.example: Doreen and I have been having some problems recently, if you catch my drift.

phrasal verbs.word: give sb a taste/dose of their own medicine
phrasal verbs.meaning: treat someone in the same way that they treat other people: trả đũa.
phrasal verbs.example: He got me into trouble, so I’m going to give him a taste of his own medicine!

phrasal verbs.meaning: promise to do something: hứa hẹn với ai.
phrasal verbs.example: I give you my word I won’t tell anyone.

phrasal verbs.meaning: decide not to do something that you usually do: không làm việc gì.
phrasal verbs.example: I think I’ll give the office party a miss this year.

phrasal verbs.meaning: share the cost of something equally: mỗi người trả phần mình.
phrasal verbs.example: Let’s go halves on the meal, shall we?

phrasal verbs.meaning: if success goes to your head, it makes you think that you are better or more important than you really are: kiêu căng, ngạo mạn.
phrasal verbs.example: I hope getting that scholarship doesn’t go to Carol’s head.

phrasal verbs.meaning: accept a difficult situation without complaining or showing how you feel: ngậm bồ hòn làm ngọt.
phrasal verbs.example: Alan just has to grin and bear it because he needs a bad review.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change your opinion about something or decide not to do something you were planning to do: đổi ý.
phrasal verbs.example: Y. Williams had a change of heart and decided not to go to university after all.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be good at growing plants: có tài trồng cây.
phrasal verbs.example: My wife’s always had green fingers, whereas I don’t know anything about growing plants.

phrasal verbs.meaning: have more time available than you need: dư thời gian.
phrasal verbs.example: Julie has a lot more time on her hands now that her children have all left home.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be able to think quickly and make sensible decisions: thông thái.
phrasal verbs.example: You’ve got to have your wits about you when dealing with pushy salespeople.

phrasal verbs.meaning: the way in which information spreads quickly: nghe từ nguồn tin không chính thức.
phrasal verbs.example: I heard through the grapevine you might be getting married soon.

phrasal verbs.word: be born with a silver spoon in your mouth
phrasal verbs.meaning: have advantages because you come from a rich family: sinh ra đã ngậm thìa vàng, sinh ra ở vạch đích.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve always had to work hard because I wasn’t born with a silver spoon in my mouth.

phrasal verbs.meaning: understand the way another thinks because you often have the same ideas and opinions: cùng tần số, cùng quan điểm.
phrasal verbs.example: It was a difficult meeting because David and I didn’t seem to be on the same wavelength.

phrasal verbs.meaning: something that makes a place look less attractive, for example, an ugly building: phá hủy phong cảnh.
phrasal verbs.example: Many people in the town think that the old factory is a blot on the landscape.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if a person or business breaks even, they neither make a profit nor lose money: hòa vốn.
phrasal verbs.example: We didn’t make a profit last year, but we did break even.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change a situation by doing something that is very different from what most people usually do or have done in the past: phá cách.
phrasal verbs.example: I thought her last movie really broke the mould.

phrasal verbs.word: bury your head in the sand
phrasal verbs.meaning: ignore a problem or an unpleasant situation and hope that it will disappear: làm đà điểu, trốn tránh sự thật.
phrasal verbs.example: We shouldn’t just bury our heads in the sand and hope that this problem goes away.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change your opinion or attitude: đổi ý.
phrasal verbs.example: Tom often criticised Nadia until he met her, but now he’s changed his tune.

phrasal verbs.meaning: completely honest or legal: trong sạch.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m not worried about the tax inspection. This company’s accounts are clean as a whistle.

phrasal verbs.meaning: extremely clean: sạch bong.
phrasal verbs.example: My mum’s coming to visit tomorrow so I want the house to be as clean as a whistle when she gets here.

phrasal verbs.meaning: tell the truth about something that you have kept secret: nói sự thật.
phrasal verbs.example: You’d better come clean and tell Mum it was you who broke the flowerpot.

phrasal verbs.meaning: used for saying that something always happens or someone always does something despite bad weather or difficult conditions: dù thế nào đi chăng nữa.
phrasal verbs.example: I’m determined to finish building the house by the end of the month, come rain or shine.

phrasal verbs.meaning: area surrounding a large city where many people who work in that city live: khu vực vành đai thành phố.
phrasal verbs.example: Towns in the commuter belt often seem to lack character.

phrasal verbs.meaning: unpleasant part of a city where there are a lot of ugly buildings close together: rừng bê tông, khu vực nhà cửa san sát.
phrasal verbs.example: Where we used to live was a bit of a concrete jungle.

phrasal verbs.meaning: someone who spends a lot of time sitting at home watching television: người hay xem tivi và lười vận động.
phrasal verbs.example: I’ve become a bit of a couch potato since I stopped playing football.

phrasal verbs.meaning: waste time feeling upset about something bad that has happened and cannot be changed: tiếc rẻ con gà quạ tha.
phrasal verbs.example: I know your CD player’s broken, but there’s no point crying over spilt milk, is there?

phrasal verbs.meaning: build a structure or put it in a particular place: xây dựng.
phrasal verbs.example: They set up the tent near the lake.

phrasal verbs.meaning: prevent someone from being heard by shouting: la ó, hét lớn.
phrasal verbs.example: The protesters shouted down the politician during his speech.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become weaker or smaller in amount: giảm sút.
phrasal verbs.example: The flowers shriveled up in the heat.

phrasal verbs.meaning: choose one person from a group for special attention: chọn ra.
phrasal verbs.example: She was singled out for her outstanding performance.

phrasal verbs.meaning: think carefully and form an opinion about a person or situation: đánh giá.
phrasal verbs.example: He sized up the situation before making a decision.

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave secretly: lẻn đi.
phrasal verbs.example: He slipped away before the meeting ended.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make a careless mistake: sơ suất.
phrasal verbs.example: I slipped up and sent the wrong email.

phrasal verbs.meaning: to make yourself look tidy and clean: làm đẹp lên.
phrasal verbs.example: You should smarten up before your job interview.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be so busy you cannot deal with it: ngập trong việc.
phrasal verbs.example: I'm completely snowed under with work right now.

phrasal verbs.meaning: find out someone’s opinions or feelings: dò hỏi ý kiến.
phrasal verbs.example: I need to sound out their opinions before we proceed.

phrasal verbs.meaning: state your opinion firmly: lên tiếng, nói rõ.
phrasal verbs.example: She spoke out against the unfair treatment.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if people in a group spread out, they move away from one another: tản ra.
phrasal verbs.example: The campers spread out their sleeping bags in the field.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be produced suddenly and quickly: đột ngột xuất hiện.
phrasal verbs.example: New cafes have sprung up all over the city.

phrasal verbs.meaning: be easy to see or notice because of being different: nổi bật.
phrasal verbs.example: Her bright clothes made her stand out in the crowd.

phrasal verbs.meaning: not allow yourself to be treated badly: đứng lên chống lại.
phrasal verbs.example: He stood up to his boss and refused to work overtime.

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave a job so that sb else can take over: từ chức.
phrasal verbs.example: The chairman stepped aside to let the younger manager take over.

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave a position of power: từ bỏ chức vụ.
phrasal verbs.example: She decided to step down after ten years as CEO.

phrasal verbs.meaning: increase intensity or effort: tăng cường.
phrasal verbs.example: We need to step up our efforts to finish this project.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stick out or extend outward: nhô ra.
phrasal verbs.example: The tree branch stuck out over the road.

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave angrily or suddenly: bỏ đi.
phrasal verbs.example: He stormed out of the meeting in frustration.

phrasal verbs.meaning: summarize or present key points: tóm tắt.
phrasal verbs.example: He summed up the discussion in a few sentences.

phrasal verbs.meaning: stop paying attention: ngừng tập trung.
phrasal verbs.example: Please switch off the lights when you leave.

phrasal verbs.meaning: accompany someone uninvited: theo sau.
phrasal verbs.example: I decided to tag along with them to the park.

phrasal verbs.meaning: gradually decrease or fade: giảm dần.
phrasal verbs.example: Her voice tailed off as she forgot the lyrics.

phrasal verbs.meaning: speak in a condescending manner: nói giọng hạ thấp.
phrasal verbs.example: He talked down to us as if we were children.

phrasal verbs.meaning: persuade someone to do something: thuyết phục ai làm gì.
phrasal verbs.example: They talked me into joining their team.

phrasal verbs.meaning: dissuade someone from doing something: thuyết phục ai không làm gì.
phrasal verbs.example: I talked her out of making a rash decision.

phrasal verbs.meaning: demolish or destroy: phá hủy.
phrasal verbs.example: The building was torn down to make way for new apartments.

phrasal verbs.meaning: consider something carefully: cân nhắc kỹ.
phrasal verbs.example: I'll think over your proposal and give you an answer tomorrow.

phrasal verbs.meaning: discard or get rid of something: vứt bỏ.
phrasal verbs.example: Don't throw away that old vase; it's an antique.

phrasal verbs.meaning: eject or remove forcibly: đuổi ra.
phrasal verbs.example: They threw out the old furniture to make space.

phrasal verbs.meaning: reprimand or scold: trách mắng.
phrasal verbs.example: She ticked off the items on the checklist.

phrasal verbs.meaning: inform secretly or warn: báo tin.
phrasal verbs.example: The police were tipped off about the robbery.

phrasal verbs.meaning: finish or complete something: hoàn thành.
phrasal verbs.example: We topped off the meal with a delicious dessert.

phrasal verbs.meaning: adjust or tune a device: điều chỉnh.
phrasal verbs.example: You can tune in to the news at 8 PM.

phrasal verbs.meaning: refuse entry: từ chối vào.
phrasal verbs.example: They turned away visitors who didn't have tickets.

phrasal verbs.meaning: result in or prove to be: hóa ra là.
phrasal verbs.example: The event turned out to be a huge success.

phrasal verbs.meaning: consume completely: sử dụng hết.
phrasal verbs.example: We've used up all the milk.

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave suddenly or unexpectedly: rời đi bất ngờ.
phrasal verbs.example: The workers walked out in protest of the new policies.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become very tired: mệt mỏi rã rời.
phrasal verbs.example: These shoes have completely worn out after years of use.

phrasal verbs.meaning: spend time doing things in a relaxed way: thư giãn.
phrasal verbs.example: There's nothing I like better than messing about in the garden.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make a mistake or do something badly: gây lỗi, làm sai.
phrasal verbs.example: She says she completely messed up the interview.

phrasal verbs.meaning: put things together without any order: trộn lẫn.
phrasal verbs.example: If you put different colors into different glasses and mixed them up, could you tell which was which?

phrasal verbs.meaning: get much larger: tăng vọt.
phrasal verbs.example: The costs are beginning to mount up.

phrasal verbs.meaning: start living in a different house or flat (with): chuyển tới (nơi ở mới).
phrasal verbs.example: When he got divorced, John moved in with me.

phrasal verbs.meaning: leave one place and travel to another: rời đi.
phrasal verbs.example: My job means that I tend to stay in one city for a year or two and then move on.

phrasal verbs.meaning: permanently leave the house or flat where you live: rời khỏi (nơi ở cũ).
phrasal verbs.example: I hear you've finally moved out of your parents' place.

phrasal verbs.meaning: change your position in order to make space for someone or something: dịch sang.
phrasal verbs.example: The woman moved over so that I could sit on the bench.

phrasal verbs.meaning: think carefully about something over a period of time: nghiền ngẫm.
phrasal verbs.example: They'll need time to mull over the proposals.

phrasal verbs.meaning: make it easier to travel or do business in a country: mở cửa.
phrasal verbs.example: You'd be amazed at how much China has opened up since you were there.

phrasal verbs.meaning: decide not to take part in something or stop taking part in it: chọn không tham gia.
phrasal verbs.example: Quite a few of the students have opted out of the school trip.

phrasal verbs.meaning: hide a problem or disagreement rather than finding a satisfactory solution to it: che giấu.
phrasal verbs.example: Fundamental problems were papered over, not resolved.

phrasal verbs.meaning: die (used to avoid saying 'die'): qua đời.
phrasal verbs.example: He passed away in his sleep at the age of 84.

phrasal verbs.meaning: become friends with someone again after a disagreement: hàn gắn.
phrasal verbs.example: The meeting was intended to patch up relations between the two sides.

phrasal verbs.meaning: give someone the same amount of money you borrowed from them: hoàn trả.
phrasal verbs.example: I'll be able to pay you back next week.

phrasal verbs.meaning: spend or pay money, especially a lot of money: trả.
phrasal verbs.example: We've paid out thousands of pounds in health insurance over the years.

phrasal verbs.meaning: gradually stop using something: loại bỏ dần.
phrasal verbs.example: They're phasing out the old-style driving licence.

phrasal verbs.meaning: keep treating someone badly or unfairly: trêu chọc.
phrasal verbs.example: Why don't you pick on someone your own size?

phrasal verbs.meaning: go and meet someone or something: đón.
phrasal verbs.example: Detectives are still piecing together the circumstances surrounding the incident.

phrasal verbs.meaning: learn the truth about something by considering all separate bits of information: lắp ghép thông tin.
phrasal verbs.example: The printer's playing up again.

phrasal verbs.meaning: if something piles up or someone piles it up, the amount of it increases a lot: chất đống.
phrasal verbs.example: The US has been propping up the government in that country for years.

phrasal verbs.meaning: cause difficulties or pain for someone: gây khó chịu.
phrasal verbs.example: Could you just pull over for a second?

phrasal verbs.meaning: continue doing something in a determined way: quyết tâm tiến hành.
phrasal verbs.example: Don't worry, your dad's going to pull through.

idioms.meaning: remain serious and not laugh (giữ vẻ mặt nghiêm túc)
idioms.example: I couldn't keep a straight face when I saw Mike’s new haircut.

idioms.meaning: regularly give someone information about something they are interested in (thường xuyên cập nhật thông tin)
idioms.example: Do please keep me posted about any developments.

idioms.meaning: keep something secret (giữ bí mật)
idioms.example: Keep it under your hat, but we’re thinking of buying a new house.

idioms.meaning: try to be as rich, successful, etc. as your neighbours (đu đòi)
idioms.example: I don’t need a new car, and I’m really not interested in keeping up with the Joneses.

idioms.meaning: used for telling someone not to get angry or upset (bình tĩnh nào)
idioms.example: Keep your hair on! There’s no need to get annoyed.

idioms.meaning: be very annoyed because you made a mistake or missed an opportunity (dằn vặt bản thân)
idioms.example: I could have kicked myself when I realised I’d left my wallet in the restaurant.

idioms.meaning: very small, because you were very young (lúc còn nhỏ xíu)
idioms.example: When I was knee-high to a grasshopper, I used to believe that a monster lived under my bed.

idioms.meaning: be very familiar with; know everything about (biết tường tận)
idioms.example: Maria’s been in the business for years and she knows advertising inside out.

idioms.meaning: know the important facts about a situation (hiểu rõ cái gì ra cái gì)
idioms.example: Ask Tony about the proposed changes. He knows what’s what.

idioms.meaning: the newest and best type of something (kiểu mới nhất, thành tựu mới nhất)
idioms.example: The ZD-2000 is the last word in mobile phones.

idioms.word: lay/put your cards on the table
idioms.meaning: tell people exactly what you are thinking or what you intend to do (thẳng thắn nói hết ra)
idioms.example: I’m going to lay my cards on the table and offer you an extra £1,000. But that’s my final offer!

idioms.meaning: allow something to develop without trying to influence it (hãy cứ để tự nhiên đi)
idioms.example: I’m sure sales will improve if we just let nature take its course.

idioms.meaning: shout or do something that allows you to get rid of anger (xả hơi, xả giận)
idioms.example: I was so annoyed I had to go for a long walk to let off steam.

idioms.meaning: leave a person or situation alone if it might cause you trouble (chuyện đã qua hãy để cho qua đi)
idioms.example: I know you think your parents are being unfair, but it’s probably best to let sleeping dogs lie and not make it worse by arguing.

idioms.meaning: relax and enjoy yourself in a comfortable environment (xõa đi)
idioms.example: It’s good to let your hair down after a hard week at work.

idioms.word: life and soul of the party
idioms.meaning: someone who is very lively at social events (linh hồn của bữa tiệc)
idioms.example: Harry’s so much fun and everyone says he’s the life and soul of the party.

idioms.word: like two peas in a pod
idioms.meaning: used for saying that two people look or think exactly the same (giống như hai giọt nước)
idioms.example: Irene and her sister are like two peas in a pod.

idioms.meaning: obtain money, especially dishonestly (vì tiền mà bất chấp, mờ mắt vì tiền)
idioms.example: He’d been lining his pockets for years before he was finally caught.

idioms.word: Your Guess is as Good as Mine
idioms.meaning: To have no idea about anything
idioms.example: Will this flight reach on time?” “Your guess is as good as mine.”

idioms.meaning: The person you’re talking about shows up at the exact time
idioms.example: I hope he doesn’t show up to the office today – oh, speak of the devil, here he comes.

idioms.meaning: No manners
idioms.example: The class showed not a spark of decency by refusing to stand up when their principal entered the classroom.

idioms.word: In the heat of the Moment
idioms.meaning: Overwhelmed by what is happening at the moment
idioms.example: I’m afraid I was very arrogant; I was caught up in the heat of the moment.

idioms.meaning: To hear rumours
idioms.example: I heard on the grapevine that my brother-in-law got the promotion, but I really don’t know much about it.”

idioms.meaning: A person who advocates an unpopular cause for the sake of an argument.
idioms.example: I don’t really believe all that – I was just playing devil’s advocate.

idioms.meaning: Under his control
idioms.example: I feel like I’m always under his thumb.

idioms.meaning: In short periods, not regularly
idioms.example: The project progressed in fits and starts, with periods of intense productivity followed by long periods of inactivity.

idioms.meaning: Unusual or strange; not typical. Khác thường, kỳ lạ.
idioms.example: He has some out-of-the-way ideas about how to run a business.

idioms.meaning: In a very difficult situation
idioms.example: Alex realized they were in a tight corner when the client demanded a lower price.

idioms.meaning: The anxiety in which you hope that nothing will upset your plans
idioms.example: I have a job interview tomorrow, so I’m keeping my fingers crossed that it goes well and I get the position.

idioms.meaning: Talent for speaking
idioms.example: With his natural charisma and the gift of the gab, he could effortlessly captivate any audience with his storytelling.

idioms.word: Cost an Arm and a Leg
idioms.meaning: Be very expensive
idioms.example: The vintage car restoration ended up costing me an arm and a leg, but it was worth it to see it gleaming again.

idioms.meaning: Suspect something foul
idioms.example: After seeing how eager he was to sell his car for such a low price, I began to smell a rat and suspected that there might be something wrong.

idioms.meaning: By fair or foul means
idioms.example: She was willing to do whatever it took—by hook or by crook—to meet the deadline.

idioms.meaning: Spread quickly
idioms.example: The news of the new product launch spread like wildfire through social media, garnering attention and excitement from users around the world.

idioms.meaning: Disturb the work
idioms.example: The sudden power outage threw the entire production process out of gear, causing delays and disruptions.

idioms.meaning: Die while in service
idioms.example: Even in his old age, he continued to teach and inspire his students until he eventually died in harness, doing what he loved most.

idioms.meaning: To be very busy
idioms.example: I can’t go out tonight, I’m absolutely snowed under with work and deadlines

idioms.meaning: To be dismissed from your job
idioms.example: After consistently showing up late for work, he eventually got the sack from his job

idioms.word: Don’t give up a day’s job
idioms.meaning: You are not very good at something or you could not do it professionally
idioms.example: I love painting, but I shouldn’t give up a day’s job just yet.

idioms.meaning: To make certain that the amount of money spent is not more than the amount of money received
idioms.example: The company was accused of balancing the books to inflate its profits and deceive investors.

idioms.meaning: A general financial figure
idioms.example: The project manager gave us a ballpark figure for the budget, estimating it to be around $50,000, but the actual costs could vary.

idioms.meaning: Newspapers which publish sensational and unscrupulous stories and exaggerate the news to attract readers.
idioms.example: Don’t believe everything you read in the yellow press. They often exaggerate stories for sensationalism

idioms.meaning: An event which relates a sensation for a time but is soon forgotten
idioms.example: The new gadget was a nine-day wonder, capturing everyone’s attention for a short time before they moved on to the next big thing.

idioms.word: One swallow does not make a summer
idioms.meaning: It is unreliable to base one’s conclusions on only a single test or incident
idioms.example: Just because John aced one test doesn’t mean he’ll excel in the whole course. Remember, one swallow does not make a summer.

idioms.meaning: To exert all efforts
idioms.example: Sarah was determined to move heaven and earth to ensure her project’s success.

idioms.word: A miss is as good as a mile
idioms.meaning: Comes nowhere near the target
idioms.example: She didn’t win the race, but her coach reminded her that in the end, a miss is as good as a mile.

idioms.meaning: The whole of everything
idioms.example: After years of negotiations, they finally decided to buy the company lock, stock, and barrel.

idioms.word: Make hay while the sun shines
idioms.meaning: Take advantage of all opportunities
idioms.example: You should go and make hay while the sun shines, as this could be your chance to secure a great job.

idioms.word: All that glitters are not gold
idioms.meaning: Things that appear attractive or valuable on the surface may not always be as good as they seem.
idioms.example: She realized that all that glitters is not gold and that a high-paying job isn’t always worth sacrificing her happiness and health.

idioms.word: To jump from a frying pan into fire
idioms.meaning: To come out of one trouble and get into a worse
idioms.example: He ended up jumping from the frying pan into the fire when he started his new job at a company.

idioms.meaning: Cheating
idioms.example: The police suspected foul play in the sudden disappearance of the valuable painting from the museum.

idioms.meaning: Anyone in an awkward
idioms.example: Sarah felt like a fish out of water at the fancy gala, surrounded by wealthy socialites and unfamiliar customs.

idioms.word: A burnt child dreads the fire
idioms.meaning: One who has had a previous unpleasant experience is always scared of situations where such experiences are likely to be repeated
idioms.example: After getting food poisoning from a street vendor, she never ate street food again; a burnt child dreads the fire.

idioms.word: To set the Thames on fire
idioms.meaning: To do something sensational or remarkable
idioms.example: It’s clear that he thinks he’s going to set the Thames on fire with his revolutionary ideas.

idioms.meaning: Useless possession which is extremely expensive to keep
idioms.example: He was getting a great deal when he bought that antique vase, but it turned out to be a real white elephant.

idioms.word: To throw dust in one’s eyes
idioms.meaning: To try to deceive someone or mislead someone
idioms.example: The company’s CEO tried to throw dust in everyone’s eyes by giving a carefully crafted speech.

idioms.meaning: Sooner or later, everyone has his share of good fortune
idioms.example: When he unexpectedly won the Employee of the Month award, he proved that every dog has his day.

idioms.word: Give a dog a bad name and hang him
idioms.meaning: Once a person loses his reputation
idioms.example: They’re just trying to give a dog a bad name and hang him, without any concrete evidence to support their claims.

idioms.meaning: Playing Cards
idioms.example: To the curious explorers, the place felt like the Devil’s playthings, where forgotten memories and eerie whispers seemed to linger in the air

idioms.meaning: Be off
idioms.example: After enduring his rude comments for far too long, Jane finally had enough and told him to go to the devil.

idioms.word: To step into dead man’s shoes
idioms.meaning: To come into an inheritance
idioms.example: Jane found herself having to step into the dead man’s shoes and lead the company through these challenging times.

idioms.meaning: Refers to a period of peace, tranquility, and happiness
idioms.example: She would often talk about the halcyon days she spent at her grandparent's farm.

idioms.meaning: A period of misfortune
idioms.example: Many families struggled to make ends meet and faced evil days as they navigated through job losses and financial instability.

idioms.meaning: Ready made
idioms.example: Sarah was cut and dried, as she had consistently outperformed her colleagues and had the most experience in the department.

idioms.word: Too many cooks spoil the broth
idioms.meaning: Where there are more workers than necessary leading to disappointment
idioms.example: Everyone had their own ideas for the project, but too many cooks spoil the broth, and the final result ended up being confusing and ineffective.

idioms.meaning: To learn by heart
idioms.example: I spent hours studying the poem so that I could learn it by heart and recite it perfectly during the poetry recitation competition.

idioms.word: To throw cold water upon anything
idioms.meaning: To discourage efforts
idioms.example: The manager threw cold water upon their ambitious ideas by pointing out the potential budget constraints.

idioms.meaning: A foolishly incredible story
idioms.example: His explanation for why he was late to the meeting was a foolishly incredible story about being abducted by aliens.

idioms.meaning: To be mean
idioms.example: As known for being close-fisted when it came to lending money to his friends.

idioms.meaning: To attempt something impossible
idioms.example: Trying to convince her strict parents to let her go on a solo backpacking trip was like trying to square the circle.

idioms.meaning: Refers to the fact that its time for action now
idioms.example: She did her best and the ball is now in your court.

idioms.meaning: To make a careful selection
idioms.example: She can’t just pick and choose which tasks she wants to do.

idioms.meaning: She is older than she says
idioms.example: Despite her age, she is no chicken when it comes to taking on challenging tasks and responsibilities.

idioms.meaning: To attract attention
idioms.example: Her vibrant red dress and confident demeanor were enough to catch anyone’s eye as she walked into the room.

idioms.meaning: Don’t fret and worry yourself to death
idioms.example: She couldn’t resist opening the mysterious package despite the warning label and care killed the cat.

idioms.word: To burn the candle at both ends
idioms.meaning: Expend energy in two directions at the same time
idioms.example: Seems like he’s been burning the candle at both ends, trying to balance his responsibilities.

idioms.meaning: no need to advertise something good
idioms.example: Handcrafted wines spread far and wide, proving that good wine needs no bush.

idioms.meaning: To die
idioms.example: He was truly prepared to kick the bucket on his feet rather than live on his knees.

idioms.word: If the cap fits, wear it
idioms.meaning: If the remarks refer to you, then accept the criticism
idioms.example: Well, if the cap fits, wear it. You’ve been known to misplace things too.

idioms.meaning: To do something without proper materials
idioms.example: Trying to complete this project with such limited resources feels like trying to make bricks without straw.

idioms.meaning: One’s means of livelihood
idioms.example: Graphic design may be my passion, but web development is my bread and butter.

idioms.meaning: Something completely unexpected that surprises you
idioms.example: Getting a job offer from that prestigious company was like a bolt from the blue.

idioms.meaning: First sight
idioms.example: At first blush, the proposal seems promising, but upon closer examination, its flaws become apparent.

idioms.meaning: A person who discourages enjoyment or enthusiasm
idioms.example: Sarah’s constant pessimism and negative comments about potential challenges threw a wet blanket on their celebration.

idioms.meaning: Deliberately
idioms.example: In cold blood, she betrayed her closest friend, revealing all of their secrets to the world without a hint of remorse.

idioms.meaning: To be defeated in battle
idioms.example: The ambitious project eventually bit the dust due to a lack of funding and support.

idioms.meaning: Act unfairly in a contest/situation
idioms.example: One candidate resorted to personal attacks and hit below the belt by bringing up his opponent’s family issues.

idioms.meaning: In private
idioms.example: Behind the scenes, the dedicated team of engineers worked tirelessly to ensure the flawless execution of the event.

idioms.meaning: To create feelings of resentment, hostility, or animosity
idioms.example: Spreading rumours about others eventually caused bad blood between her and the rest of the office.

idioms.meaning: To speak negatively about someone in their absence
idioms.example: Sarah often backbites her colleagues, spreading rumors about them when they are not around.

idioms.meaning: The idiom is used to indicate the entirety of someone’s belongings
idioms.example: They left nothing behind, departing with their bag and baggage.

idioms.meaning: Used to describe someone who lacks courage
idioms.example: He never takes any action to improve his situation; it’s clear that he has no backbone.

idioms.meaning: To continue an activity or process
idioms.example: The marketing team worked diligently to keep the ball rolling by organizing engaging events.

idioms.meaning: To prepare for battle or engage in a conflict
idioms.example: The labor union decided to take up arms against unfair working conditions.

idioms.word: The other side of the coin
idioms.meaning: looking at different aspects of a situation
idioms.example: Teams might elevate the sales rate but the other side of the coin is overburdening the employees.

idioms.meaning: Doing something that causes problems
idioms.example: We already have too much homework; let’s not rock the boat and get more!

idioms.meaning: A cash cow
idioms.example: A singer deemed a cash cow for the record label.

idioms.word: Plenty more fish in the sea (Idiom, noun)
idioms.meaning: A kind and comforting phrase meaning that there are other potential romantic partners in the world. Usually said to someone who has just broken up with a romantic partner.
idioms.example: People often say ‘plenty more fish in the sea’ when a relationship ends, but it isn’t always what the person wants to hear.

idioms.meaning: Informal phrase used by people who are single but would like to find a romantic partner, either for a long- or short-term relationship.
idioms.example: My friend told me that she was single and ready to mingle, so I set her up with my classmate.

idioms.word: It’s better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all (common expression)
idioms.meaning: Having a good relationship which ends for some reason is better than not having a relationship. Often used to console people who have broken up with their partner.
idioms.example: A good friend will remind you that it’s better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all.

idioms.meaning: The number of people, usually children, in a family, who have to be provided for in terms of earning money, buying food as well as other necessary items like clothes.
idioms.example: Large families with a lot of hungry mouths to feed often struggle to save money or make investments.

idioms.word: To loosen the purse strings (idiom, verb)
idioms.meaning: To spend more money than usual, to be less frugal than usual. Often related to making a large or luxurious purchase.
idioms.example: My dad was always very cautious with money, and would only loosen the purse strings once a year at Christmas.

idioms.meaning: Describes a change in behaviour - spending less money and living a less luxurious and expensive lifestyle than in the past.
idioms.example: When my grandpa was a young farmer, he would have to tighten his belt every time there was a bad harvest or money was short.

idioms.meaning: Something you buy suddenly without having had a plan to buy it.
idioms.example: One good way to save money is to plan all your spending and avoid impulse purchases.

idioms.meaning: The person in a household who earns money for the family.
idioms.example: In families with two breadwinners, domestic tasks are often divided more equally.

idioms.meaning: The idea or trend of people putting a lot of emphasis and importance on buying goods and spending money. Usually used as a negative.
idioms.example: The rise of mass consumerism is a direct threat to the environment.

idioms.meaning: Money (or another resource) used in a way that has a chance of showing a reward or return in the future.
idioms.example: Making smart investments means that you make your money work for you, instead of you working for money.

idioms.meaning: To make enough money to cover basic living costs like food and housing, but without much money for luxuries.
idioms.example: Many families with only a single breadwinner struggle to make ends meet.

idioms.word: To splash the cash (informal idiom, verb)
idioms.meaning: To spend a lot of money in a very carefree way.
idioms.example: The children of that billionaire are often seen out splashing the cash.

idioms.meaning: The story of the movie, what happens step by step
idioms.example: My main complaint about the movie is that it has several massive plot holes.

idioms.meaning: The music included in a movie. Includes both the background music and any songs the characters sing.
idioms.example: To be fair, the movie had a great soundtrack, but I couldn’t get past the extremely predictable plot.

idioms.meaning: A fictional person from a story or movie.
idioms.example: One of the things I liked about the movie was how real the characters seemed, particularly the minor characters.

idioms.meaning: The art of camerawork in a movie. Simply, does a movie look very impressive?
idioms.example: I generally judge movies based on the believability of the plot and the quality of the cinematography.

idioms.meaning: One period of time with continuous action in a movie, set in a specific place with specific characters.
idioms.example: That movie is absolutely full of chase scenes, fight scenes and other action sequences.

idioms.meaning: The collection of actors who appear in a movie.
idioms.example: The movie featured an amazing cast, but did very poorly at the box office.

idioms.meaning: The money a movie makes from selling tickets.
idioms.example: What depresses me about modern movies is that they have to be set in an existing universe to stand a chance of doing well at the box office.

idioms.meaning: When a movie is set in a world/situation that has been shown in previous movies/TV shows. Example- The Marvel Universe
idioms.example: One reason I liked the movie is that it is set in an existing universe, so we got to see how the new characters interact with other characters from previous movies.

idioms.meaning: To make a movie with something very new, in special effects, content of the story, or another area.
idioms.example: I know that the special effects were groundbreaking when the movie came out, but now they look a little dated.

idioms.meaning: To attract the most attention, often surprisingly.
idioms.example: The young girl who played the daughter completely stole the show – she was fantastic!

idioms.meaning: The words sung in a song.
idioms.example: I learned the lyrics of several English songs to help me improve my language ability.

idioms.meaning: The part of a song that is repeated. Usually, the highest emotional point and often the most memorable part of the song.
idioms.example: The whole crowd joined in the final chorus, and it was amazing to hear all those thousands of people singing together.

idioms.meaning: The musical notes that make a song.
idioms.example: That’s my favourite song because it has a beautiful melody and fantastic lyrics.

idioms.meaning: A negative word for someone who has very particular taste in something (for example, art or music), and believes their tastes are superior to other people. Also means someone from a higher social class who looks down on people from lower social classes.
idioms.example: People tell me that quite often I come across as a snob, but really I just have very specific taste in music.

idioms.meaning: The type of music or genre of music that a person likes.
idioms.example: One thing that I have in common with my parents is that we have a similar taste in music.

idioms.meaning: To have a calm and gentle effect.
idioms.example: The thing I like about classical music is that I find it very soothing.

idioms.meaning: Popular, well-known, and not artistically challenging or different. For example- music or movies.
idioms.example: My brother only cares about mainstream music, but my taste in music is a lot more unconventional.

idioms.meaning: To not be singing (or playing an instrument) at the right pitch or tone.
idioms.example: I love singing but my friends always tell me that I sing horribly out of tune!

idioms.meaning: When a musician or musical band/group travels to different places to play concerts.
idioms.example: I plan to see my favourite band live next time they go on tour.

idioms.meaning: The group of people who support something or often do something. For example, the people who like a particular band or genre of music.
idioms.example: While American country music isn’t exactly part of the mainstream in my country, it does have a small but dedicated following here.

idioms.meaning: To have a good relationship with or feel a connection to nature.
idioms.example: My friend loves sitting underneath trees – he says it makes him feel at one with nature.

idioms.meaning: A place that is empty of life, in a negative or unhappy way. For example, a desert, or abandoned house.
idioms.example: After the landslide, the whole area looked desolate, with hardly anything left standing.

idioms.meaning: Something in new and perfect condition. For example, the ground immediately after snow has fallen, but before anyone has stepped on it.
idioms.example: It’s very unusual to find pristine wilderness in the modern world.

idioms.meaning: An area of completely wild nature, with no humans living there. Examples include parts of the Amazon rainforest, Alaska and Siberia. Usually describes somewhere that would be difficult for humans to live.
idioms.example: One of the great challenges left to humans is exploring the wilderness of space.

idioms.meaning: When a plant produces flowers and/or fruits.
idioms.example: Something my parents always loved to do was to take me to the countryside in early spring when the plants were beginning to blossom.

idioms.meaning: A type of flat, dry, grassy land in tropical areas that doesn’t have many trees. Most famous in Africa as the home of the big mammals (lions, elephants, zebras etc).
idioms.example: The African savannas have to be protected from poachers, as they are the home of many endangered species.

idioms.meaning: The type of tree or other plant that loses its leaves in autumn and grow them again in spring.
idioms.example: One of the great joys of seasons is watching deciduous trees shed their leaves in autumn and grow fresh ones in spring.

idioms.meaning: The culture of protecting and preserving nature. For example, protecting endangered animals or fighting against deforestation.
idioms.example: Governments around the world need to make a commitment to conservation before we lose any more of the natural world.

idioms.meaning: To be able to live side by side without one group damaging the other. Usually used for groups that find it hard to do this because of their different interests.
idioms.example: One of the challenges of the 21st century for humans is re-learning how to coexist peacefully alongside animals.

idioms.meaning: Someone who has a strong natural ability to grow plants.
idioms.example: My mum has a really green thumb, but she’s never been able to teach me how she manages to grow all those delicious vegetables.

idioms.meaning: A news story that is focused on an individual person (usually a normal person, not a celebrity).
idioms.example: I prefer to read news from websites that feature a lot of human interest stories.

idioms.meaning: A type of newspaper, traditionally of a smaller physical size, that focuses more on sensationalist news and less on quality reporting. Often uses simplistic language and concepts.
idioms.example: People who only read tabloid newspapers are less likely to understand the nuances of current affairs.

idioms.meaning: The attention given to a story by a newspaper or other media outlet.
idioms.example: Natural disasters like floods and hurricanes always receive widespread media coverage.

idioms.meaning: A story that reveals private information to the public. Usually about a public figure who has done something wrong or illegal.
idioms.example: We often read shocking exposés in newspapers about the illegal or morally reprehensible actions of major corporations.

idioms.meaning: Neutral, without any bias or prejudice. Used to describe media sources that can be more easily trusted.
idioms.example: It’s important for news sources to remain at least fairly impartial, as they have a responsibility to provide objective and non partisan information to their audience.

idioms.meaning: The owner of a newspaper, media source, or other business.
idioms.example: The identity of a newspaper’s proprietor can have a big influence on it’s political leaning and editorial focus.

idioms.meaning: To follow developments in something (e.g. a current news story) and avoid missing important new details or information.
idioms.example: A major advantage of reading news online is that people are able to keep up to speed with all the major developments in a breaking news story, instead of having to wait until the evening to hear about them.

idioms.meaning: Negative stories or information.
idioms.example: I don’t tend to read newspapers because they are always full of doom and gloom.

idioms.meaning: The title of a story in the news. Also used as a summary of the main news stories of the day.
idioms.example: More and more online news sources are using misleading headlines as click bait to attract readers.

idioms.meaning: A type of online advertising, often featuring a sensationalist news headline, that encourages people to click on it.
idioms.example: It can sometimes be hard to tell the difference between legitimate news and clickbait.

idioms.meaning: Someone who loses their temper and gets angry very quickly and easily.
idioms.example: Someone who has a short fuse would not make a great neighbour, in my opinion.

idioms.meaning: Someone who behaves differently or says different things depending on who they are with. Used as a negative.
idioms.example: It’s very hard to trust someone who has been two-faced in the past.

idioms.word: Bend over backwards to help (idiom, verb)
idioms.meaning: To always be willing to help people, even if it is difficult or costly to do so.
idioms.example: A good friend is someone willing to bend over backwards to help you in your time of need.

idioms.meaning: Someone willing to laugh at or make fun of themselves.
idioms.example: I tend to get on better with people who have a self deprecating sense of humour and are not too pretentious.

idioms.meaning: Someone, usually older, who has a particular way of acting or behaving, and is not willing to change it.
idioms.example: Older generations are usually more set in their ways, and as such, find it harder to adapt to societal changes.

idioms.word: Comfortable in one’s own skin (idiom, adjective)
idioms.meaning: Someone who has confidence in themselves as a person. Used as a positive.
idioms.example: I only really became comfortable in my own skin when I started my first job.

idioms.meaning: To often forget things or find it hard to pay attention to things happening around you. Usually negative
idioms.example: My father tends to be a bit absent-minded, but luckily my mother is always on the ball.

idioms.meaning: To be focused, ready to act and very competent. A positive adjective.
idioms.example: People who are always on the ball often make the best employees. 154155

idioms.meaning: Someone who enjoys meeting and talking to others, including acquaintances and strangers.
idioms.example: I’d like to be more of a people person, but I always get tongue-tied when talking to strangers.

idioms.meaning: A common theoretical discussion in psychology about whether someone is born with their personality and other traits (nature) or whether those traits are developed through their childhood by their parents, teachers and others (nurture). Used fairly commonly in daily English.
idioms.example: Whether personality is fixed at birth really comes down to the question of nature versus nurture.

idioms.meaning: The act or situation of being with someone else as a friend. Used as a positive word.
idioms.example: One of the big appeals of having a pet is the companionship that they can provide, particularly for elderly people.

idioms.meaning: A pet or other animal that has been bred by humans with others of the same breed to create a specific breed of animal. Note – sometimes written as pure-bred.
idioms.example: Some people question the morality of buying a purebred pet, as they are more likely to suffer from a myriad of health issues.

idioms.meaning: Willing to show love or affection to someone. For example, a dog towards its owner.
idioms.example: People who prefer dogs to cats often mention how affectionate dogs are with their owners.

idioms.meaning: To be demanding of the love and attention of someone, and jealous of sharing that person with others.
idioms.example: The downside of having an affectionate dog is that they can get overly possessive towards their owners, which results in misbehaviour in the presence of other people or other dogs.

idioms.meaning: A type of love given regardless of any bad things that happen. For example, a parent towards their child, or a dog towards its owner.
idioms.example: Pets are a reliable source of unconditional love in a world where that resource is in short supply.

idioms.meaning: When an animal loses hair from its coat.
idioms.example: My parents never let us have a cat because they were worried about it shedding all over the furniture.

idioms.meaning: Someone who prefers one type of pet over the others. Can also include other types of pets e.g. snakes, rabbits, hamsters.
idioms.example: My parents are both cat people, but I’m 100% a dog person.

idioms.meaning: To look after and maintain the physical well-being and appearance of an animal, for example by brushing its coat and cleaning its teeth.
idioms.example: Wild animals like monkeys tend to groom each other, but domesticated animals like dogs and cats require regular grooming.

idioms.meaning: A specific type of domesticated animal. Example – A Husky (breed of dog)
idioms.example: As dog ownership becomes more popular, people see owning a rare breed of dog as a kind of status symbol.

idioms.meaning: Spend a lot of money on a particular item
idioms.example: I don’t often go shopping, because when I do go, I always get the urge to splurge!

idioms.meaning: To be depressed or sad, and make oneself feel better by going shopping.
idioms.example: My sister often engages in a spot of retail therapy when she is feeling down.

idioms.meaning: To look through products in a shop one by one, but in a relaxed way. Not looking for a specific item.
idioms.example: I know a lot of people like to go into shops and peruse the items, but that’s not really my cup of tea.

idioms.meaning: Someone who loves to shop / is addicted to shopping.
idioms.example: I’m an absolute shopaholic – I just can’t stop myself!

idioms.meaning: To search for the same or similar products in different places, usually looking for a lower price or better deal.
idioms.example: Before deciding what to buy, I always take time to shop around, and usually end up saving a bit of money!

idioms.meaning: To have a product, usually one bought online, delivered to someone’s house the same day as it was purchased.
idioms.example: One of the big developments in online shopping has been the rise in companies offering same-day delivery.

idioms.meaning: To have a very large amount of choice, in a good way.
idioms.example: The good thing about shopping online is that you are spoiled for choice when choosing your products.

idioms.meaning: A shop (usually fairly small) that only exists in 1-2 places, and isn’t part of a large chain of shops/a larger company.
idioms.example: I love exploring independent stores when I go on holiday, but I must admit that I often end up buying everything cheaper in big department stores.

idioms.meaning: To have little money to spend on something.
idioms.example: When I find myself on a tight budget, I usually shop around for bargains.

idioms.meaning: The member of staff who helps customers in a shop.
idioms.example: I know that they are just doing their job, but I find it very annoying to be harassed by sales assistants when I walk into a shop.

idioms.meaning: People who send insulting or offensive messages on social media.
idioms.example: One of the problems of social media is that it is full of trolls, who take pleasure in insulting others and causing trouble.

idioms.meaning: An action or message that is insulting, disrespectful or offensive.
idioms.example: Internet trolls will often leave derogatory comments underneath a video to try to insult other viewers.

idioms.meaning: Someone who has a large following on social media.
idioms.example: The increasing popularity of social media means that being an influencer is now a legitimate career choice for some people.

idioms.meaning: A scene or situation that would look good in a video/photo and shared on social media. Example – an attractive meal in a restaurant.
idioms.example: A piece of advice that marketers often give their new clients is that their products have to be instagrammable to have a chance of success.

idioms.meaning: The main page on a social media website/app. Updated constantly and usually filled with suggested content e.g. videos or articles. Also written as newsfeed.
idioms.example: One of the dangers of social media is getting lost in the different content that appears on the newsfeed and finding that an hour or more has passed.

idioms.meaning: To find a way to make money from something – for example, a popular social media channel.
idioms.example: Many people dream of monetizing their hobby, but it takes a lot of dedication and isn’t always possible.

idioms.meaning: A picture, gif or piece of text that is used in a funny way and passed quickly around the internet.
idioms.example: One meme that was popular recently featured pictures comparing a person’s situation in 2020 and 2021.

idioms.meaning: Short for video blog/log. A video of someone talking to the camera about a specific topic. Topics can include recent news, daily activities, a review of a product or others.
idioms.example: People who vlog regularly are often able to quickly grow their channel.

idioms.meaning: A piece of software or app function that changes the physical appearance of the person on camera. For example, by making their skin clearer and their eyes bigger.
idioms.example: Many influencers rely so much on filters that they are virtually unrecognisable without them.

idioms.meaning: To become extremely popular online, and be shared many times by many people.
idioms.example: The power of social media is that you never know what is going to go viral, so anyone has a chance of finding fame.

idioms.meaning: A person who travels into space.
idioms.example: While many children dream of becoming astronauts, the fantasy and the reality are actually quite different.

idioms.meaning: Living creatures from another planet.
idioms.example: I do believe in the existence of extraterrestrial life, but I’m a little worried about what might happen if we encounter it.

idioms.word: The commercial exploitation of space (phrasal noun)
idioms.meaning: Attempts to do business and make a profit in space.
idioms.example: Many companies are starting to investigate the commercial exploitation of space, with SpaceX and Blue Origin two of the frontrunners.

idioms.meaning: The action of placing weapons in space.
idioms.example: While humans so far have largely avoided the militarization of space, many experts believe that it is an inevitability.

idioms.meaning: The parts of space far from Earth and the Moon.
idioms.example: The next step for humanity is the exploration of deep space.

idioms.meaning: The use of extremely cold temperatures to preserve someone in a state of hibernation.
idioms.example: Many sci-fi movies use cryogenic freezing as a way of explaining how humans could survive long journeys into deep space.

idioms.meaning: The distance that light can travel in one year. Used as a measurement of distance in space travel.
idioms.example: Beyond our own sun, the nearest star is 4 light years away from Earth.

idioms.meaning: The study of space and anything beyond the Earth.
idioms.example: The field of astronomy is considered one of the most challenging areas of science, and with good reason!

idioms.meaning: In the situation of travelling around the Earth (or another planet/moon/star) while remaining outside the atmosphere.
idioms.example: There are an increasing number of commercial satellites in orbit around the Earth.

idioms.meaning: Something that causes a feeling of awe through being very special in some way. 169170
idioms.example: I think seeing the Earth from space would be absolutely awe-inspiring.

idioms.meaning: The positive feeling of teamwork and team spirit when working or playing sports together.
idioms.example: People who play in successful sports teams, whether at a high or low level, often enjoy great camaraderie with their teammates.

idioms.meaning: To compete or fight against someone in the strongest possible way, fiercely and directly.
idioms.example: One of the joys of playing sports is going toe to toe with your opponent and seeing who emerges as the victor.

idioms.word: To leave it all out on the field (idiom, verb)
idioms.meaning: To put in all possible effort during an activity, so that you have no energy left afterwards.
idioms.example: One of the greatest things about playing sports is the feeling you get afterwards of having left it all out on the field.

idioms.meaning: A sport that is enjoyable to watch.
idioms.example: I’d say football is the most popular spectator sport in my country, but it’s never been my cup of tea.

idioms.meaning: To start to do a new activity, such as a sport or hobby.
idioms.example: I’m considering taking up swimming in order to get in shape before summer.

idioms.meaning: To be very committed and dedicated to practicing something e.g. specific sports skills.
idioms.example: You have to practice religiously for many years if you want to become a professional athlete, so I’d say they do deserve their high salaries.

idioms.meaning: A sport in which people can make contact with each other legally. For example, football, rugby, ice-hockey.
idioms.example: I always wanted to play contact sports like football, but my parents were worried about the risk of injuries.

idioms.meaning: Very exciting or thrilling.
idioms.example: As far as I’m concerned, nothing is more exhilarating than the feeling of winning a very closely fought sports game that goes down to the wire.

idioms.word: Go down to the wire (idiom, verb)
idioms.meaning: A sports game or competition in which the result is in doubt until the very end.
idioms.example: The most exhilarating sports games are the ones that go right down to the wire.

idioms.meaning: To receive the enthusiastic applause of the audience after a performance.
idioms.example: I always wanted to be a famous sports star and get a standing ovation from the crowd after a great performance, but I was never good enough to play professionally.

idioms.meaning: A big, usually positive development in a specific area. Could be science and technology, or other areas e.g. emotional.
idioms.example: Scientific and technological breakthroughs can lead to great improvements in people’s quality of life, as well as economic opportunities.

idioms.meaning: A way of explaining complicated ideas in simple words so that non-experts can understand.
idioms.example: I’m not a technology expert, so I prefer people to explain new concepts in layman’s terms to make it easier for me to understand.

idioms.meaning: An area of technology which aims to create machines capable of performing tasks that usually need human intelligence. Also known as AI.
idioms.example: While many people are excited about the rise of artificial intelligence, others are concerned about the dangers it could pose.

idioms.meaning: Someone who either doesn’t understand or actively dislikes new technology. Note – used with capital L when used as a noun, with lower case ‘l’ when adjective.
idioms.example: The great thing about the first iPhone was that even a self-confessed Luddite like me could use it fairly easily.

idioms.meaning: A feature of websites that allows them to track user activity and modify the performance of the website accordingly, or more accurately advertise to the users.
idioms.example: I worry about being manipulated by internet advertising, so I generally opt out of internet cookies when I visit a new website.

idioms.meaning: A piece of technology (or a person) that is too old or technologically limited to be useful.
idioms.example: The rise of self-driving cars may render human drivers obsolete in the near future.

idioms.meaning: A development or decision that changes a situation in a big way. For example, the discovery of a cure for cancer would be a game changer for medicine.
idioms.example: Scientists say that technology that allows genetic modification could be a game changer in the way we look at reproduction.

idioms.meaning: A type of digital currency that only exists electronically. A famous example is Bitcoin.
idioms.example: Many people are worried that cryptocurrency is just a fad, but others have made millions investing in Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.

idioms.meaning: Protection against cybercrime (crime that occurs through the use of technology and/or the internet)
idioms.example: It’s important to pay attention to cybersecurity, for individuals, companies and even governments.

idioms.meaning: When a piece of technology is easy for non-experts to use.
idioms.example: However complicated the underlying technology is, a piece of software must be as user-friendly as possible if it wants to attract a significant userbase.

idioms.meaning: The physical and organizational structures and facilities of a society. For example, road, hospitals, power supplies.
idioms.example: Ever since the government improved the transport infrastructure in this city, it’s been far easier to move around either by car or public transport.

idioms.meaning: When traffic on the road is very heavy and moving very slowly.
idioms.example: One of the advantages of taking the subway is that it saves loads of time, because it’s always bumper to bumper on the streets during rush hour.

idioms.meaning: An area in which several roads or lanes of traffic merge into one road/lane, leading to very heavy traffic.
idioms.example: There are several places on my journey to work in which the government had to add extra lanes to the road in order to prevent bottlenecks.

idioms.meaning: A young male car driver who drives in a fast and irresponsible manner, causing discomfort or danger to other road users.
idioms.example: One of the dangers of driving your own car is having to deal with boy racers who drive too fast and can cause accidents.

idioms.meaning: The angry feeling that some people get when they drive, which can lead to them shouting at or fighting other drivers.
idioms.example: Fortunately for me, I don’t suffer from road rage, but I know people who get angry almost as soon as they get into the car.

idioms.meaning: The waste emissions from a car’s exhaust pipe.
idioms.example: One way for the government to combat air pollution is to reduce the emission of car exhaust fumes.

idioms.meaning: When several people traveling to the same or nearby places share a single car, rather than each driving their own cars.
idioms.example: I try to carpool whenever possible, because I think it’s a great way of reducing my carbon footprint while also being more sociable.

idioms.meaning: A ticket bought for public transportation (buses, subway etc) that last for a long period of time, from a few months to 1-2 years. Often sold at a large discount.
idioms.example: Public transport can be quite expensive if you buy single tickets every day, but you can make significant savings by buying an annual season ticket.

idioms.meaning: A person who gives driving instructions while not driving. Refers to driving but also other situations when a person who is not in charge tries to take control from the leader in some way. Used in a negative way.
idioms.example: Driving is probably my preferred form of transportation, as long as I don’t have a backseat driver in the car with me.

idioms.meaning: Cars that are driven automatically by technology rather than being controlled by humans.
idioms.example: The next big improvement in transportation must be the widespread adoption of self-driving cars.

idioms.meaning: When all food, drink and sometimes activities are included in the price- e.g. in a hotel.
idioms.example: I stayed in a wonderful all-inclusive resort when I visited Thailand.

idioms.meaning: A trip, often for a day or several days. Usually done for fun or interest.
idioms.example: The hotel we stayed in offered all kinds of excursions, including a trip to a local food market.

idioms.meaning: To eat a large amount of food, usually on a special occasion or in a specific place.
idioms.example: Whenever we go on holiday, we always eat like pigs.

idioms.meaning: A wonderful place
idioms.example: I’ve often heard it said that Dubai is a paradise for shoppers.

idioms.meaning: To start to understand a new place or situation. Particularly used to describe knowing where things are or how things work e.g. in a new city.
idioms.example: The first thing that I like to do in a new city is take a few hours to walk around and get my bearings.

idioms.meaning: To take time to enjoy a pleasurable experience, for example looking at something beautiful
idioms.example: People visiting the Great Wall often just stand still in front of the wall and drink it in.

idioms.meaning: Something which is completely worth seeing, often a tourist attraction or movie.
idioms.example: If you visit Paris, the Eiffel Tower is a must-see.

idioms.meaning: When someone familiar with a place (e.g. their hometown) acts as a guide for visitors.
idioms.example: If you visit a new city, it’s great to have someone who can show you the sights, but if not, there are usually plenty of maps and tour guides available.

idioms.meaning: Very polite and helpful, paying close attention to the needs of someone.
idioms.example: One of the best things about that trip was how friendly and attentive all the staff in the hotel were.

idioms.meaning: The best moment(s) of a trip or activity.
idioms.example: The highlight of our trip was definitely climbing the Empire State Building and looking down on the whole of New York.

idioms.meaning: A very severe storm, which can cause great damage if it reaches land.
idioms.example: The damage caused by a hurricane that hits land can run into the tens of billions of dollars.

idioms.meaning: Very cold. Used literally as being below zero degrees Celsius, or figuratively to mean ‘extremely cold’
idioms.example: My city has very extreme weather – it’s always boiling in summer and absolutely freezing in winter.

idioms.meaning: To get very wet, usually from heavy rain.
idioms.example: The main thing to remember is to always carry an umbrella, otherwise you run the risk of getting absolutely soaked.

idioms.meaning: To be extremely wet, usually as a result of rain, and look very sad or uncomfortable. Also used in plural (like drowned rats)
idioms.example: I remember going out with my brother during a rainstorm one day, and coming back five minutes later looking like a pair of drowned rats.

idioms.meaning: A period of very hot weather, hotter than the average for that time of year. Can be dangerously hot.
idioms.example: Intense heatwaves can lead to forest fires and other natural disasters.

idioms.meaning: The measurement for a type of weather or climate that is hot and wet.
idioms.example: I find the humidity in Shanghai in the summer absolutely unbearable.

idioms.meaning: A grey and cloudy day.
idioms.example: Most days in summer are fairly overcast, so we have to make the most of the bright blue skies when they come.

idioms.meaning: The prediction of what something will be in the future – e.g. tomorrow’s weather
idioms.example: The forecast said it would be sunny for the whole day, but it started to rain as soon as we got there.

idioms.meaning: A period of the same type of consistent weather. Usually at least a few days, and as much as 1-2 months.
