idioms.example: My city is always beautiful during a hot spell, but really miserable if we have a wet spell.

idioms.meaning: To rain very heavily.
idioms.example: Generally, outdoor activities in my city can go ahead in any weather. The only exception is if it’s absolutely chucking it down.

idioms.meaning: Doing the same or similar thing again and again. Used as a negative word, usually to explain why something is boring.
idioms.example: I like my job on the whole, but it does get a bit repetitive at times.

idioms.meaning: To start work. Originally used literally for manual laborers, with a punch in card. Today, used for office workers as well. Fairly informal.
idioms.example: I generally punch in at around 8.30am, and clock off at around 5.30pm.

idioms.meaning: Stop working and stop thinking about work. Usually used in the evening, at weekends or on vacations.
idioms.example: The advent of the internet and social media has blurred the lines between work time and rest time, meaning that people often find it difficult to unplug at night.

idioms.meaning: To learn the details of how to do a particular job or work in a particular company. Often used when someone joins a new company.
idioms.example: It took me a while to learn the ropes when I first started this job, but now I know exactly what I’m doing.

idioms.meaning: To have a huge amount of work to do, more than you can handle in a short time.
idioms.example: I often find myself snowed under with work on a Monday, so I rarely clock off until 9pm or even later.

idioms.word: To pour one’s heart and soul into something (idiom, verb)
idioms.meaning: To put all your effort, hard work and emotions into something. For example, a project at work.
idioms.example: The CEOs of start-ups often demand that their employees work long hours and pour their heart and soul into their work.

idioms.meaning: A negative way to describe a full-time job that you have but don’t enjoy, which is probably difficult in some way.
idioms.example: Taking early retirement can be a great way to escape the daily grind, but many people who do it find their life devoid of meaning.

idioms.meaning: A way of describing the role that a low or medium-level employee has in a large company. Often used in a negative way, but can also be positive.
idioms.example: Although I don’t like the idea of being a cog in the machine, my company does have excellent benefits and career advancement opportunities.

idioms.word: A big fish in a small pond (idiom, noun)
idioms.meaning: An important person in a small or medium-sized organisation.
idioms.example: One of the advantages of being a big fish in a small pond is that you can influence the direction that the organisation takes.

idioms.meaning: used for saying that something happened or existed before you were born or before you lived or worked somewhere: trước khi bạn được sinh ra.
idioms.example: When I was a girl, we didn’t have mobile phones. That was before your time, of course.

idioms.meaning: below the usual or expected standard: dưới trung bình.
idioms.example: Your essays have been a bit below par recently. Is anything wrong?

idioms.meaning: used as a criticism of someone when they say things they should not: nhiều chuyện.
idioms.example: Don’t tell Jamie anything you want to remain secret – he’s got a big mouth!

idioms.meaning: used for saying that you are happy to be back in your home: không đâu tốt hơn nhà mình.
idioms.example: It was a good trip, but there’s nothing like home sweet home.

idioms.meaning: an extremely long time: rất lâu.
idioms.example: I haven’t been swimming in donkey’s years.

idioms.meaning: used for saying that someone is annoyed/pleased with you: ai đó làm phiền/vui thích.
idioms.example: I don’t think I’m in Mrs Patterson’s good books at the moment.

idioms.meaning: not knowing very much about something because other people are keeping it secret from you: không biết gì, bí mật.
idioms.example: The Prime Minister kept even his closest colleagues in the dark about when he would call a general election.

idioms.meaning: a long way from any town or city: ở chốn đồng không mông quạnh.
idioms.example: The car broke down and we realised we were in the middle of nowhere.

idioms.meaning: just in time to prevent something bad happening: vừa kịp lúc.
idioms.example: The swimmers were rescued in the nick of time.

idioms.meaning: in an area far from the town or city: nơi hẻo lánh.
idioms.example: I don’t think I could live so far out in the sticks.

idioms.word: it’s as broad as it’s long
idioms.meaning: used for saying that you cannot choose between two things: cũng thế cả thôi.
idioms.example: It’s as broad as it’s long whether we get there on Saturday night or on Sunday morning.

idioms.meaning: a very small amount that will not have much effect: muối bỏ bể.
idioms.example: The cost of a hotel for one night is a drop in the ocean if you compare it to the company’s budget.

idioms.meaning: a place where you feel as relaxed as you do in your own home: ngôi nhà thứ hai.
idioms.example: Everyone arrives at this hotel, it’s a home from home.

idioms.word: a leopard can’t change its spots
idioms.meaning: used for saying that someone will never change their behaviour or character: giang sơn dễ đổi, bản tính khó dời.
idioms.example: Jimmy says he’s changed, but a leopard never changes its spots, you know.

idioms.meaning: someone or something that you are very pleased to see: cảnh đẹp ý vui.
idioms.example: You’re a sight for sore eyes! I’m so pleased you’re here!

idioms.meaning: used for saying that it is better to solve a problem now, rather than leave it until later when it may be more difficult: một mũi khâu lúc này hơn chín mũi khâu sau.
idioms.example: If there’s a problem with your car, you have to get it looked at now. You know what they say: a stitch in time saves nine.

idioms.meaning: very close to: rất gần.
idioms.example: Where we live is only a stone’s throw from the park.

idioms.meaning: a weak feature of someone or something that could cause failure or be attacked: gót chân Achilles, điểm yếu.
idioms.example: She’s an extremely talented politician, but her Achilles’ heel may be her inability to prioritise.

idioms.meaning: make a bad situation worse: đổ thêm dầu vào lửa.
idioms.example: Your refusing to discuss this with Colin is just adding fuel to the fire, in my opinion.

idioms.meaning: used for telling someone to wait for something and not try to make you hurry: kiên nhẫn, lặng lẽ.
idioms.example: You’ll get the report when it’s finished. All in good time!

idioms.meaning: the machines and pieces of equipment in your house that make life easy and comfortable: tất cả tiện nghi hiện đại.
idioms.example: I’d quite like to move to a place that has all mod cons.

idioms.meaning: an event such as a flood, lightning, or an earthquake that is produced by natural forces, and that people have no control over: thảm họa thiên nhiên.
idioms.example: The insurance doesn’t cover acts of God.

idioms.meaning: in a straight line (used for measuring distance): theo đường chim bay.
idioms.example: It’s about 200 miles as the crow flies.

idioms.meaning: with nothing in particular to do: vô công rồi nghề.
idioms.example: If you’re at a loose end this weekend, why don’t we get together?

idioms.word: at the drop of a hat
idioms.meaning: immediately or in a way that shows that you have no doubts about doing something: ngay lập tức.
idioms.example: Let me know if you need help and I’ll be there at the drop of a hat!

idioms.meaning: permanently, without the possibility of change in the future: mãi mãi.
idioms.example: Have Don and Jenny split up for good, do you think, or is it only temporary?

topic vocab.meaning: Without notice to prepare the mind for the event; sudden
topic vocab.example: The ambulance came to an abrupt stop outside the patient’s home.

topic vocab.meaning: to want something a lot, especially something difficult to get (ao ước)
topic vocab.example: Many people yearn to retire to the country, but not everyone manages it.

topic vocab.meaning: so entertaining that you give it all your attention (hấp dẫn)
topic vocab.example: The film was so absorbing that time simply flew by.

topic vocab.meaning: relaxed and informal (tự nhiên, không trịnh trọng)
topic vocab.example: The party is quite casual, so don’t dress too formally.

topic vocab.meaning: making you feel happy, excited and full of energy (gây hứng khởi, hồi hộp)
topic vocab.example: The funfair was really exhilarating.

topic vocab.meaning: a feeling of being very tired (mệt nhọc)
topic vocab.example: Fatigue can lead to mistakes.

topic vocab.meaning: not doing anything when you should be (lười biếng, vô công rồi nghề)
topic vocab.example: Don’t just sit there being idle — there’s housework to be done.

topic vocab.meaning: not working or not being used (ăn không ngồi rồi)
topic vocab.example: The company is losing money all the time the workers are idle.

topic vocab.meaning: to allow yourself to have or do something enjoyable (nuông chiều, thỏa mãn)
topic vocab.example: I decided to indulge myself and had a holiday in the Bahamas.

topic vocab.meaning: the way in which a person lives (lối sống)
topic vocab.example: This product is ideal for today’s busy lifestyles.

topic vocab.meaning: a period of time away from your job or the armed forces (thời gian nghỉ phép)
topic vocab.example: My brother comes out of the army on leave next week.

topic vocab.meaning: a short journey taken for enjoyment (cuộc đi chơi ngắn)
topic vocab.example: Let’s have an outing to the beach this weekend.

topic vocab.meaning: an activity that you do for fun in your free time (trò tiêu khiển)
topic vocab.example: I need to find a pastime that doesn’t demand a lot of money.

topic vocab.meaning: to follow or try to achieve something (theo đuổi)
topic vocab.example: I’m thinking of pursuing a career in medicine.

topic vocab.meaning: activities done for enjoyment (sự giải trí, tiêu khiển)
topic vocab.example: Sport can be a very social form of recreation.

topic vocab.meaning: a short break from something difficult or unpleasant (thời gian nghỉ ngơi)
topic vocab.example: We had a few days of respite from the hot weather, but it soon got warmer again.

topic vocab.meaning: involving little physical activity (tĩnh tại, ít vận động)
topic vocab.example: I’ve got quite a sedentary job, so I like to go to the gym once a week.

topic vocab.meaning: to spend time with others in a friendly way (giao tiếp xã hội)
topic vocab.example: We seem to have done a lot of socialising this month.

topic vocab.meaning: the state of being alone in a pleasant way (trạng thái cô độc dễ chịu)
topic vocab.example: There’s nothing like the peace and solitude you get when you’re fishing.

topic vocab.meaning: boring and lasting a long time (chán ngắt)
topic vocab.example: I couldn’t believe how tedious that meeting was!

topic vocab.meaning: not important or serious (tầm thường, vụn vặt)
topic vocab.example: Fran always seems to think that her problems are important, while yours are quite trivial.

topic vocab.meaning: to relax after working or being nervous (thư giãn)
topic vocab.example: I like to unwind with a good book in the evenings.

topic vocab.meaning: a place where an event happens (địa điểm)
topic vocab.example: Have they chosen a venue for the wedding yet?

topic vocab.meaning: to become less or worse (giảm, suy tàn)
topic vocab.example: The service in this hotel has really declined over the last couple of years.

topic vocab.meaning: spending all your time and effort on something (tận tâm)
topic vocab.example: Kelly’s very dedicated to her job and should go far.

topic vocab.meaning: to give someone a lot of enjoyment or pleasure (làm vui sướng)
topic vocab.example: I was delighted by the decision.

topic vocab.meaning: to want something (ao ước, khát khao)
topic vocab.example: It’s quite common for people to desire what they can’t have.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong feeling of wanting to have or do something (niềm mơ ước, khao khát)
topic vocab.example: She had a strong desire to work in the media.

topic vocab.meaning: to spend a lot of time or effort doing something (cống hiến)
topic vocab.example: Gordon’s absolutely devoted to his kids.

topic vocab.meaning: to use something such as money for a particular purpose (dành cho việc gì)
topic vocab.example: The government has devoted £10 million to the museum.

topic vocab.meaning: to see or show the difference between things (phân biệt)
topic vocab.example: I’m colour blind, so I have problems differentiating between red and green.

topic vocab.meaning: to have the unhappy feeling of wanting to be like someone else (ghen tị)
topic vocab.example: Carla’s brother never showed envy at her success.

topic vocab.meaning: the unhappy feeling of wanting what someone else has (sự ghen tị)
topic vocab.example: Envy can destroy a relationship.

topic vocab.meaning: to want to have or do something (thích, muốn)
topic vocab.example: Do you fancy going out tonight?

topic vocab.meaning: state of being extremely interested in something (sự quyến rũ, hấp dẫn)
topic vocab.example: Carol’s always had a fascination with insects.

topic vocab.meaning: to support or agree with one thing more than another (sự ủng hộ)
topic vocab.example: I favour the first suggestion.

topic vocab.meaning: to help or give advantage to someone (thiên vị)
topic vocab.example: It’s not fair to favour one student over another.

topic vocab.meaning: to do something for someone as an act of kindness (sự giúp đỡ)
topic vocab.example: I don’t suppose you could do me a favour, could you?

topic vocab.meaning: wanting more money, things or power than needed (tham lam)
topic vocab.example: Maybe being sick will teach you not to be so greedy next time.

topic vocab.meaning: a sudden strong desire to do something (sự thôi thúc)
topic vocab.example: I couldn’t resist the impulse to kiss her.

topic vocab.meaning: feeling that you want to do something (có khuynh hướng)
topic vocab.example: I’m inclined to agree with you.

topic vocab.meaning: an enjoyment or fondness for something (sự ưa thích)
topic vocab.example: I developed a liking for Chinese food when I lived there.

topic vocab.meaning: average or below average in quality (tầm thường)
topic vocab.example: The food was only mediocre.

topic vocab.meaning: the reason why someone does something (động cơ)
topic vocab.example: What was the murderer’s motive?

topic vocab.meaning: ordinary and not interesting or exciting (tẻ nhạt)
topic vocab.example: I’m thinking of changing jobs. This one’s become quite mundane.

topic vocab.meaning: thinking or worrying about something all the time (bị ám ảnh)
topic vocab.example: Oliver’s totally obsessed with football.

topic vocab.meaning: not required, you can choose to do it (tùy chọn)
topic vocab.example: The course includes some optional language classes.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong enthusiasm for something (niềm đam mê)
topic vocab.example: Alice had a passion for cooking.

topic vocab.meaning: to express admiration or approval (khen ngợi)
topic vocab.example: The teacher praised the students for their efforts.

topic vocab.meaning: expression of approval or admiration (lời khen)
topic vocab.example: Praise usually works far better than criticism.

topic vocab.meaning: to make a firm decision to do something (quyết tâm)
topic vocab.example: We resolved to leave early and avoid traffic.

topic vocab.meaning: to give up something for the sake of others (hy sinh)
topic vocab.example: We had to sacrifice a lot to get here.

topic vocab.meaning: the act of giving up something valuable (sự hy sinh)
topic vocab.example: She made many sacrifices for her family.

topic vocab.meaning: to make a great effort to achieve something (phấn đấu)
topic vocab.example: You won’t achieve your goals unless you strive towards them.

topic vocab.meaning: ability to judge if something is good or bad (gu, khiếu thẩm mỹ)
topic vocab.example: He really has no taste in clothes.

topic vocab.meaning: appealing, making you want it (đầy cám dỗ)
topic vocab.example: It was a tempting offer, but I had to refuse.

topic vocab.meaning: to advise strongly about what action to take (thúc giục)
topic vocab.example: I would urge you to speak to a lawyer.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong feeling of wanting to do something (sự thôi thúc)
topic vocab.example: I suddenly felt an urge to run from the room.

topic vocab.meaning: to say that you accept or support something (hoan nghênh)
topic vocab.example: We welcome your feedback and suggestions.

topic vocab.meaning: pleased to be accepted or included (được chào đón)
topic vocab.example: We were made to feel very welcome.

topic vocab.meaning: worth the time, effort, or money (đáng giá)
topic vocab.example: Why don’t you watch less TV and do something more worthwhile?

topic vocab.meaning: to decide to start using a particular idea, plan, or method (thực hiện)
topic vocab.example: I adopted the method the coach showed me and played far better.

topic vocab.meaning: to take someone else’s child into your family and legally make them your own (nhận nuôi)
topic vocab.example: We’re hoping to adopt a young boy.

topic vocab.meaning: someone in your family who lived a long time ago (tổ tiên)
topic vocab.example: My ancestors all came from the same part of China.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who has the right to live in a particular country (công dân)
topic vocab.example: He was an American citizen.

topic vocab.meaning: someone you spend a lot of time with (người đồng hành)
topic vocab.example: This prize is a holiday for you and your companion.

topic vocab.meaning: a child or other relative you care for financially (người sống phụ thuộc)
topic vocab.example: I couldn’t believe how many dependants he’s got!

topic vocab.meaning: a relative of someone from the past (hậu duệ)
topic vocab.example: I’m a descendant of Lord Byron.

topic vocab.meaning: able to understand how someone feels (thấu cảm)
topic vocab.example: I’ve had a similar experience, so I can empathise.

topic vocab.meaning: someone confident and outgoing (người hướng ngoại)
topic vocab.example: She’s such an extrovert and loves meeting new people.

topic vocab.meaning: to take care of a child temporarily (nuôi dưỡng tạm thời)
topic vocab.example: Parents have fostered lots of children over the years.

topic vocab.meaning: someone legally responsible for a child (người giám hộ)
topic vocab.example: You need to get the form signed by a parent or guardian.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who prefers being alone or quiet (người hướng nội)
topic vocab.example: I’m more of an introvert and prefer to spend time on my own.

topic vocab.meaning: someone you do a particular activity with (đối tác)
topic vocab.example: Nadine and I are partners at tennis.

topic vocab.meaning: someone you live with and have a relationship with (bạn đời)
topic vocab.example: The invitation is for me and my partner.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who is the same age or level as you (người đồng lứa)
topic vocab.example: What your peers think of you can be very important.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who had the job before you (người tiền nhiệm)
topic vocab.example: I hope to avoid making my predecessor’s mistakes.

topic vocab.meaning: your brothers and sisters (anh/chị/em ruột)
topic vocab.example: The elder sibling is often more successful in his or her career.

topic vocab.meaning: a husband or wife (vợ hoặc chồng)
topic vocab.example: Each spouse is responsible for paying their own income tax.

topic vocab.meaning: someone’s step-relative from a second marriage (mẹ kế, con riêng...)
topic vocab.example: I didn’t really get on with my stepmother.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who takes a job after someone else (người kế nhiệm)
topic vocab.example: I hope my successor enjoys the job as much as I have.

topic vocab.meaning: to show that you understand and care about someone’s problems (đồng cảm)
topic vocab.example: Why do you always sympathise with people instead of blaming them?

topic vocab.meaning: a strong need to regularly have or do something (nghiện)
topic vocab.example: I developed an addiction to video games.

topic vocab.meaning: to love someone or something very much (rất yêu thích)
topic vocab.example: I absolutely adore Indian food!

topic vocab.meaning: a feeling of excitement about something new (sự hấp dẫn)
topic vocab.example: I waited for the appeal of something new.

topic vocab.meaning: a quality that makes something attractive (tính hấp dẫn)
topic vocab.example: It’s difficult to explain the appeal of this place.

topic vocab.meaning: a request to change a decision (lời kháng cáo)
topic vocab.example: He made an appeal for witnesses to come forward.

topic vocab.meaning: not based on any particular plan or reason (tùy tiện)
topic vocab.example: The wedding was just arbitrary.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong desire to achieve something (khát vọng)
topic vocab.example: One of my aspirations is to become fluent in French.

topic vocab.meaning: to accept or tolerate something difficult (chịu đựng)
topic vocab.example: I can’t bear waiting in queues.

topic vocab.meaning: required by rule or law (bắt buộc)
topic vocab.example: This course is compulsory for all students.

topic vocab.meaning: happy and satisfied (hài lòng)
topic vocab.example: I’m quite content working here.

topic vocab.meaning: a very strong desire for something (sự thèm muốn)
topic vocab.example: I had a sudden craving for chocolate ice cream.

topic vocab.meaning: to say politely that you will not accept something (từ chối)
topic vocab.example: The Prime Minister declined to answer questions.

topic vocab.meaning: a serious disagreement, especially one between groups that lasts a long time (tranh chấp)
topic vocab.example: The dispute seems likely to continue.

topic vocab.meaning: to recognize the difference between two things (phân biệt)
topic vocab.example: It’s not always easy to distinguish between expensive coffee and the cheap brand.

topic vocab.meaning: very different from each other (đa dạng)
topic vocab.example: The school has students from quite a diverse range of backgrounds.

topic vocab.meaning: to take legal action to end your marriage (ly hôn)
topic vocab.example: She and her husband divorced ten years ago.

topic vocab.meaning: the legal ending of a marriage (ly hôn)
topic vocab.example: I’ve been meaning to tell you for some time now… I’d like a divorce.

topic vocab.meaning: something that has the same size, value, importance or meaning (vật tương đương)
topic vocab.example: There’s no equivalent word in English.

topic vocab.meaning: of the same size, value, or meaning as something else (tương đương)
topic vocab.example: We can exchange it for one of equivalent value.

topic vocab.meaning: to deliberately not include something (loại trừ)
topic vocab.example: Excluding ourselves, we’re 18 people on the trip.

topic vocab.meaning: coming from outside a place or organisation (bên ngoài)
topic vocab.example: You’ll be interviewed by an external examiner.

topic vocab.meaning: on or from the outside of something like a building or body (ở bên ngoài)
topic vocab.example: This cream is for external use only.

topic vocab.meaning: to recognize someone and be able to say who they are (xác nhận, nhận diện)
topic vocab.example: The witness wasn’t able to identify the man.

topic vocab.meaning: to feel that you understand and share someone’s feelings (thấu hiểu)
topic vocab.example: I could really identify with the character of Melissa in the film.

topic vocab.meaning: essential or necessary to make something complete (cần thiết, không thể thiếu)
topic vocab.example: Learning to forgive is an integral part of growing up.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone become a full member of society or group (hòa nhập)
topic vocab.example: I think people who come to this country should make an effort to integrate.

topic vocab.meaning: to become involved in a situation and try to influence it without being wanted (xen vào, quấy rầy)
topic vocab.example: Stop interfering in my relationship with Jane!

topic vocab.meaning: in between two stages or levels (trung gian)
topic vocab.example: You can’t become a pilot without going through a lot of intermediate steps.

topic vocab.meaning: at a level of education higher than beginner but lower than advanced (trung cấp)
topic vocab.example: This course is aimed at intermediate learners.

topic vocab.meaning: existing or happening inside a building, body, or organisation (bên trong)
topic vocab.example: We decided to knock down one of the internal walls.

topic vocab.meaning: to become involved in a situation in order to improve or change it (can thiệp)
topic vocab.example: The fight could have got ugly if the teacher hadn’t intervened.

topic vocab.meaning: describes a very close and personal relationship (thân mật)
topic vocab.example: Martin seems to have problems forming intimate relationships.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to very private or personal things (riêng tư)
topic vocab.example: Try not to ask too many intimate questions.

topic vocab.meaning: to include as a necessary part or result (bao gồm)
topic vocab.example: Getting your degree is going to involve a lot of hard work.

topic vocab.meaning: to include someone in an activity (bao gồm ai đó tham gia)
topic vocab.example: You need to involve your team in decision-making.

topic vocab.meaning: involving two or more people (chung, cùng nhau)
topic vocab.example: We decided to open a joint bank account.

topic vocab.meaning: to say that someone or something is similar to someone or something else (so sánh với)
topic vocab.example: She likened her experience to being on a roller coaster.

topic vocab.meaning: to connect or relate two or more things (liên kết)
topic vocab.example: The robbery is linked to the one that took place last week.

topic vocab.meaning: a connection or relationship between two or more things (mối liên hệ)
topic vocab.example: There’s a strong link between diet and health.

topic vocab.meaning: to combine two or more things into one (sáp nhập)
topic vocab.example: I might lose my job when the two businesses merge.

topic vocab.meaning: shared equally by two or more people (lẫn nhau, chung)
topic vocab.example: John doesn’t respect mutual feelings of trust.

topic vocab.meaning: to try to reach an agreement by discussion (đàm phán)
topic vocab.example: We managed to negotiate through traffic and arrive on time.

topic vocab.meaning: connected in some way (liên quan)
topic vocab.example: The stress you are under is related to your workload.

topic vocab.meaning: considered in comparison with something else (tương đối)
topic vocab.example: After the failure of other schemes, the last one was a relative success.

topic vocab.meaning: similarity in appearance or nature (sự tương đồng)
topic vocab.example: Can you see the resemblance between me and my father?

topic vocab.meaning: someone you know a little, but who is not a close friend (người quen)
topic vocab.example: He’s not really a friend, more of an acquaintance.

topic vocab.meaning: a piece of art that consists of several different objects or images arranged to produce a particular effect (tác phẩm trưng bày)
topic vocab.example: There’s an interesting installation at the Tate Gallery next month. The artist created a powerful light installation. Visitors admired the outdoor sound installation. The museum hosts interactive installations annually.

topic vocab.meaning: the words that an actor says in a performance (lời thoại)
topic vocab.example: He forgot his lines. She memorized her lines overnight. The actor practiced his lines before rehearsal. His delivery of the final lines was perfect.

topic vocab.meaning: the words of a song (lời bài hát)
topic vocab.example: I’ve written the music but not the lyrics. She always mishears the lyrics. He studies song lyrics for inspiration. These lyrics are beautifully poetic.

topic vocab.meaning: an excellent work of art, book, piece of music, etc. (kiệt tác)
topic vocab.example: The film widely regarded as Hitchcock’s masterpiece. This novel is her literary masterpiece. The painting was declared a masterpiece. That sculpture is considered a modern masterpiece.

topic vocab.meaning: a book with a soft cover (sách bìa mềm)
topic vocab.example: His collection of rare books is now out in paperback. She prefers to travel with paperbacks. I found an old paperback edition. The book was released in paperback this spring.

topic vocab.meaning: typical of a particular historical time (thuộc về thời kỳ nào đó)
topic vocab.example: Will you be wearing period costumes in the play? The film used period furniture. She collects period jewelry. A period drama aired last night.

topic vocab.meaning: a particular time in history (thời kỳ)
topic vocab.example: Her collection is solely related to the Roman period. It was a difficult period in his life. We studied the Baroque period in class. The medieval period was very harsh.

topic vocab.meaning: very valuable and impossible to replace (vô giá)
topic vocab.example: These are priceless jewels. That vase is absolutely priceless. The moment we shared was priceless. Her advice turned out to be priceless.

topic vocab.meaning: a set of fixed actions performed regularly (nghi lễ, nghi thức)
topic vocab.example: Are you coming to the piano recital ritual tonight? He follows a strict morning ritual. The ritual lasted for two hours. Candle lighting was part of the ritual.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to things that happened in the past (hồi tưởng)
topic vocab.example: The show includes a retrospective look at the 1970s. It was a retrospective exhibition of her work. His writing had a retrospective tone. The museum held a retrospective series.

topic vocab.meaning: an exhibition showing the work of an artist over a long period (triển lãm hồi cố)
topic vocab.example: I really want to get to the Tim Burton retrospective. They opened a retrospective of Picasso. The gallery hosted a Van Gogh retrospective. The retrospective drew large crowds.

topic vocab.meaning: the music written for a film, play, etc. (nhạc phim)
topic vocab.example: Who wrote the musical score for Star Wars? The score enhanced the scene’s emotion. That composer won awards for his score. The film’s score is unforgettable.

topic vocab.meaning: a drawing made quickly that does not have many details (bức phác thảo)
topic vocab.example: Draw a rough sketch of the dog. She shared her travel sketches. His sketch captured the skyline beautifully. The museum displayed several artist sketches.

topic vocab.meaning: to make a quick drawing (phác thảo)
topic vocab.example: She sketched the outline of the landscape. He sketched a portrait from memory. I just sketch and go with the flow. We sat by the lake and sketched birds.

topic vocab.meaning: to describe something briefly (mô tả sơ lược)
topic vocab.example: I’ll just sketch out a few ideas. She sketched the plan to the team. He sketched the situation before we entered. They asked him to sketch the event quickly.

topic vocab.word: work of art (n phr) /ˌwɜːk əv ˈɑːt/
topic vocab.meaning: something that is made or done in a skilful or attractive way (công trình nghệ thuật)
topic vocab.example: Her house is a real work of art. The dress was a work of art. The garden is a living work of art. That mural is a true work of art.

topic vocab.meaning: not having any value or good qualities (vô giá trị)
topic vocab.example: The country’s currency is nearly worthless. That promise turned out worthless. This broken device is worthless now. The coins looked old but were worthless.

topic vocab.meaning: next to or near something else (ở sát cạnh)
topic vocab.example: The theatre is adjacent to the library. Our room was adjacent to the pool. The adjacent street was blocked. We sat in adjacent seats.

topic vocab.meaning: to join or fasten something (gắn liền, đính)
topic vocab.example: You need to attach these two parts. The form is attached to the letter. She attached her name to the application. Please attach a recent photo.

topic vocab.meaning: to fix things firmly together with glue, or to form a close connection (gắn kết)
topic vocab.example: It’s not easy to bond plastic and metal. They bonded quickly during the trip. Heat helps bond the materials. They bonded over shared experiences.

topic vocab.meaning: a close connection joining two or more people (mối liên kết)
topic vocab.example: We shared a strong bond from the start. Their bond grew stronger over time. Family bonds can last a lifetime. There’s a bond of trust between us.

topic vocab.meaning: to live or exist together (cùng tồn tại)
topic vocab.example: Can art and commerce coexist? These traditions coexist peacefully. Humans and animals coexist in harmony. Two different views can coexist.

topic vocab.meaning: logical and well-organized (mạch lạc)
topic vocab.example: Your argument is not coherent. He gave a coherent explanation. Her writing is clear and coherent. The plan must be coherent and realistic.

topic vocab.meaning: able to exist or work together (tương thích, hòa hợp)
topic vocab.example: Lisa and Jim are very compatible. The software isn’t compatible with my phone. Their goals aren’t compatible. The charger is compatible with all models.

topic vocab.meaning: a way of solving a problem in which people agree to accept less (sự thỏa hiệp)
topic vocab.example: They reached a compromise after long talks. Compromise is vital in any relationship. We made a compromise on budget. The solution was a fair compromise.

topic vocab.meaning: to settle a disagreement by each side accepting less (thỏa hiệp)
topic vocab.example: They agreed to compromise on the schedule. You must compromise to move forward. We compromised after hours of debate. Don’t compromise your values easily.

topic vocab.meaning: a serious disagreement (xung đột)
topic vocab.example: Many people have died in the conflict. There’s a conflict between two departments. Family conflict affects children deeply. Conflict over pay led to the strike.

topic vocab.meaning: to go close to someone in a threatening way (đối mặt)
topic vocab.example: A man in a suit confronted me. She was afraid to confront her boss. He confronted the thief in the act. They confronted protesters at the gate.

topic vocab.meaning: to deal with a difficult situation (đương đầu)
topic vocab.example: Just confront the problem head on. He confronted his past mistakes. She decided to confront the issue. They must confront their fears together.

topic vocab.meaning: not changing in behaviour, attitudes or qualities (nhất quán)
topic vocab.example: He is consistent but not quick. Her results are always consistent. The policy must be consistent. They demand consistent performance.

topic vocab.meaning: to say the opposite of what someone else has said (mâu thuẫn, phủ nhận)
topic vocab.example: The witness contradicted the evidence. Don’t contradict your teacher. His story contradicts the facts. You shouldn’t contradict me all the time.

topic vocab.meaning: to show that something is wrong or false (bác bỏ)
topic vocab.example: The second witness contradicted the alibi. Your statement contradicts the timeline. Facts contradict what you claim. His later words contradicted the original promise.

topic vocab.meaning: very different from each other (đối lập)
topic vocab.example: They wore contrasting styles. The essay compared two contrasting views. Their personalities are contrasting. We studied contrasting colors in design.

topic vocab.meaning: to work with other people to achieve something (hợp tác)
topic vocab.example: We can achieve more if we cooperate. Countries must cooperate to fight climate change. He refused to cooperate with the police. Let’s cooperate on the project.

topic vocab.meaning: to be the same as or very much like something (tương ứng, khớp)
topic vocab.example: The two accounts did not correspond. Your idea corresponds with mine. The evidence corresponds to the theory. Results must correspond to the expectations.

topic vocab.meaning: to say something is incorrect or false (tranh cãi, phản bác)
topic vocab.example: I’m not disputing the facts. She disputed the charges. We disputed the decision. He always disputes authority.

topic vocab.meaning: a serious argument (cuộc tranh cãi)
topic vocab.example: The dispute was finally resolved. There’s a long-standing dispute over the land. That caused a bitter dispute. The contract ended in legal dispute.

topic vocab.meaning: the best or most suitable type (lý tưởng, tốt nhất)
topic vocab.example: The fair provides an ideal opportunity for job seekers and employers to meet.

topic vocab.meaning: an idea or standard that seems perfect and worth aiming for (lý tưởng)
topic vocab.example: In an ideal world there would be no poverty or war.

topic vocab.meaning: not good enough or not sufficient for a particular purpose (không đủ, không tương xứng)
topic vocab.example: We are suffering because of inadequate resources.

topic vocab.meaning: extremely useful (vô giá)
topic vocab.example: The Internet is an invaluable resource for students.

topic vocab.meaning: most suitable within a range of possibilities (tối ưu)
topic vocab.example: The warm water provides the optimum conditions for breeding.

topic vocab.meaning: the best or most suitable situation, level or amount (mức tối ưu)
topic vocab.example: The optimum we should be producing is 100 units per hour.

topic vocab.meaning: to be much better than someone or something else (vượt trội)
topic vocab.example: The team was completely outclassed by the opposition.

topic vocab.meaning: most important, most suitable or of the highest quality (chính, chủ yếu, ưu tú)
topic vocab.example: Our prime concern was the safety of the children.

topic vocab.meaning: a quality that improves something that is not very good (điểm bù trừ)
topic vocab.example: Smith’s only redeeming feature is his sense of humor.

topic vocab.meaning: to improve a room or building by cleaning and decorating it (tân trang, cải tạo)
topic vocab.example: They’re planning to refurbish the teachers’ room.

topic vocab.meaning: to make a building, structure or object stronger (gia cố)
topic vocab.example: Crews started work today to reinforce the seriously damaged bridge.

topic vocab.meaning: to make something old look new again by repairing and improving it (nâng cấp, cải tạo)
topic vocab.example: They plan to renovate the fire station.

topic vocab.meaning: something that is decayed or bad (thối, hỏng)
topic vocab.example: There was a horrible smell of rotten eggs.

topic vocab.meaning: of low quality, standard or behavior (tệ hại)
topic vocab.example: She’s a rotten singer.

topic vocab.meaning: a rusty metal object is covered in rust (bị gỉ sét)
topic vocab.example: I don’t know why you bought that rusty old car.

topic vocab.meaning: good enough to be accepted in a particular situation (đủ dùng)
topic vocab.example: I have still not received a satisfactory answer to my question.

topic vocab.meaning: enjoyable and pleasing (hài lòng)
topic vocab.example: This new arrangement proved highly satisfactory to us all.

topic vocab.meaning: a situation that is very badly organised and does not operate effectively (rối ren, hỗn loạn)
topic vocab.example: Government corruption has left the economy in a shambles.

topic vocab.meaning: shoddy work, services or products are of very low standard (chất lượng kém)
topic vocab.example: The work they did on the new road was very shoddy in places.

topic vocab.meaning: involving good judgment or reliable methods (hợp lý, đúng đắn)
topic vocab.example: You’ll need a sound understanding of basic teaching skills before you start.

topic vocab.meaning: thorough or solid (toàn diện, vững chắc)
topic vocab.example: Wrap the bread in foil to keep it sound.

topic vocab.meaning: food that is stale is old and no longer fresh (ôi, thiu)
topic vocab.example: This bread is stale. Throw it away.

topic vocab.meaning: to improve a business, organisation, process etc by making it more modern and efficient (tinh gọn)
topic vocab.example: We need to streamline the whole process.

topic vocab.meaning: to make something stronger (gia cố, củng cố)
topic vocab.example: The bridge strengthens the connection between the two cities.

topic vocab.meaning: to be better or greater than something else (vượt qua)
topic vocab.example: Winning the gold medal surpassed our expectations.

topic vocab.meaning: happening at the end of a process or activity (cuối cùng)
topic vocab.example: The incident affected the outcome of the ultimate decision.

topic vocab.meaning: as good or as bad as possible (tối thượng, tốt nhất)
topic vocab.example: The course offers the ultimate test of skill.

topic vocab.meaning: to become worse, or to make something worse (làm trầm trọng hơn)
topic vocab.example: Temperatures fell and the weather worsened.

topic vocab.meaning: something that has been badly damaged (đống đổ nát)
topic vocab.example: The car was a wreck after the accident.

topic vocab.meaning: to severely damage (phá hủy)
topic vocab.example: The town was wrecked by the bombing.

topic vocab.meaning: abstract art shows ideas rather than actual objects (trừu tượng)
topic vocab.example: I’m not very keen on abstract paintings.

topic vocab.meaning: an abstract painting or design (tác phẩm trừu tượng)
topic vocab.example: You’re not supposed to understand what an abstract is.

topic vocab.meaning: a public occasion when things are sold to the person who offers the most money (buổi đấu giá)
topic vocab.example: They bought the paintings at auction in 1989.

topic vocab.meaning: a short performance to decide if someone is good enough (buổi thử vai)
topic vocab.example: I’ve got an audition for the school play tomorrow.

topic vocab.meaning: a book that many people buy (sách bán chạy)
topic vocab.example: His first novel was a bestseller.

topic vocab.meaning: a rare or valuable object that collectors want (đồ hiếm)
topic vocab.example: Do you think this watch is a collector’s item?

topic vocab.meaning: someone whose job is to look after the objects in a museum or art gallery (bảo tàng viên)
topic vocab.example: He’ll be able to tell you more about it – he’s the curator.

topic vocab.meaning: art forms like painting, drawing, or sculpture (mỹ thuật)
topic vocab.example: I’m thinking of studying fine art at university.

topic vocab.meaning: a statement about what disease someone has, based on examining them (chẩn đoán); a diagnosis of appendicitis (chẩn đoán viêm ruột thừa)
topic vocab.example: The doctor’s diagnosis was pneumonia. Early diagnosis of diabetes can save lives. She awaited the final diagnosis with anxiety. His diagnosis of appendicitis was confirmed by blood tests.

topic vocab.meaning: to protect someone against a particular disease by injecting a small amount of it so that their body becomes immune (tiêm phòng); to inoculate someone against diphtheria
topic vocab.example: The hospital inoculated all staff against influenza. They plan to inoculate children before flu season. She was inoculated against measles at birth. The clinic offers to inoculate travelers for free.

topic vocab.meaning: a painful feeling in a part of the body, often with red skin or swelling (kích ứng); stomach irritation (đau dạ dày)
topic vocab.example: The cream reduced skin irritation quickly. Spicy food can cause throat irritation. He experienced eye irritation from the smoke. The patch may cause mild irritation initially.

topic vocab.meaning: a part of your body that is numb has no feeling (tê liệt); After hours of sitting on the floor, her legs had gone numb
topic vocab.example: Her fingers went numb in the cold. He felt numb after hearing the shocking news. The dentist gave her an injection to make her gums numb. He sat so long that his foot went completely numb.

topic vocab.meaning: not able to react or to show your emotions, often because of an extreme shock (làm tê liệt); I was numb with fear
topic vocab.example: He was numb with disbelief after the accident. She sat there, numb from the news. The pain numned her senses. He felt numb and could not cry.

topic vocab.meaning: an institution where old or ill people live when they are too old or ill to look after themselves without help (viện dưỡng lão)
topic vocab.example: My grandmother is moving into a nursing home next week. The nursing home provides 24-hour care. Their grandfather lives in a private nursing home. She visits the nursing home every Sunday.

topic vocab.meaning: the loss of the ability to move your body or a part of it, usually because of an injury or illness (liệt); uỷ liệt; The syndrome can lead to sudden paralysis
topic vocab.example: He recovered slowly from the paralysis. The accident caused partial paralysis in his arm. Early treatment can prevent permanent paralysis. She fears paralysis if the injury worsens.

topic vocab.meaning: to cover a cut or broken bone with a band of plaster (băng dán vết thương); I’ve cut my finger. Have you got a plaster?
topic vocab.example: The nurse plastered his arm after the fall. She plastered the wound to prevent infection. He asked for a plaster for his cut. They plastered her leg until it healed.

topic vocab.meaning: if a part of someone’s body is in plaster, it has a hard cover around it to protect a broken bone (thạch cao); One man had his leg in plaster, having broken it in an accident
topic vocab.example: She had her arm in plaster for six weeks. His plaster was removed yesterday. The child played despite having a plaster on his knee. He accidentally cracked his plaster doing sports.

topic vocab.meaning: if a doctor prescribes a drug or treatment, they say you should have it (kê đơn); The drug should not be taken unless prescribed by a doctor
topic vocab.example: The physician prescribed antibiotics for the infection. He was prescribed rest and fluids. The doctor prescribed a new treatment plan. She prescribes only what’s necessary.

topic vocab.meaning: medical examinations, treatments, advice, etc. intended to prevent illness or discover it before it becomes serious (y tế dự phòng)
topic vocab.example: The government should invest more in preventative medicine. Preventative medicine reduces healthcare costs. She studies preventative medicine at university. Vaccination is a key part of preventative medicine.

topic vocab.meaning: a doctor’s opinion about the way in which a disease or illness is likely to develop (tiên lượng); What’s the prognosis, doctor?
topic vocab.example: The prognosis for full recovery is good. He asked the doctor about his prognosis. Early diagnosis improved her prognosis. The specialist gave a grim prognosis.

topic vocab.meaning: a period of time during which you do not work because you are ill (nghỉ ốm); Mr Jenkins is away on sick leave today
topic vocab.example: She took two weeks of sick leave after surgery. He filed for sick leave last Monday. The company offers paid sick leave. He returned from sick leave refreshed.

topic vocab.meaning: an effect of a medicine that is not intended and could be unpleasant (tác dụng phụ); The treatment has no significant side effects
topic vocab.example: Nausea is a common side effect of this drug. She experienced severe side effects. The doctor warned him about side effects. He stopped the medication due to side effects.

topic vocab.meaning: a needle fitted to a plastic tube, used for taking blood from your body or for putting medicine or drugs into it (ống tiêm)
topic vocab.example: The nurse filled the syringe with vaccine. He handled the syringe carefully. She taught me how to use a syringe. The syringe needs to be sterilized.

topic vocab.meaning: a substance put into the body, usually by injection, in order to provide protection against a disease (vắc xin); Is there an effective vaccine for meningitis?
topic vocab.example: Scientists developed a new vaccine for malaria. The clinic offers free vaccines. He opted to receive the flu vaccine. A vaccine can prevent many illnesses.

topic vocab.meaning: a large room in a hospital with beds for people to stay in; phòng bệnh, khu bệnh; Jo is a staff nurse working on the maternity ward
topic vocab.example: She visited her grandmother in the ward. The ward was full of healthy babies. He volunteered to work in the children’s ward. The ward staff were very attentive.

topic vocab.meaning: an angry feeling that makes you want to attack or defeat someone else (sự hung hăng)
topic vocab.example: He struggled to control his aggression during the heated debate. Road rage is a common form of aggression on busy highways. The coach warned that unchecked aggression could lead to penalties. She learned techniques to manage her aggression in stressful situations.

topic vocab.meaning: the power to make decisions for or tell people what to do (quyền hạn)
topic vocab.example: Only the principal has the authority to approve changes to the curriculum. The manager’s authority was challenged by some team members. We need to escalate this issue to someone with proper authority. He questioned the authority of the new policy.

topic vocab.meaning: kind and easygoing; not harmful (nhân từ, lành tính)
topic vocab.example: Her benign smile put everyone at ease. The lump turned out to be benign, not cancerous. He has a benign demeanor that makes him well liked. The doctor said the growth was benign and required no treatment.

topic vocab.meaning: to frighten or hurt someone who is smaller or weaker (bắt nạt)
topic vocab.example: He refused to bully his classmates into doing his homework. Online platforms must do more to stop users from bullying others. Don’t let anyone bully you into backing down. She stood up when she saw him bully a younger student.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who frightens or hurts someone smaller or weaker (kẻ bắt nạt)
topic vocab.example: The playground bully was finally reprimanded by the teacher. No one should have to tolerate a bully at work. He used to be a bully in high school but has changed. Parents worried the new student would become a target for the bully.

topic vocab.meaning: to officially order someone to do something (mệnh lệnh)
topic vocab.example: The general commanded his troops to hold their position. She commanded the team to stop all work immediately. The director can command resources for any urgent project. He commanded respect from his subordinates.

topic vocab.meaning: an official order (mệnh lệnh)
topic vocab.example: He carried out every command from his superior. The rescue team acted on the commander’s commands. You must follow the safety commands in the manual. Failure to obey that command could be dangerous.

topic vocab.meaning: to take control of land or people using soldiers (chinh phục)
topic vocab.example: The empire set out to conquer neighboring territories. Alexander the Great conquered vast regions before age 30. They attempted to conquer the rugged mountain passes. Napoleon famously tried to conquer all of Europe.

topic vocab.meaning: to gain control of a situation or emotion by making a great effort (chinh phục)
topic vocab.example: She trained hard to conquer her fear of public speaking. He finally conquered the challenges of learning a new language. They worked together to conquer every obstacle. It took years to conquer his self-doubt.

topic vocab.meaning: to give approval for something (đồng ý)
topic vocab.example: You cannot proceed without the patient’s consent. She consented to share her data for the study. He consented to the new terms and conditions. They asked for parental consent before the trip.

topic vocab.meaning: permission to do something (sự đồng ý)
topic vocab.example: The project needed consent from all stakeholders. They obtained consent before accessing private records. He signed the form to indicate his consent. Consent is required by law for any data collection.

topic vocab.meaning: a public disagreement about a policy or moral issue (tranh cãi)
topic vocab.example: The new law sparked controversy across the country. There was controversy over the CEO’s high salary. The film’s ending caused heated controversy among fans. Scientists faced controversy when they published their findings.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who uses force to take and keep power in a country (nhà độc tài)
topic vocab.example: The dictator ruled the nation with an iron fist. Citizens lived in fear under the oppressive dictator. He escaped the country to flee the dictator’s regime. Historians study how dictators maintain control.

topic vocab.meaning: to control something or someone, often negatively, because you have more power (áp đảo)
topic vocab.example: Large corporations often dominate smaller competitors. His presence can dominate any room he enters. Social media platforms dominate our daily interactions. The team’s star player dominated the game.

topic vocab.meaning: to get rid of something unwanted or unnecessary (loại bỏ)
topic vocab.example: We need to eliminate all bugs before release. The new process eliminates redundant steps. He aimed to eliminate waste from the workflow. That diet plan promises to eliminate unhealthy fats.

topic vocab.meaning: to make sure that a law or rule is obeyed (thực thi)
topic vocab.example: Police work to enforce traffic regulations. The company enforces a strict code of conduct. Judges enforce court orders without exception. It’s challenging to enforce remote-work policies.

topic vocab.meaning: having the right to something (được quyền)
topic vocab.example: Students are entitled to free access to the library. He was entitled to compensation after the delay. Full-time employees are entitled to health benefits. She felt entitled to a refund after poor service.

topic vocab.meaning: allowed to ignore a rule, obligation, or payment (được miễn)
topic vocab.example: Nonprofits are exempt from certain taxes. Volunteers may be exempt from registration fees. Some countries exempt students from military service. Members with seniority are exempt from jury duty.

topic vocab.example: Police work to enforce traffic regulations. The company enforces a strict code of conduct. Judges enforce court orders without exception. It’s challenging to enforce remote-work policies.

topic vocab.meaning: having the right to something (được quyền)
topic vocab.example: Students are entitled to free access to the library. He was entitled to compensation after the delay. Full-time employees are entitled to health benefits. She felt entitled to a refund after poor service.

topic vocab.meaning: allowed to ignore a rule, obligation, or payment (được miễn)
topic vocab.example: Nonprofits are exempt from certain taxes. Volunteers may be exempt from registration fees. Some countries exempt students from military service. Members with seniority are exempt from jury duty.

topic vocab.meaning: used for describing someone or something that had a particular job, title, or status in the past, but not now (trước đó)
topic vocab.example: The former CEO now runs a startup. She met her former teacher at the event. Their former office was downtown. The Prime Minister of India is visiting the UK.

topic vocab.meaning: to introduce something such as a law or new system, and force people to accept it (áp đặt)
topic vocab.example: The government imposed a new tax on imports. The school imposed stricter rules for late arrivals. Curfews were imposed after the unrest. New fees are being imposed without anyone’s opinion.

topic vocab.meaning: not as good as something else (kém hơn)
topic vocab.example: Street markets often sell inferior quality goods. Their design felt inferior to the original version. The copy was clearly inferior in build. He never considered himself inferior to others.

topic vocab.meaning: to deliberately make someone feel frightened, especially so that they will do what you want (hăm dọa)
topic vocab.example: The bully tried to intimidate the new student. The manager’s tone intimidated everyone in the room. He uses threats to intimidate people. Richard often tries to intimidate people.

topic vocab.meaning: to use a word or phrase to describe someone or something, especially one that is not completely fair (gán mác)
topic vocab.example: Don’t label all young people as lazy. He was unfairly labeled a troublemaker. They labeled her without understanding her background. I wish people wouldn’t try to put a label on me.

topic vocab.meaning: a piece of paper or material fastened to an object that gives information about it (nhãn, nhãn hiệu)
topic vocab.example: Check the label before washing the shirt. The nutrition label lists all ingredients. I don’t recognize the brand’s label. Each product has a barcode label attached.

topic vocab.meaning: to give someone the freedom to do something by taking away their restrictions (giải phóng)
topic vocab.example: Leaving the job liberated her from stress. They worked to liberate the city from occupation. He felt liberated after speaking his mind. Technology can liberate us from manual tasks.

topic vocab.meaning: ideas, attitudes, or activities that are considered ordinary and accepted by most people (xu hướng chính)
topic vocab.example: Most mainstream politicians dismissed the idea. He struggles to fit into the mainstream. The film never achieved mainstream popularity. Life can be difficult if you're not part of the mainstream.

topic vocab.meaning: considered ordinary or normal and accepted by most people (chính thống)
topic vocab.example: Mainstream media didn’t cover the story. His views differ from mainstream science. She made the issue part of mainstream culture. That style isn’t considered mainstream anymore.

topic vocab.meaning: to learn something thoroughly so that you know how to do it very well (nắm vững, tinh thông)
topic vocab.example: It took her years to master graphic design. He mastered the technique through practice. I’m trying to master Spanish before my trip. She finally mastered the software tools.

topic vocab.meaning: a man who has control over servants or other people (chủ, thầy)
topic vocab.example: The servant bowed to his master. He was the master of the estate. Servants should show respect to their master at all times. The master expected complete obedience.

topic vocab.meaning: an official in charge of a government department (bộ trưởng)
topic vocab.example: The Minister of Health announced new policies. He was appointed as the Education Minister. The Minister responsible for defense resigned. A new Minister was sworn in last week.

topic vocab.meaning: a king or queen (vua, chúa)
topic vocab.example: The monarch represents the country abroad. Britain still has a monarch as head of state. The monarch addressed the nation live. The monarch’s role today is mostly symbolic.

topic vocab.meaning: to officially stop something from being done, especially by making it illegal (cấm)
topic vocab.example: Smoking is prohibited in public buildings. The school prohibits mobile phones during exams. They passed a law to prohibit animal testing. The sale of lottery tickets is prohibited.

topic vocab.meaning: if a king or queen reigns, they officially rule a country (trị vì)
topic vocab.example: Queen Elizabeth II reigned for decades. The king reigned during a time of great change. She reigned with fairness and grace. Monarchs traditionally reign until death.

topic vocab.meaning: the period of time during which a king or queen rules a country (triều đại)
topic vocab.example: The long reign of the monarch brought stability. His reign was marked by peace and reform. What was the longest reign of any king or queen? The reign ended with revolution.

topic vocab.meaning: to make an idea, belief or feeling stronger (củng cố)
topic vocab.example: The speech reinforced their confidence. Media often reinforces stereotypes. His actions reinforced the team's trust in him. The teacher reinforced the idea with real-life examples.

topic vocab.meaning: not willing to do something (chần chừ, miễn cưỡng)
topic vocab.example: He was reluctant to share his ideas at the meeting. She felt reluctant to accept the promotion. I’m reluctant to travel during the storm. Many employees were reluctant to adopt the new system.

topic vocab.meaning: to oppose or fight against something or someone (chống cự, kháng cự)
topic vocab.example: They resisted the new regulations. She couldn't resist laughing at the joke. The people resisted the invaders bravely. The Prime Minister resisted a lot of pressure to change his mind.

topic vocab.meaning: to stop yourself from doing something that you want to do (cưỡng lại, kìm chế)
topic vocab.example: I can’t resist chocolate. He resisted the urge to speak. They couldn’t resist checking their phones. She tried to resist buying the dress.

topic vocab.meaning: to keep something within strict limits (hạn chế)
topic vocab.example: Parents restrict the number of hours children watch TV. Access is restricted to authorized personnel. The policy restricts movement during lockdowns. They restricted the budget for travel expenses.

topic vocab.meaning: people in general living together in organized communities, with laws and traditions (xã hội)
topic vocab.example: Education plays a big role in modern society. Society expects everyone to follow the rules. We live in a diverse and evolving society. People have more freedom in today’s society.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone experience something unpleasant (bắt phải chịu)
topic vocab.example: They were subjected to harsh criticism. The soldier was subjected to intense training. She was subjected to unfair treatment. They subjected the poor prisoner to torture.

topic vocab.meaning: an idea, problem, situation, etc. that you discuss or think about (chủ đề, đề tài)
topic vocab.example: Math is my favorite subject. That subject came up often during meetings. Have you chosen your subject for the essay? It’s a complex subject that needs research.

topic vocab.meaning: a citizen of a country ruled by a monarch (thần dân)
topic vocab.example: He is proud to be a British subject. The Queen’s subjects attended the ceremony. All subjects must obey royal laws. She lived as a subject under the empire.

topic vocab.meaning: based on your own feelings and ideas and not on facts (chủ quan)
topic vocab.example: Her review was highly subjective. Opinions on art are often subjective. That’s just your subjective view. We tried to avoid being subjective in the report.

topic vocab.meaning: to accept that someone has defeated you and you must obey them (phục tùng, đầu hàng)
topic vocab.example: They refused to submit to the enemy. The country would never submit to foreign rule. He finally submitted after hours of questioning. They submitted without a fight.

topic vocab.meaning: to formally give something to someone in authority (nộp)
topic vocab.example: You must submit your application by Friday. She submitted the report late. They stopped listening when he submitted. He was asked to submit the design proposal.

topic vocab.meaning: to officially order someone to come to a place, especially a court of law (triệu tập)
topic vocab.example: The witness was summoned to court. He was summoned for questioning. The king summoned his advisors. I was suddenly summoned to the boss’s office.

topic vocab.meaning: better than someone or something else in quality or skill (vượt trội)
topic vocab.example: His work is vastly superior to mine. This version is technically superior. She thinks her cooking is superior. The latest model is superior in design.

topic vocab.meaning: to make something become gradually less effective or successful (làm suy yếu)
topic vocab.example: His actions undermined the team’s trust. Criticism can undermine your confidence. The scandal undermined the leader’s credibility. This unfortunate event undermined morale.

topic vocab.meaning: angry or violent behavior by people who are protesting (tình trạng bất ổn)
topic vocab.example: The policy led to civil unrest. Political unrest spread quickly. There’s growing unrest among workers. The protest ended in unrest across the city.

topic vocab.meaning: to treat someone in a deliberately unfair way (ngược đãi)
topic vocab.example: It’s not right to victimise someone at work. He was victimised for his beliefs. Many were victimised under the regime. She felt victimised by the teacher’s comments.

topic vocab.meaning: weak or easy to hurt physically or mentally (dễ bị tổn thương)
topic vocab.example: Children are vulnerable to online abuse. The elderly feel vulnerable living alone. She became emotionally vulnerable after the breakup. I felt vulnerable walking home late at night.

topic vocab.meaning: to officially get rid of a law, system, or practice (bãi bỏ)
topic vocab.example: Slavery was abolished in the 19th century. They voted to abolish the tax. The law was officially abolished in 1963. Activists fought to abolish unfair policies.

topic vocab.meaning: to publicly support a particular policy or action (ủng hộ công khai)
topic vocab.example: He advocates equal pay for all employees. The article advocates reform in education. Many advocate for stronger climate action. Do you advocate capital punishment in schools?

topic vocab.meaning: to make something less painful, severe, or serious (giảm bớt)
topic vocab.example: The new policy aims to alleviate poverty. Painkillers help alleviate headaches. These measures are designed to alleviate suffering. The medicine alleviates symptoms quickly.

topic vocab.meaning: to make something bad become worse, especially a situation or a medical condition (làm trầm trọng thêm)
topic vocab.example: His rude comments only aggravated the situation. The dust aggravated her asthma. Loud noises can aggravate my headache. His headache was aggravated by stress.

topic vocab.meaning: to achieve a better result than someone or something (vượt qua, vượt trội)
topic vocab.example: She bettered her previous exam score. The new team bettered last year's record. He hopes to better his personal best. Bradman’s average of 96 has never been bettered.

topic vocab.meaning: to improve something (cải thiện)
topic vocab.example: We must better our communication process. It’s an important step towards bettering relations. The city bettered its public transportation system. Efforts are being made to better the lives of workers.

topic vocab.meaning: a mark or spot that spoils the appearance of something (vết nhơ, vết xấu)
topic vocab.example: The mirror had a small blemish on its surface. The report was almost perfect except for one blemish. The painting was spoiled by a tiny blemish. His record has only one blemish: a late submission.

topic vocab.meaning: a situation in which everything is confused and in a mess (hỗn loạn)
topic vocab.example: There was chaos during the blackout. Chaos broke out after the announcement. The office was in chaos during the audit. His desk is always in a state of chaos.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone or something seem less valuable or respected (làm mất giá trị)
topic vocab.example: The scandal cheapened his reputation. These types of ads cheapen the brand. Don’t cheapen your work by rushing. This type of advertising cheapens the image of the brand.

topic vocab.meaning: to make a place or substance dirty or harmful by adding something unwanted (làm ô nhiễm)
topic vocab.example: The lake was contaminated by chemicals. Don’t contaminate the samples. One drop of bleach can contaminate the entire solution. Infection can contaminate the wound.

topic vocab.meaning: to be gradually destroyed as a result of natural process or lack of care (mục nát, suy tàn)
topic vocab.example: The wood began to decay after months of rain. Morals can decay without strong values. The abandoned house was slowly decaying. Without sunlight, your teeth may decay.

topic vocab.meaning: the gradual destruction of something as a result of natural process (sự mục nát, suy tàn)
topic vocab.example: Tooth decay can be prevented with proper hygiene. Urban decay affects many old cities. There’s been a moral decay in leadership. The paint showed signs of decay.

topic vocab.meaning: to become lower in amount or less in quality (giảm sút)
topic vocab.example: Sales declined in the third quarter. Attendance continues to decline. His health declined rapidly. The number of people attending has declined.

topic vocab.meaning: not working correctly or not made correctly (lỗi, bị lỗi)
topic vocab.example: The car was recalled due to defective brakes. The batch had several defective units. A defective product can be dangerous. They refunded me for the defective item.

topic vocab.meaning: harmful or damaging (có hại, bất lợi)
topic vocab.example: Too much screen time is detrimental to your eyes. Oversleeping may be detrimental to health. Pollution is detrimental to marine life. Sunlight can have a detrimental effect on skin.

topic vocab.meaning: to seriously damage or completely destroy something (tàn phá, phá hủy)
topic vocab.example: The earthquake devastated entire villages. War can devastate communities. Western India was devastated by a huge storm. The flood devastated local businesses.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone feel very shocked and upset (tàn phá về tinh thần)
topic vocab.example: The news devastated her. She was devastated by her dog’s disappearance. His sudden death devastated the team. The breakup devastated him emotionally.

topic vocab.meaning: to improve something, or make it more attractive or valuable (nâng cao, cải thiện)
topic vocab.example: They want to enhance the user experience. The new lighting enhances the mood. The course is designed to enhance your skills. The measures should enhance quality of life.

topic vocab.meaning: to think carefully about something before making a judgment (đánh giá)
topic vocab.example: We need to evaluate the risks before launching. She evaluated the pros and cons. The company evaluates performance every quarter. The performance of each employee is evaluated once a year.

topic vocab.meaning: to make a problem become worse (làm trầm trọng thêm)
topic vocab.example: The fire was exacerbated by the wind. His complaints only exacerbate the tension. Bad weather exacerbated the delay. Complaining will only exacerbate an already difficult situation.

topic vocab.meaning: extremely beautiful and delicate (tinh xảo)
topic vocab.example: She wore an exquisite silk dress. The artist created an exquisite sculpture. That’s an exquisite piece of jewelry. It was an exquisite hand-painted vase from China.

topic vocab.meaning: of the highest quality (hàng đầu, xuất sắc)
topic vocab.example: The hotel service was first-rate. She’s a first-rate designer. This is a first-rate opportunity for growth. The service is first-rate.

topic vocab.meaning: a mistake or fault in something that makes it useless, less effective or beautiful (lỗi, khuyết điểm)
topic vocab.example: There’s a flaw in the software design. Her logic had a major flaw. The mirror had no visible flaw. There are serious flaws in the way we train our teachers.

topic vocab.meaning: a complicated and annoying system of rules and processes (quan liêu)
topic vocab.example: I tried to start my own business but there was too much bureaucracy. The new policy created additional bureaucracy. Bureaucracy slows down decision-making. He's frustrated by the school bureaucracy.

topic vocab.meaning: an organisation to which you give money so it can help people in need (tổ chức từ thiện)
topic vocab.example: She donates to local charities every year. The charity supports homeless children. They set up a charity for disaster relief. There are one or two charities that I make regular donations to.

topic vocab.meaning: a group into which people in a society are divided based on family background, income, or education (giai cấp, tầng lớp)
topic vocab.example: My family are very middle class in a lot of ways. There’s a big gap between the rich and the working class. He moved up from the lower class. Education often reflects social class.

topic vocab.meaning: the people who live in an area (cộng đồng)
topic vocab.example: Politics should begin in the local community. She volunteers in her immigrant community. The school is central to the rural community. We need stronger ties in our online community.

topic vocab.meaning: to prove in court that someone is guilty of a crime (kết tội)
topic vocab.example: He was convicted of arson. The jury convicted her quickly. They were convicted despite weak evidence. A court must convict someone beyond doubt.

topic vocab.meaning: someone who is in prison because they committed a crime (tù nhân)
topic vocab.example: Two convicts have escaped from the local prison. The convict was transferred to maximum security. Former convicts often struggle to find work. The convict was granted parole.

topic vocab.meaning: dishonest or illegal behaviour by officials or people in power (sự tham nhũng)
topic vocab.example: They’ve started an investigation into corruption. Corruption in the police force was exposed. The government vowed to end corruption. Bribery is a common form of corruption.

topic vocab.meaning: something that makes people decide not to do something by making them realise that something unpleasant could happen to them (răn đe)
topic vocab.example: I think capital punishment serves as a deterrent. Alarm systems are a good deterrent to thieves. Fear of fines is a deterrent. Cameras act as a strong deterrent.

topic vocab.meaning: the art, buildings, and traditions that are important to a society’s culture and history (di sản)
topic vocab.example: It’s important that we preserve our national heritage. UNESCO protects world heritage sites. The museum showcases cultural heritage. We must protect our architectural heritage.

topic vocab.meaning: the process of people entering a country to live permanently (sự nhập cư)
topic vocab.example: Is the level of immigration actually rising, or is it falling? Immigration laws are often debated. Canada supports skilled immigration. Immigration affects the economy and housing.

topic vocab.meaning: a protest in which workers disagree with employer policy, often by striking (trừng phạt lao động)
topic vocab.example: Unless something changes, we’ll be taking industrial action. Teachers are threatening industrial action. The union voted for industrial action. Train workers announced new industrial action.

topic vocab.meaning: a large organisation like a bank, hospital, or prison (cơ quan, tổ chức)
topic vocab.example: It’s hard spending all your life inside an institution like a children’s home. The university is a respected institution. Mental health institutions need more funding. Banks are financial institutions.

topic vocab.meaning: a law or set of laws (pháp luật)
topic vocab.example: There is already legislation to prevent that. New legislation was passed yesterday. The minister proposed new legislation. Environmental legislation is now stricter.

topic vocab.meaning: an unreasonable opinion or feeling, especially dislike for people in a particular group (định kiến)
topic vocab.example: Many women have had to deal with prejudice in the workplace. We must fight racial prejudice. He was a victim of religious prejudice. Prejudice often stems from ignorance.

topic vocab.meaning: changes to make the prison system fairer or more effective (cải cách nhà tù)
topic vocab.example: I’m a great believer in prison reform. The minister proposed prison reform. Prison reform aims to reduce repeat offenses. Activists are calling for urgent prison reform.

topic vocab.meaning: having advantages and opportunities that other people do not have (được ưu tiên)
topic vocab.example: I suppose I come from quite a privileged background. He grew up in a privileged family. Privileged students get better access. She's aware of her privileged position.

topic vocab.meaning: to officially accuse someone of a crime in court (khởi tố)
topic vocab.example: The police decided not to prosecute and let him off with a warning. They prosecuted him for fraud. Few corporations are prosecuted for pollution. She was prosecuted for tax evasion.

topic vocab.meaning: the government of a country (nhà nước); also, a condition something is in (tình trạng)
topic vocab.example: The health system is the state’s responsibility. The building was in a poor state. He works for a state agency. Her mental state was concerning.

topic vocab.meaning: Strategic advantage or the power to act effectively. Also used in finance to describe investing with borrowed money to amplify potential returns. Đòn bẩy, lợi thế chiến lược.
topic vocab.example: The merger gave the company greater leverage in negotiating with international partners.

topic vocab.meaning: the trait of lacking restraint or control; reckless freedom from inhibition or worry a feeling of extreme emotional intensity forsake, leave behind give up with the intent of never claiming again leave behind empty; move out of stop maintaining or insisting on; of ideas or claims leave someone who needs or counts on you; leave in the lurch
topic vocab.example: We had to abandon the car. By the time the rebel troops arrived, the village had already been abandoned. As a baby he was abandoned by his mother.

topic vocab.meaning: very great; limitless resembling an abyss in depth; so deep as to be unmeasurable
topic vocab.example: His manners are abysmal. The council has an abysmal record on education.

topic vocab.meaning: extremely unpleasant and causing disgust  exceptionally bad or displeasing
topic vocab.example: The judge described the attack as an abominable crime. We were served the most abominable coffee. I think you are utterly selfish and your behaviour has been abominable.

topic vocab.meaning: expressing opinions or desires strongly and with confidence, so that people take notice; aggressively self-assured
topic vocab.example: You should try and be more assertive. assertive behaviour

topic vocab.meaning: - a strong feeling in favour of or against one group of people, or one side in an argument, often not based on fair judgement - showing an unreasonable like or dislike for a person based on personal opinions
topic vocab.example: Reporters must be impartial and not show political bias There was clear evidence of a strong bias against her Employers must consider all candidates impartially and without bias. biased information/sources/press reports a biased jury/witness The newspapers gave a very biased report of the meeting

topic vocab.meaning: the amount of money that is a profit or a loss after everything has been calculated
topic vocab.example: The bottom line for 2014 was profit of £85 million. How will the rise in interest rates affect our bottom line?

topic vocab.meaning: past events to be put aside well in the past; former happening or existing a long time ago.
topic vocab.example: a bygone age/era The family story was that, in bygone days, he had been a rich farmer in Australia. The horse and cart belongs to a bygone era.

topic vocab.meaning: someone's main reason for being well-known or famous.
topic vocab.example: This little town's chief claim to fame is that the president was born here. Her chief claim to fame is that she can recite the entire works of Shakespeare.

topic vocab.word: Subjects: Statistics; Visual arts; Philosophy; Politics; Performing arts; Logic
topic vocab.meaning: Statistics; Visual arts; Philosophy; Politics; Performing arts; Logic; Humanities; Business management; Archaeology; Agriculture. (Các môn học: Thống kê; Mỹ thuật; Triết học; Chính trị học; Nghệ thuật biểu diễn; Logic; Nhân văn; Quản trị kinh doanh; Khảo cổ học; Nông nghiệp)
