topic vocab.example: In her first year, she explored various subjects like Philosophy, Visual Arts, and Statistics to find her true interests.

topic vocab.meaning: noisy like the sound of a bee to befilled with noise and activity
topic vocab.example: When we arrived, the party was in full swing and the room was abuzz. The air was abuzz with military helicopters.

topic vocab.meaning: - the part of the body below the chest that contains the stomach, bowels, etc - connected with the the part of the body below the chest
topic vocab.example: abdominal pains

topic vocab.meaning: While you are speaking, many new ideas may come into your head. This is another good opportunity to show your communication skills. Here are some examples of expressions you can use to introduce new ideas in a natural, spontaneous way.
topic vocab.example: What else? Oh, yes, ... Another example just came to me. One more thing I’d just like to add. Another point I wanted to make is that ... I just remembered what I wanted to say. One more thing comes to mind (ADVANCED). One more thing springs to mind. (ADVANCED). Here are some examples of how these expressions can be used. In the examples, the candidate is talking about why she likes a particular

topic vocab.word: In order to achieve a very high band in the IELTS speaking test, you need to show that you can use some ‘less common’ vocabulary, including idioms and less common collocations. Let’s look at how you can say common sentences in a ‘less common’
topic vocab.meaning: Note on using idioms. Do not try to ‘show off’ to the examiner by using an idiom in every single sentence. Idioms should be used appropriately. Think of them like spices in a cooking recipe.
topic vocab.example: People in my country think that they are good singers, so they enjoy karaoke. People in my country regard themselves as being talented singers, so they enjoy karaoke. I was very happy when I got my exam results. I was over the moon when I got my exam results. We should try to produce fewer greenhouse gas emissions. We should try to reduce our carbon footprint. Some people in my country are very very poor. Some people in my country live below the breadline.

topic vocab.word: He would → He'd, Why have → Why've, I will → I'll, Where did → Where'd, They are → They're
topic vocab.meaning: Common English contractions formed by shortening auxiliary or modal verbs with pronouns. These are used frequently in spoken and informal written English. (Các dạng rút gọn thông dụng trong tiếng Anh dùng trong văn nói hoặc viết không trang trọng)
topic vocab.example: He'd like to see you now. Why've you come so early? I'll think about it. Where'd you get that jacket? They're already here.

topic vocab.word: some ‘less common’ vocabulary, including idioms and less common collocations.
topic vocab.meaning: Note on using idioms . Do not try to ‘show off’ to the examiner by using an idiom in every single sentence. Idioms should be used appropriately. Think of them like spices in a cooking recipe.
topic vocab.example: I think his reaction was a little exaggerated. I think his reaction was a little over the top. Although they played well, they lost the match. Even though they played well, they lost the match. In my country, if you are rich, you can do bad things and not get punished. In my country, if you are wealthy, you can get away with murder.

topic vocab.meaning: suitable or fitting for a particular purpose or situation.
topic vocab.example: This gift is appropriate for a birthday.   This is the appropriate moment to discuss our plans.

topic vocab.meaning: causing harm or damage.
topic vocab.example: Smoking is detrimental to health.   The chemicals in that product can be harmful.

topic vocab.meaning: unpleasant or unkind.
topic vocab.example: We had a dreadful holiday experience.   The service at that restaurant was really unpleasant.

topic vocab.meaning: providing or relating to beautiful views.
topic vocab.example: The village has picturesque and scenic views.   The view from the top of the mountain is breathtaking.

topic vocab.meaning: not allowed or prohibited.
topic vocab.example: Smoking is forbidden in this area.   The use of plastic bags has been banned.

topic vocab.meaning: pleasing or appealing to the senses, especially visually.
topic vocab.example: She is a gorgeous woman.   He is very good-looking.

topic vocab.meaning: extremely large in size or extent.
topic vocab.example: The project requires a substantial amount of resources.   The company has seen a substantial improvement in sales.

topic vocab.meaning: lacking interest or excitement; boring.
topic vocab.example: The book was uninspiring and dull.   The job was uninteresting and uninspiring.

topic vocab.meaning: characterized by intense activity, confusion, or busyness.
topic vocab.example: My job can be very busy and hectic at times.   The schedule was overloaded and hectic.

topic vocab.meaning: low in price; affordable.
topic vocab.example: Flats in my country are rather inexpensive these days.   The city offers a low-cost means of transport.

topic vocab.meaning: required by a rule, law, or obligation.
topic vocab.example: Using the Internet for research should be mandatory for students.   Attendance at the meeting is obligatory.

topic vocab.meaning: involving risk or danger.
topic vocab.example: Drinking too much alcohol can be hazardous to your health.

topic vocab.meaning: difficult to deal with or accomplish; requiring skill or caution.
topic vocab.example: Phrasal verbs can be quite tough.   That's a tricky question.

topic vocab.meaning: requiring little or no effort; easy.
topic vocab.example: The course was effortless.

topic vocab.meaning: giving pleasure or enjoyment.
topic vocab.example: The holiday was pleasurable.

topic vocab.meaning: causing excitement or interest; invigorating.
topic vocab.example: The experience was stimulating.

topic vocab.meaning: costing a lot of money; expensive.
topic vocab.example: New cars are very pricey.

topic vocab.meaning: available to be used because it is extra or not needed.
topic vocab.example: In my spare time, I enjoy hiking.

topic vocab.meaning: widely recognized or familiar.
topic vocab.example: The actor is well-known.

topic vocab.meaning: happening or moving quickly; fast.
topic vocab.example: The development of technology has been rapid.

topic vocab.meaning: liked or wanted more than others.
topic vocab.example: My preferred type of film is action.   Blue is my most-liked color.

topic vocab.meaning: If you want to check that you understood something correctly, you can
topic vocab.example: Do you mean …? Are you asking …? When you say …, do you mean …? By …, do you mean …? When you say …, are you including ...? When you say ‘family member’, do you mean my close family, or can I talk about my relatives? When you say ‘hometown’, do you mean the town where I grew up?; Do you find your work satisfying? Are you asking if I like my job? What is your favourite gadget? By ‘gadget’, do you mean things like iPhones and cameras?; What typical problems do you have in your hometown? When you say ‘typical problems’, are you including pollution, traffic, and things like that?

topic vocab.meaning: funny
topic vocab.example: I find the TV show very amusing / quite amusing

topic vocab.meaning: very funny
topic vocab.example: He is absolutely hilarious.

topic vocab.meaning: funny and clever
topic vocab.example: a witty person

topic vocab.meaning: good (enjoyable)
topic vocab.example: an enjoyable event; a pleasurable meal

topic vocab.meaning: another way of good (beneficial)
topic vocab.example: beneficial for the environment

topic vocab.meaning: healthy (food)
topic vocab.example: I try to eat wholesome food. a nutritious meal

topic vocab.meaning: helpful (ready to help)
topic vocab.example: a supportive work environment, ideal
a model boss; a perfect house

topic vocab.word: major, significant, essential, vital (= very important)
topic vocab.meaning: important
topic vocab.example: Computers are essential. a vital role

topic vocab.meaning: intelligent
topic vocab.example: a clever child a bright student; a smart businessman

topic vocab.meaning: interesting
topic vocab.example: a fascinating documentary

topic vocab.meaning: late (person)
topic vocab.example: Being tardy is considered to be a bad character trait in my country.

topic vocab.meaning: main
topic vocab.example: the principal industries

topic vocab.meaning: memorable
topic vocab.example: an unforgettable holiday

topic vocab.meaning: modern
topic vocab.example: I prefer contemporary buildings to old-fashioned ones.

topic vocab.meaning: negative
topic vocab.example: an undesirable impact on society.

topic vocab.meaning: old-fashioned
topic vocab.example: An outdated method of learning; unfashionable clothes

topic vocab.word: nutritious, wholesome I try to eat wholesome food.
topic vocab.meaning: healthy (food)
topic vocab.example: a nutritious meal

topic vocab.meaning: polite
topic vocab.example: a well-mannered person

topic vocab.meaning: poor
topic vocab.example: There are a lot of impoverished people in my country.

topic vocab.meaning: popular (belief)
topic vocab.example: a widespread opinion; a prevalent belief

topic vocab.meaning: popular (enjoyed by many people)
topic vocab.example: ‘Dancing with the Stars’ is a well-liked TV show in my country

topic vocab.meaning: positive (impact)
topic vocab.example: I think technology has had a constructive impact on society.

topic vocab.meaning: on time
topic vocab.example: Being on time is considered to be a positive character trait.

topic vocab.meaning: rich
topic vocab.example: People in my country are becoming wealthier.

topic vocab.meaning: safe
topic vocab.example: My neighbourhood is very secure.

topic vocab.meaning: special
topic vocab.example: My city is well-known for its distinctive architecture.

topic vocab.meaning: successful
topic vocab.example: a prosperous business

topic vocab.meaning: traditional (use)
topic vocab.example: The conventional use of a mobile phone is to make calls and send text messages.

topic vocab.meaning: typical (dish, name)
topic vocab.example: A characteristic dish in my country is chicken madras.

topic vocab.meaning: useful
topic vocab.example: Shopping online is very convenient

topic vocab.meaning: positive (impact)
topic vocab.example: I think technology has had a constructive impact on society.

topic vocab.meaning: A LAWNMOWER
topic vocab.example: I don’t know what you call it, but you use it to cut grass.

topic vocab.meaning: A REMOTE CONTROL
topic vocab.example: I can’t remember the word for it, but it’s used for changing the TV channel.

topic vocab.meaning: GOGGLES
topic vocab.example: I can’t remember the word for them, but they help you to see under water.

topic vocab.meaning: SALMON
topic vocab.example: I’ve forgotten the name for it, but it’s a type of fish with red meat and is normally quite expensive.

topic vocab.meaning: A FLIGHT ATTENDANT
topic vocab.example: I don’t recall the word for this profession, but it’s a person who helps passengers on a plane.

topic vocab.meaning: DYE
topic vocab.example: I’ve forgotten the verb, but it’s when you change the colour of something, for example your hair or your car.

topic vocab.meaning: EMBEZZLEMENT
topic vocab.example: The name of this crime is on the tip of my tongue but I can’t quite recall it. It’s a form of crime where someone dishonestly takes money that is entrusted to him or her.

topic vocab.meaning: ASTHMA
topic vocab.example: The name of this condition has completely slipped my mind. It’s when you have problems breathing.

topic vocab.meaning: AN OWL
topic vocab.example: I’ve never come across the name of this animal in English. It’s a nocturnal bird with large eyes, a flat face and a flexible neck.”

topic vocab.meaning: If the examiner uses a word or phrase that you didn’t understand or that you have forgotten, for example the verb exaggerate, you can say something
topic vocab.example: Sorry, but could you explain what you mean by exaggerate? I haven’t heard that word before. Could you explain what you mean? Sorry, I’m not sure what that word means. Could you explain it another way? Sorry, I don’t know what exaggerate means. Could you explain it another way? Sorry, I’ve forgotten what exaggerate means. Could you explain it another way?

topic vocab.meaning: If you simply didn’t hear what the examiner said or asked, you can say something
topic vocab.example: Excuse me, I didn't quite catch that. Could you say it again? Sorry, I didn’t hear what you said. Could you repeat it? I'm sorry, but would you mind repeating that? (MORE POLITE)

topic vocab.meaning: In Part 3 of the IELTS speaking test, you will be asked a question related to the topic of Part 2, and you might need more time to think than you did in Part 1. Simple conversation fillers might not be enough to buy yourself the time that you need before answering the question. Here are some more effective techniques.
topic vocab.example: Repeat the question - When the examiner asks the question, try to repeat it in your own

topic vocab.meaning: If you ask yourself a direct question, you need to use standard question word
topic vocab.example: How popular is TV in my country? – How do I like to spend my free time?

topic vocab.meaning: Another way to give yourself extra time to think about your response is simply to ask for time. This is a technique that everybody uses in normal conversation.
topic vocab.example: Interesting question. Can I think about it for a minute? ; Okay, that’s a difficult question. Can you give me a moment to think about it?; Hmm...good question. Can I have a little time to think about it?; If you are aiming for a very high band, you can consider using the following expressions; That’s an interesting question. Can I dwell on it for a moment?; Okay, that’s a tricky question. I just need a moment to think it over; Okay, that’s a tricky question. I just need a moment to ponder over it.

topic vocab.meaning: If you still need a few extra seconds after using the above expressions, you can begin your response with a suitable conversation filler.
topic vocab.example: Well, I guess I would say that television is extremely popular’ Hmm....I suppose that train travel is the most common form of transport; Well, umm, basically I think that sport can help us to live a much healthier lifestyle.

topic vocab.meaning: In order to buy yourself the maximum time that you need, consider all three approaches
topic vocab.example: What different types of food do people eat in your country?-- Hmm....so you would like to know the different types of food that people eat in my country. Hmm...interesting question. Can I think about it for a moment? Well, I guess traditional Polish cuisine is still very popular.

topic vocab.meaning: In Part 2 and 3 of the IELTS speaking test, you will need to speak at length about a particular issue. In order to get a high band, it is important to develop your ideas using appropriate connecting words and phrases. Imagine the examiner asks if you would prefer to live in a big or small city. Study how the connecting words/phrases in bold are used in the answer below.
topic vocab.example: Well, I think on the whole I’d prefer to live in a big city. Firstly, there are more job opportunities. On top of that, the standard of living is higher and the infrastructure is more developed. Also, there are more places to go shopping. In short, there are lots of advantages. On the other hand, I think there are several important drawbacks. First of all, big cities tend to be more polluted because of all the cars. Secondly, there is more noise. Regarding transport, big cities can be very stressful. For example, my home city Moscow has a very crowded metro system. In fact, it’s one of the most stressful metro systems in the world. However, despite those disadvantages, I’d still prefer to live in a big city.

topic vocab.meaning: Talking in general
topic vocab.example: I think on the whole I’d prefer to live in a big city.

topic vocab.meaning: Introducing a topic
topic vocab.example: Regarding transport, big cities can be very stressful.

topic vocab.meaning: Listing different points Firstly, First of all, Secondly,
topic vocab.example: On top of that, the standard of living is higher and the infrastructure is more developed.

topic vocab.word: On the other hand, However, Despite (those disadvantages),
topic vocab.meaning: Introducing a contrast
topic vocab.example: However, despite those disadvantages, I’d still prefer to live in a big city.

topic vocab.meaning: Modifying a previous statement
topic vocab.example: In fact, it’s one of the most stressful metro systems in the world.

topic vocab.meaning: Summarizing
topic vocab.example: In short, there are lots of advantages.

topic vocab.meaning: Use well to introduce a remark or give yourself time to think.
topic vocab.example: Who is my favourite family member? Well, I need to think about that one.

topic vocab.meaning: Use so or therefore to introduce a logical result. So is more informal than therefore.
topic vocab.example: Living in a big city has lots of advantages. Therefore, I’d prefer to live there. Living in a big city has lots of advantages. So I’d prefer to live there.

topic vocab.meaning: Use basically to introduce the most important aspect of something. It is very common - in spoken English (don’t use it in formal writing) and often used as a conversation filler.
topic vocab.example: Basically, there are three reasons why I’d like to live in a big city.

topic vocab.meaning: Use however or yet to make a contrast.
topic vocab.example: I agree with that opinion. However, I don’t know if it will be true in the future. I agree with that opinion. Yet I don’t know if it will be true in the future.

topic vocab.meaning: Though is used to make a contrast. It normally goes at the end of the sentence.
topic vocab.example: Living in a big city has lots of advantages. I’d still prefer to live in a small town, though.

topic vocab.meaning: Use in other words to simplify or summarize what you just said before.
topic vocab.example: In big cities, there are more offices and shops. In other words, there is more work.

topic vocab.meaning: Use If we’re talking ... to introduce a new topic.
topic vocab.example: If we’re talking shopping and entertainment, I’d prefer to live in a big city.

topic vocab.meaning: We use as far as something is concerned when we introduce a new topic. It is a little more formal than If we’re talking ...
topic vocab.example: As far as shopping is concerned, it is much better to live in a big city than a small town.

topic vocab.meaning: Use eventually to say what happens after a long time and/or many problems. The meaning is similar to in the end.
topic vocab.example: We drove for two hours trying to find the hotel. Eventually, we gave up and decided to stay at a hostel.

topic vocab.meaning: Use on top of that or what’s more to introduce an additional point.
topic vocab.example: The hotel was awful. On top of that, the weather was cold and wet. The hotel was awful. What’s more, the weather was cold and wet. These connectors are more informal than in addition, furthermore and moreover, so don’t use them in formal writing.

topic vocab.meaning: Use anyway or anyhow to confirm or support a point or idea just mentioned in a conversation.
topic vocab.example: When I was in Italy, I didn’t have time to go for a pizza. Anyway, I don’t really like pizza. You can also use anyway or anyhow to return to something you were talking about before the subject was changed. Anyhow, we finally found a mechanic to fix our car.

topic vocab.meaning: Use 'actually' to give an unexpected or surprising response. (Thực ra, thực tế là – dùng để diễn tả điều bất ngờ hoặc trái ngược với dự đoán.)
topic vocab.example: I thought he was unfriendly, but actually he’s very kind once you get to know him.

topic vocab.meaning: Use in fact to modify a previous statement, for example if you said something that is slightly inaccurate and you want to be more precise.
topic vocab.example: I used to get up at 7am. In fact, it was around 6.30. You can also use

topic vocab.word: to cut a long story short
topic vocab.meaning: Use the idiom to cut a long story short (American
topic vocab.example: To cut a long story short, I arrived home after midnight.

topic vocab.meaning: Use on the whole or in general to make a general statement.
topic vocab.example: On the whole, I think the food in my country is healthy. In general, I think the food in my country is healthy.

topic vocab.meaning: Use overall to make a final concluding statement.
topic vocab.example: Overall, it was a fantastic holiday. You can also

topic vocab.meaning: Use for example or for instance to give an example.
topic vocab.example: Big cities have more developed public transport. For instance, in my city there are trams, metro systems, buses and trains.

topic vocab.meaning: You can use alternatively to provide an alternative idea.
topic vocab.example: In my town, you can get to the city centre by tram. Alternatively, you can take the bus.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to or denoting the later part of the Stone Age, characterized by the development of agriculture and the use of polished stone tools.
topic vocab.example: The Neolithic period marked a significant shift in human civilization, with the emergence of settled communities and the domestication of plants and animals.

topic vocab.meaning: a type of igneous rock, often blue-gray in color, used in the construction of Stonehenge and believed to have been transported from the Preseli Hills in Wales.
topic vocab.example: The bluestones at Stonehenge are believed to have been brought from Wales over a distance of 300 kilometers.

topic vocab.meaning: to pull or drag with effort or force, especially over a distance.
topic vocab.example: The prehistoric builders had to haul the massive stones of Stonehenge over a great distance using primitive tools and techniques.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to or denoting the period before written records.
topic vocab.example: Prehistoric humans relied on stone tools for hunting and survival.

topic vocab.meaning: having, revealing, or involving a great deal of worldly experience and knowledge of fashion and culture.
topic vocab.example: The ancient Egyptians had a sophisticated understanding of astronomy.

topic vocab.meaning: a large rock, typically one that has been worn smooth by erosion.
topic vocab.example: The landscape was scattered with massive boulders left behind by ancient glaciers.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to an early stage of development or existence; characterized by simplicity or a lack of sophistication.
topic vocab.example: The primitive tools used by early humans were made from stone, bone, and wood.

topic vocab.meaning: wood that has been prepared for use in building or carpentry.
topic vocab.example: The ancient structure was constructed using large timber beams and supports.

topic vocab.meaning: the branched horns that grow on the heads of deer, typically shed and regrown annually.
topic vocab.example: The ancient hunters used deer antlers as tools for various purposes, such as digging and crafting.

topic vocab.meaning: a long narrow trench or channel dug in the ground, typically used for drainage or as a boundary marker.
topic vocab.example: The Neolithic Britons dug a massive circular ditch as part of the construction of Stonehenge.

topic vocab.meaning: a long raised mound or ridge of earth, often serving as a barrier or support.
topic vocab.example: The circular bank surrounding Stonehenge provided structural stability to the monument.

topic vocab.meaning: a prehistoric monument consisting of a circular or oval-shaped bank and ditch with an internal or external stone circle.
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge is one of the most famous examples of a henge in the world.

topic vocab.meaning: deep holes or cavities in the ground, often used for storage or as a means of construction.
topic vocab.example: The pits within the Stonehenge circle may have once held timber posts.

topic vocab.meaning: people who have studied a subject in depth and are considered experts or authorities in that field.
topic vocab.example: Scholars have debated the purpose and significance of Stonehenge for centuries.

topic vocab.meaning: a person who studies or collects antiques or ancient artifacts.
topic vocab.example: William Stukeley was an antiquarian who made significant contributions to the study of Stonehenge.

topic vocab.meaning: originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
topic vocab.example: The Neolithic agrarians were likely to have been indigenous to the British Isles.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to astrology, the study of the movements and positions of celestial bodies and their influence on human affairs and natural events.
topic vocab.example: Gerald Hawkins proposed an astrological interpretation of Stonehenge, suggesting it served as a calendar.

topic vocab.meaning: having the ability to cure or heal; therapeutic.
topic vocab.example: The bluestones at Stonehenge were believed to possess curative powers.

topic vocab.meaning: an era in human history, also known as the Neolithic period, characterized by the development of agriculture, domestication of animals, and the use of polished stone tools.
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge was constructed during the New Stone Age.

topic vocab.meaning: a period in human history characterized by the widespread use of iron tools and weapons.
topic vocab.example: The Celts inhabited the region during the Iron Age.

topic vocab.meaning: a proposed explanation or theory based on limited evidence, intended to be tested and further investigated.
topic vocab.example: Archaeologists have put forward various hypotheses regarding the construction methods of Stonehenge.

topic vocab.meaning: a general agreement among a group of people, typically reached through discussion or compromise.
topic vocab.example: There is a consensus among modern scholars that Stonehenge served as a burial ground.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to or characteristic of a megalith, which is a large stone used in prehistoric construction.
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge is a famous example of megalithic architecture.

topic vocab.meaning: a person who studies human history and prehistory through the excavation of artifacts, structures, and other physical remains.
topic vocab.example: Archaeologists have been studying Stonehenge for centuries to uncover its mysteries.

topic vocab.meaning: a method used to determine the age of organic materials by measuring the decay of radioactive carbon isotopes.
topic vocab.example: Radiocarbon dating has provided valuable insights into the timeline of Stonehenge's construction.

topic vocab.meaning: having doubts or reservations; inclined to question or doubt accepted opinions or beliefs
topic vocab.example: Most archaeologists remained sceptical about the theory of glaciers transporting the bluestones to Stonehenge.

topic vocab.meaning: objects made by humans, typically of historical or cultural interest
topic vocab.example: Bones, tools, and other artifacts found at the Stonehenge site provide insights into its construction and purpose.

topic vocab.meaning: shared by all members of a community; for common use
topic vocab.example: Groups with a more communal way of life likely contributed to the construction of Stonehenge.

topic vocab.meaning: having a specified ancestor or ancestry
topic vocab.example: Some believe that the later builders of Stonehenge were descended from the original builders.

topic vocab.meaning: a thick layer of clouds that obscures visibility
topic vocab.example: Critics argue that England's dense cloud cover would have hindered the view of the skies for Stonehenge's builders.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to astronomy, the study of celestial objects and phenomena
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge is believed to have had an astronomical purpose, aligning with celestial events.

topic vocab.meaning: large single stones or structures made from a single piece of material
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge is composed of several monoliths, some weighing over 25 tons.

topic vocab.meaning: a religious or solemn ceremony consisting of a series of actions performed according to a prescribed order
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge is thought to have been a site for religious or ritualistic practices.

topic vocab.meaning: difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge's purpose remains enigmatic, captivating researchers and visitors alike.

topic vocab.meaning: natural objects in the sky, such as stars, planets, and moons
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge may have been used to track the movements of celestial bodies.

topic vocab.meaning: the positioning of celestial objects in relation to specific points or structures on Earth
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge is renowned for its astronomical alignments, particularly during solstices and equinoxes.

topic vocab.meaning: a culture or society characterized by the construction and use of megaliths
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge is an iconic symbol of the megalithic culture that existed during the Neolithic period.

topic vocab.meaning: a location or structure used for observing celestial objects and phenomena
topic vocab.example: Some researchers propose that Stonehenge served as an astronomical observatory for ancient astronomers.

topic vocab.meaning: the importance or meaning attributed to something in relation to a particular culture or society
topic vocab.example: Stonehenge holds great cultural significance as a symbol of ancient British heritage.

topic vocab.meaning: a typical example or pattern of something; a model or framework
topic vocab.example: The discovery of DNA's structure shifted the scientific paradigm of genetics.

topic vocab.meaning: present, appearing, or found everywhere
topic vocab.example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

topic vocab.meaning: a division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different
topic vocab.example: There is often a dichotomy between theory and practice in many fields.

topic vocab.meaning: a confusing or difficult problem or question; a dilemma
topic vocab.example: Solving the mystery of the Bermuda Triangle remains a conundrum for researchers.

topic vocab.meaning: the mental discomfort or tension experienced when holding two or more contradictory beliefs, ideas, or values
topic vocab.example: People may experience cognitive dissonance when their actions contradict their personal beliefs.

topic vocab.meaning: based on or involving conjecture; speculativeWord
topic vocab.example: The theories about Stonehenge's construction are largely conjectural, as there is limited historical evidence.Word

topic vocab.meaning: Whether people know a brand, how famous a brand is.
topic vocab.example: This advertising campaign is designed to raise our brand awareness by 50%.

topic vocab.meaning: Control someone without them knowing they are being controlled.
topic vocab.example: Children can be easily manipulated into desiring certain products.

topic vocab.meaning: The group of people a company wants as its customers.
topic vocab.example: Once a company identifies their target audience, they can design more specific advertisements for them.

topic vocab.meaning: A message in an advertisement that encourages the viewer to do something e.g. make a purchase.
topic vocab.example: Advertisements that include an effective call to action are much more likely to attract new customers.

topic vocab.meaning: The 2-3 minutes of TV advertisements before/during a TV show.
topic vocab.example: Many people change channels during the commercial break.

topic vocab.meaning: A type of natural advertising where people recommend things they like to their friends, without any hope of reward.
topic vocab.example: Smaller companies like family restaurants often rely on word of mouth to bring in new customers.

topic vocab.meaning: Type of advertising showing products being used in media (movies, TV shows, videos)
topic vocab.example: Many movies supplement their budgets by allowing subtle, or in some cases blatant, product placement.

topic vocab.meaning: The short song or piece of music included in an advertisement to make it catchy.
topic vocab.example: Memorable jingles, like the one featured by McDonald’s, are an important part of making an advertisement effective.

topic vocab.meaning: The short set of words used by a company in its advertisement. For example, ‘Just do it’ from Nike.
topic vocab.example: While an effective or distinctive slogan can set a company apart, a meaningless slogan can actively damage the brand.

topic vocab.meaning: Getting public approval of a product, usually from a famous person.
topic vocab.example: Using a celebrity endorsement can be a very powerful form of advertising.

topic vocab.meaning: Animal that eats meat
topic vocab.example: Tigers are known as fearsome carnivores.

topic vocab.meaning: Animal that eats plants
topic vocab.example: Herbivores, like zebra, tend to move in large groups for safety.

topic vocab.meaning: Changed over time from being wild animal to human service animal e.g. pig, dog.
topic vocab.example: Domesticated animals, such as dogs, have completely different behaviour patterns to wild animals.

topic vocab.meaning: 1) Illegally hunt wild animals, 2) Take something from a rival/competitor
topic vocab.example: Illegal poaching remains a huge threat to endangered animals like rhinos.

topic vocab.meaning: An animal’s area of control
topic vocab.example: Wild animals can be aggressive when defending their territory.

topic vocab.meaning: Having children, continuing the generations of animal (or person).
topic vocab.example: It is often hard for wild animals like pandas to reproduce in captivity.

topic vocab.meaning: A carnivore at the top of its food chain, without natural predators of its own.
topic vocab.example: Apex predators like great white sharks are an important part of maintaining a balanced ecosystem.

topic vocab.meaning: Travel long distances on a regular basis (e.g. yearly) for a specific purpose, often at a fixed time of the year.
topic vocab.example: Many types of birds in the northern hemisphere migrate southwards in the winter.

topic vocab.meaning: Few of this animal left, in danger of going extinct.
topic vocab.example: The protection of endangered species is one reason why we should keep zoos open.

topic vocab.meaning: Dangerous, willing to fight or attack.
topic vocab.example: Sometimes pet dogs can be aggressive towards strangers, but mostly they are fairly docile and even friendly. 1. Dogs can get very territorial when a new dog or person enters their home. They will often bark or display other signs of aggression. 2. Even though the poaching of elephants for their tusks is illegal in most countries, it is still very common. 3. Carnivorous birds like eagles and hawks are often known as birds of prey. 4. Before dogs were domesticated, they were much closer in behaviour and appearance to wolves. 5. All of the common animals that humans eat, like cows, chickens and pigs, are herbivores.

topic vocab.meaning: The person (or job title of someone) who designs buildings.
topic vocab.example: I am more interested in the work of classical architecture rather than the work of contemporary architects.

topic vocab.meaning: Something that causes strong feelings in both positive and negative ways. For example, a building that some people love but other people hate.
topic vocab.example: The decision to demolish the original town hall and replace it with a steel and glass alternative was highly controversial.

topic vocab.meaning: A building, piece of art or something else visual that is considered very unattractive.
topic vocab.example: The new steel and glass town hall is a real eyesore!

topic vocab.meaning: To tear down a building, either for safety, to replace it or just because it is old.
topic vocab.example: When the old, unsightly prison on the outskirts of the city was demolished, a great cheer went up amongst the local residents.

topic vocab.meaning: The right, usually given by the local government, to construct a building in a specific location.
topic vocab.example: Now that property developers have to apply for planning permission before beginning construction, the local government can better control the appearance of the local area.

topic vocab.meaning: A classic, elaborate style of architecture from Europe, most popular between the 12th and 16th Century. Examples include Notre Dame cathedral in Paris.
topic vocab.example: I loved exploring the gothic cathedrals when I went to Paris.

topic vocab.meaning: A type of architecture with heavy use of geometric shapes. A famous example is the Sydney Opera House.
topic vocab.example: While I do enjoy some modernist architecture, I find some of it a bit unsightly.

topic vocab.word: Sticks out like a sore thumb (idiom, verb)
topic vocab.meaning: Something that is very obviously different, often in a bad way, compared to the things around it.
topic vocab.example: I can’t believe the government gave them planning permission. That futuristic building sticks out like a sore thumb amongst the gothic architecture all around it.

topic vocab.meaning: A type of architecture that tries to do something new, either visually or functionally (or both). Examples are ‘vertical forests’ or the Jeddah tower in Saudi Arabia.
topic vocab.example: I prefer classical architecture in general, although I must admit that I find some futuristic buildings quite inspiring.

topic vocab.meaning: Something widely recognized or famous, and usually admired by people. Often is an example of a particular style.
topic vocab.example: Part of my plan for visiting any city is to check out any iconic buildings they have.

topic vocab.meaning: Type of art that doesn’t show the literal object. It uses shapes, colors and other techniques to achieve an effect.
topic vocab.example: I’m more interested in abstract art than more photorealistic work.

topic vocab.meaning: A type of paint or painting style that is based in water rather than oil. Often used for soft, translucent artwork. (Màu nước hoặc tranh màu nước, dùng nước làm dung môi thay vì dầu)
topic vocab.example: She painted a beautiful watercolour landscape of the mountains at sunset.

topic vocab.meaning: A work of art produced by shaping a material e.g. clay, stone, wood, metal.
topic vocab.example: I took sculpture classes in college but I never sculpt these days.

topic vocab.meaning: A type of painting depicting an inanimate object e.g. flowers, books
topic vocab.example: The guide at the art gallery showed me an amazing still life called Vase with Fifteen Sunflowers by Van Gogh.

topic vocab.meaning: A very high-quality piece of art that is praised by the public, and/or usually is an artist’s best work.
topic vocab.example: Although the Mona Lisa has been hailed as a masterpiece, Leonardo da Vinci didn’t consider it his finest piece of work.

topic vocab.meaning: Represent a person/animal/object in a piece of art.
topic vocab.example: In her paintings, she often depicts scenes of strong human emotion.

topic vocab.meaning: Very hard to understand or enjoy.
topic vocab.example: I must admit that I find a lot of abstract art completely impenetrable.

topic vocab.meaning: The meaning that a person gets from something e.g. a piece of art.
topic vocab.example: While I agree that there can be more than one interpretation of this piece of work, my interpretation of it is that it shows the struggles of life.

topic vocab.meaning: Skills related to using hands and fingers in a specific way.
topic vocab.example: Studying art is a great way for children to develop fine motor skills.

topic vocab.meaning: To be creative and try to create new things/ideas.
topic vocab.example: Parents should offer praise to children when they are being innovative, in order to encourage the same behaviour in the future.

topic vocab.meaning: A situation when lots of people are paying attention to one person.
topic vocab.example: I liked being the center of attention at my birthday parties, because everyone had to do what I wanted!

topic vocab.meaning: To reach or pass a certain age.
topic vocab.example: I remember having a great birthday party when I turned 11.

topic vocab.meaning: The person (usually child) who is celebrating their birthday.
topic vocab.example: These days, the birthday girl or boy will receive all kinds of gifts from different people.

topic vocab.meaning: Describes an event that has few people or a low level of noise, excitement or expense.
topic vocab.example: These days, I still celebrate my birthday but I prefer to keep it a bit more low-key than when I was in my 20s!

topic vocab.meaning: To cover something (usually a gift) in paper. Often brightly coloured or attractive paper.
topic vocab.example: My parents always gave me a gift that was beautifully wrapped in bright blue wrapping paper, and I found it so exciting!

topic vocab.meaning: A party that the centre of attention (e.g. the birthday girl) didn’t know was happening.
topic vocab.example: My friends organized a surprise party for me when I turned 18.

topic vocab.meaning: A small party or event where several people (usually less than 20) come together to celebrate something.
topic vocab.example: These days, I tend to have a little get-together with some close friends to celebrate my birthday.

topic vocab.meaning: To make something (a cake, a house) look attractive by adding some extra items.
topic vocab.example: For my birthday, my parents would always decorate the apartment with balloons and a huge banner saying ‘Happy Birthday!’

topic vocab.meaning: A tradition where the birthday boy/girl makes a secret wish in their head before blowing out the candles on the birthday cake.
topic vocab.example: I remember that my parents could always guess what I had made my birthday wish about. I don’t know how they always knew!

topic vocab.meaning: A tradition where the birthday boy/girl is the only person who can use their mouth to blow out the candles on top of a birthday cake.
topic vocab.example: Blowing out the candles was always my favorite part of my birthday when I was young.

topic vocab.meaning: The quality level of a product compared to its price. Technically is neutral, but ‘value for money’ is often used to mean ‘good value for money’. Synonyms (good value for money): Good value; Reasonable; Worth the money (both adjectives) Synonyms (bad value for money): Overpriced;
topic vocab.example: If a company offers exceptional value for money, they are likely to have plenty of customers.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who starts or has started new companies.
topic vocab.example: Visionary entrepreneurs like Jack Ma and Elon Musk have the power to change the world.

topic vocab.meaning: A company’s profit (the money they make after costs are removed).
topic vocab.example: Companies which only focus on their bottom line often ignore their ethical and community responsibilities.

topic vocab.meaning: To earn money for a company. Note – not the same as earning a salary for an individual. Also not the same as making a profit.
topic vocab.example: New companies usually have to start generating revenue early on in order to be successful.

topic vocab.word: Cut-throat (adjective). Note – sometimes written as cutthroat.
topic vocab.meaning: A ruthless, fierce, intense situation.
topic vocab.example: Some people enjoy the challenge of working in a cut throat culture, whereas others prefer a more relaxed and compassionate environment.

topic vocab.meaning: To reduce the amount of money a company (or person) spends.
topic vocab.example: Many managers are under pressure to cut costs by making workers redundant.

topic vocab.meaning: Legal restrictions that a company faces e.g. not polluting the local area, or inside a company e.g. coming to work on time.
topic vocab.example: The government can help companies to grow by reducing rules and regulations.

topic vocab.meaning: A large company with operations in many countries.
topic vocab.example: Multinational corporations have a big responsibility to treat their employees well and protect the local areas in which they operate.

topic vocab.meaning: A new company, often (but not always) associated with technology. Generally assumed to have the ability to grow quickly.
topic vocab.example: People who work for fast-growing start-ups are often extremely busy, but the rewards could be enormous.

topic vocab.meaning: A special characteristic of a company/product that can make it successful.
topic vocab.example: JingDong’s unique selling point is that they promise to deliver products the same day that the customer buys them.

topic vocab.meaning: To allow people to break the rules without punishment, or avoid giving people strict rules.
topic vocab.example: I think modern parents are often too lenient with their children.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who usually follows the rules.
topic vocab.example: I was always very obedient as a child, whereas my sister was a lot more rebellious than me.

topic vocab.word: To get away with something (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: To avoid being punished for something wrong.
topic vocab.example: My sister could get away with murder when we were growing up, but I was constantly getting caught red-handed.

topic vocab.meaning: A child that doesn’t have siblings (brothers or sisters)
topic vocab.example: Someone who grows up as an only child is more likely to be spoilt.

topic vocab.word: To raise someone to be (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: To raise children in a specific way, usually a positive meaning.
topic vocab.example: My parents raised me to be always polite and respectful with strangers.

topic vocab.meaning: Lose contact with someone gradually, over a long period of time.
topic vocab.example: My friend Paul and I were great friends in high school, but we drifted apart after going to different universities.

topic vocab.word: To look up to someone (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: To admire someone, usually older. Mostly used by children or young adults.
topic vocab.example: Children look up to their parents and often follow in their footsteps.

topic vocab.word: To follow in someone’s footsteps (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: To do the same thing as someone did before, usually related to jobs or studies.
topic vocab.example: My mother is an artist, and when I was young, I wanted to follow in her footsteps.

topic vocab.word: To go through a ____ phase (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: Be very interested in something for a limited period of time, usually when young.
topic vocab.example: I remember that I went through a dinosaur phase when I was about seven years old.

topic vocab.meaning: The way that a child is raised.
topic vocab.example: Behavioural problems suffered by adults are often the result of a difficult upbringing.

topic vocab.meaning: A collection of clothes worn together at one time.
topic vocab.example: I generally spend a long time choosing my outfit before going to see my friends.

topic vocab.meaning: To put on one’s best clothes, often for a special occasion.
topic vocab.example: I very rarely get dressed up during the summer – most of the time, I just throw something on when I’m leaving the house.

topic vocab.meaning: To be dressed in an appropriate way, usually including wearing neat, clean clothes.
topic vocab.example: We can certainly learn about a person’s character from whether they usually make themselves presentable or generally turn up looking dishevelled.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who follows fashion and pays careful attention to their appearance, usually wearing the latest styles.
topic vocab.example: I’m certainly no fashionista, but I do like to make myself presentable.

topic vocab.meaning: The rules of what to wear at an event, including weddings, or in an organisation, including schools and companies.
topic vocab.example: Traditional events, including weddings and funerals, tend to have a strict dress code in my country.

topic vocab.meaning: A type of clothing style or dress code that includes both smart and comfortable clothes. Neat and tidy but not too formal. Example – wearing a shirt and jeans.
topic vocab.example: Modern companies often choose a smart-casual dress code rather than making their employees dress very formally every day.

topic vocab.meaning: Small items that people wear, including bracelets, rings, and bags.
topic vocab.example: I try to find the perfect accessories to go with my outfit.

topic vocab.meaning: A heterosexual man who enjoys shopping, fashion and grooming.
topic vocab.example: Many men these days are considered to be metrosexuals, given their strong interest in fashion and grooming.

topic vocab.meaning: Comfortable clothes that are informal, and often worn around the house or for doing exercise.
topic vocab.example: I wouldn’t go out in leisure wear, but I wear it all the time at home.

topic vocab.meaning: From a famous/expensive brand, either of clothing or accessories.
topic vocab.example: I would love to buy designer clothes but, sadly, they are usually out of my price range.

topic vocab.meaning: To have a long, informal (and probably unimportant) conversation with someone close e.g. friend, family, colleague, classmate.
topic vocab.example: I spend most of every Sunday chewing the fat with my friends.

topic vocab.meaning: To talk in a way that avoids getting to the point or crucial information. Often used in the negative.
topic vocab.example: My old boss was a very direct communicator – he never beat around the bush, and he didn’t accept other people beating around the bush either!

topic vocab.meaning: An attitude or way of speaking that is direct and aggressive.
topic vocab.example: His confrontational style is often a little too direct for his colleagues.

topic vocab.meaning: Aggressive and direct manner of communicating or behaving.
topic vocab.example: My style of leadership could definitely be described as in your face.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who is aggressive or confrontational in an indirect way. Example – Person A dislikes your idea, but doesn’t say it out loud. Instead, they say that they agree with it, but then work against your idea (e.g. by arriving late or deliberately failing to complete tasks)
topic vocab.example: I hate dealing with Sarah – she is always so passive aggressive.

topic vocab.meaning: To meet someone after a period of time apart, and talk with them about what has happened since the last meeting. Usually used by friends/family, but can also be in business.
topic vocab.example: I try to find time for a catch-up with my old high-school friends whenever I visit my hometown.

topic vocab.meaning: A relationship between two people. Can be family/friends/colleagues/other situations. Usually used in plural to describe someone’s relationships in general.
topic vocab.example: Communication is a critical tool in managing and improving your interpersonal relationships.

topic vocab.meaning: The use of physical signs and signals as a form of communication. Can be deliberate or unintentional.
topic vocab.example: He said that he agreed with the idea, but I could tell from his body language that he was disappointed.

topic vocab.word: Drop someone a line (phrasal verb, informal)
topic vocab.meaning: To contact someone, often after a period of no contact (or for the first time)
topic vocab.example: I like to keep in touch with my old friends, so I try to drop them a line whenever I have free time.

topic vocab.word: Shoot someone a message (phrasal verb, informal)
topic vocab.meaning: Send a message to someone (by email or social media). Usually done casually or quickly, without lots of planning.
topic vocab.example: When I drive home after seeing my parents, I usually shoot them a message on WhatsApp to let them know that I got home safe.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who chooses what they eat very carefully and doesn’t like/won’t eat a lot of different food types.
topic vocab.example: I’m not a fussy eater at all – I’ll eat anything!

topic vocab.meaning: A selection of skills that someone has, for example in which dishes they can cook.
topic vocab.example: I like cooking but I have a pretty limited repertoire of dishes that I can cook.

topic vocab.meaning: A meal prepared by the manufacturer and sold with only reheating needed before eating.
topic vocab.example: Many people don’t have the energy to cook their dinner from scratch, and choose ready meals instead.

topic vocab.meaning: To make a meal by reading a cooking recipe and following the steps.
topic vocab.example: I generally tend to get creative in the kitchen, because I can’t stand following recipes.

topic vocab.meaning: Cook in oil/fat, usually at a high heat.
topic vocab.example: The first step is always to shallow-fry some onions and garlic.

topic vocab.meaning: To cut something into pieces with a knife
topic vocab.example: The next step is to roughly chop some carrots and other vegetables.

topic vocab.meaning: A type of food or cooking, usually specific to a place. e.g. Indian cuisine.
topic vocab.example: The local cuisine in my area includes a lot of deep-fried food.

topic vocab.meaning: A special dish or cuisine you can cook well, or the dish you cook best.
topic vocab.example: When it comes to cooking, my specialty is definitely Chinese food, specifically stir-fries.

topic vocab.meaning: Cook something in water at a high heat, usually at the temperature that causes the water to bubble and turn into steam.
topic vocab.example: The third step is to put the vegetables into a pot of water and bring it to the boil.

topic vocab.meaning: A meal cooked at home (this phrase has very positive connotations in English)
topic vocab.example: I like to eat out occasionally, but for me, there’s nothing like home-cooked meals, particularly if my grandma is cooking!

topic vocab.word: Lock someone up and throw away the key (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: Put a criminal in prison for a long time, possibly forever.
topic vocab.example: I think we should lock drug dealers up and throw away the key.

topic vocab.meaning: Educate people to allow them to re-enter society successfully or become useful members of society.
topic vocab.example: Many people believe that we should rehabilitate prisoners to help them escape a life of crime in the future.

topic vocab.meaning: Planned in advance, usually related to a crime or negative action.
topic vocab.example: We should have extremely strong sentences for premeditated crimes.

topic vocab.meaning: A crime committed because of sudden strong emotions, and without planning.
topic vocab.example: It is understandable to look differently on crimes of passion compared to deliberate and cold-blooded criminal acts.

topic vocab.word: Commit + name of crime/negative action (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: The official word for ‘doing’ a crime.
topic vocab.example: He committed fraud and several white collar crimes, but escaped a harsh sentence.

topic vocab.meaning: To be found guilty of a crime by a court
topic vocab.example: People who are convicted of non-violent crimes often avoid serving time in prison.

topic vocab.meaning: Organisations formed/operated with the goal of breaking the law, usually in order to make money.
topic vocab.example: In some countries, local politicians have been linked to organised crime.

topic vocab.meaning: An official punishment for crimes, where the convict helps in the community rather than going to prison.
topic vocab.example: People guilty of minor crimes are often given community service instead of jail-time.

topic vocab.meaning: A way of discouraging or scaring people to stop them committing crimes.
topic vocab.example: The death penalty is rarely used, but acts as a useful deterrent to potential criminals.

topic vocab.meaning: A place that underage criminals are sent instead of going to an adult prison.
topic vocab.example: I don’t think it’s right to send underage criminals to prison alongside hardened adult prisoners. Instead, they should be sent to a juvenile detention center, where they can be rehabilitated.

topic vocab.meaning: The spread of companies, products and cultures across the world.
topic vocab.example: Globalization has reduced the cultural differences between once-distant countries.

topic vocab.meaning: A society or situation that includes people from several different ethnic or cultural backgrounds.
topic vocab.example: One of the challenges of living in a multicultural society is learning to accept and tolerate very different lifestyles and customs.

topic vocab.meaning: To join something (e.g. society/group) and adapt to the culture of the new situation.
topic vocab.example: Some people are able to integrate into new societies, whereas others find it very difficult.

topic vocab.meaning: A feeling of anxiety, depression or confusion from being in a very different culture.
topic vocab.example: People who move abroad often suffer from culture shock in the first few weeks or months.

topic vocab.meaning: The ethical or behavioural beliefs of a person, place or society.
topic vocab.example: The older generations in my country generally share a different set of values to the younger generations.

topic vocab.meaning: An action or set of actions that is culturally or traditionally important.
topic vocab.example: Older people often perform elaborate rituals when inviting guests into their homes.

topic vocab.meaning: A series of traditions, values or customs shared by a group of people e.g. a country.
topic vocab.example: I believe that we should take pride in our heritage rather than trying to adopt the customs of other countries.

topic vocab.meaning: An oversimplified or completely incorrect idea about a group of people, usually negative and offensive.
topic vocab.example: People who live in the countryside are often portrayed as being backwards, but this is actually a rather offensive stereotype.

topic vocab.meaning: Full of life, energy and activity.
topic vocab.example: Many of the cities across Latin American are really vibrant and full of life.

topic vocab.meaning: An action that is considered completely unacceptable by a society. 4647
topic vocab.example: Actions that are considered taboo in some societies, like unmarried women having children, are perfectly acceptable in other parts of the world.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who finds it easy and/or enjoyable to wake up early in the morning.
topic vocab.example: I’d love to be a morning person, but I’m actually more of a night owl.

topic vocab.word: Get something out of the way (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: To finish a task that is either difficult or unpleasant.
topic vocab.example: When I know I’ve got something difficult to do, I like to get it out of the way as early as possible, because then I can relax and enjoy the day.

topic vocab.meaning: A person who avoids necessary tasks and wastes time rather than completing the tasks.
topic vocab.example: I used to be a chronic procrastinator, but recently I’ve been controlling myself a lot better and getting tasks out of the way much earlier.

topic vocab.meaning: To find the time in the day to do something.
topic vocab.example: I’d like to find the time to exercise every day, but I really struggle to fit it into my schedule.

topic vocab.meaning: Have a short sleep in the middle of the day.
topic vocab.example: I try to fit in a nap in the afternoon, but often I just have to power through.

topic vocab.meaning: Working or studying all through the night, usually to meet a deadline.
topic vocab.example: I usually try to get everything out of the way before bedtime, but occasionally I do have to pull an all-nighter.

topic vocab.meaning: To do several tasks at the same time.
topic vocab.example: I’m not very good at multitasking so I generally tend to focus on one thing and try to finish it before moving onto the next one.

topic vocab.meaning: To consider one task more important than another, and/or do one task before another.
topic vocab.example: I find that if I prioritize tasks that don’t have a deadline, I still manage to fit in the tasks that do have a deadline as well. That way, I am able to finish everything.

topic vocab.meaning: To find it difficult to wake up and get out of bed in the morning.
topic vocab.example: Some people are able to bounce out of bed and attack the day, but as a night-owl, I always end up crawling out of bed and hating the world!

topic vocab.meaning: A person’s mental attitude at a particular time – neutral meaning.
topic vocab.example: I find that spending ten minutes in the morning meditating always puts me in a positive frame of mind.

topic vocab.meaning: The money that people have left once they have paid for all their necessities.
topic vocab.example: The more disposable income people have, the more they will go out and spend money on luxuries.

topic vocab.meaning: The money spent by the government on public-related items e.g. hospital, roads, schools, military.
topic vocab.example: Many governments are considering increasing public spending on environmentally-friendly technology and projects.

topic vocab.meaning: The number of people who don’t have a job in a country.
topic vocab.example: One of the key responsibilities of any government is to maintain a low unemployment rate.

topic vocab.meaning: To promote or encourage growth in the economy.
topic vocab.example: Some people claim that lower corporation tax rates can stimulate the economy by encouraging companies to make investments.

topic vocab.meaning: Money paid to the government by individuals or companies.
topic vocab.example: One solution could be to pay for the necessary services by introducing a wealth tax on the richest 1% of the population.

topic vocab.meaning: A period of time when the economy of a country stops growing and/or starts to shrink.
topic vocab.example: Poor economic decisions by a government can lead to a recession.

topic vocab.meaning: Reducing the tax you have to pay through legal methods.
topic vocab.example: Large multinational corporations like Amazon are particularly good at employing tax avoidance strategies.

topic vocab.meaning: To spend more money than you make.
topic vocab.example: People who live beyond their means run the risk of getting into inescapable debt.

topic vocab.meaning: Having just enough money to live and nothing extra, no disposable income. 5455
topic vocab.example: The government should attempt to help people who are living hand to mouth to become more financially secure.

topic vocab.meaning: A person’s job or the way they provide the basic necessities for themselves.
topic vocab.example: While it may mean that many local people lose their livelihoods, it is still crucial to stop the destruction of the Amazon rainforest.

topic vocab.meaning: Study very hard, usually memorizing lots of facts, to prepare for an exam. Often with only a short-time left.
topic vocab.example: Whenever I have an exam, I tend to leave everything till the last minute and then spend the whole night cramming.

topic vocab.meaning: Information about something without doing it in practice.
topic vocab.example: I believe that schools should attempt to combine theoretical knowledge and practical skills when educating children.

topic vocab.meaning: The ability to do a task in the real world, not just knowing the theory of it.
topic vocab.example: Students who are able to develop practical skills as well as theoretical knowledge are far more employable after they graduate.

topic vocab.meaning: The day on which an assignment or piece of work must be finished and submitted.
topic vocab.example: I remember that I almost missed the due date for my final coursework at university, but in the end I managed to submit it just in time.

topic vocab.meaning: Learn facts by memorizing them and reviewing them repeatedly.
topic vocab.example: Many schools still rely on endless rote learning rather than using other methods of education, such as meaningful learning or problem solving.

topic vocab.meaning: An official record showing the completion of certain course or acquisition of a skill.
topic vocab.example: Without the necessary qualifications, it is very difficult to get a good job.

topic vocab.meaning: Studying something outside of the traditional classroom, usually online. Usually still done through a recognized institution e.g. university.
topic vocab.example: The coronavirus pandemic led to the increasing popularity of distance learning programmes over traditional classroom based learning.

topic vocab.meaning: Exhaustion or complete lack of motivation as the result of too much work/stress.
topic vocab.example: There is an increasingly high rate of burnout amongst both students and teachers.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who has very strict standards or requirements about behaviour.
topic vocab.example: I remember that our school principal was a real stickler for punctuality. Anyone who arrived late to school always got a really strict punishment.

topic vocab.meaning: A punishment involving some physical pain, for example being hit with a stick or a hand. Usually related to children at home or in school.
topic vocab.example: Although corporal punishment is banned in the UK, many people still support the use of it in schools.

topic vocab.meaning: Additional good points included in a job or provided by a company, other than salary. For example – a season ticket for the subway; free lunches; discounts on products; flexible working hours.
topic vocab.example: One of the perks of being self-employed is that you can choose your own hours.

topic vocab.meaning: The hierarchy of employment in a company, from the lowest employee to the owner or CEO.
topic vocab.example: I think that climbing the corporate ladder is one of the things that causes people the most stress in their jobs.

topic vocab.meaning: A skill that is considered very valuable by a company or client. For example, computer coding or speaking a second language.
topic vocab.example: The importance of having sellable skills when applying for a job shouldn’t be underestimated.

topic vocab.meaning: A job that makes an employee satisfied and happy.
topic vocab.example: For many people, choosing a job that they find fulfilling is more important than getting a high salary.

topic vocab.meaning: A person’s attitude towards work, and their ability to work hard. Note – this is a neutral word. Someone could have a good or bad work ethic.
topic vocab.example: One thing that employers always look for in a candidate is a strong work ethic.

topic vocab.meaning: To get a job when you previously didn’t have one. Usually used when graduating from school or university.
topic vocab.example: The main goal of the final year of university is to get students ready to join the workforce, but many graduates still end up with few sellable skills.

topic vocab.word: Get your foot in the door (idiom, verb)
topic vocab.meaning: Find a way to get an opportunity or enter an organisation. Sometimes done by entering the organisation at a lower level and trying to rise up the corporate ladder.
topic vocab.example: For new graduates fresh out of university, doing an unpaid internship is one way to get your foot in the door.

topic vocab.meaning: The culture inside a company, including the way employees interact with managers, the working hours, the attitude to work, and how the company interacts with other companies.
topic vocab.example: How much an employee enjoys their job is often heavily influenced by their company’s corporate culture.

topic vocab.meaning: Skills related to handling people and relationships. For example, the ability to run a meeting, to criticize someone in a controlled way, or to motivate someone.
topic vocab.example: Quite often, graduates from technical courses like physics lack the soft skills needed to thrive in a company.

topic vocab.meaning: To lose one’s job, usually as a result of the company not needing the employee anymore, or having financial trouble.
topic vocab.example: Workers who are laid off as part of a restructuring effort should receive some form of compensation.

topic vocab.meaning: A chemical released in the brain that makes you feel happy and fulfilled.
topic vocab.example: One reason that video games are so popular is that they are designed to stimulate the release of dopamine, meaning that players start to associate the game with feeling happy.

topic vocab.meaning: Something that takes and keeps all of our attention.
topic vocab.example: Many people find painting quite dull, but for me, it’s absolutely absorbing. I can pass hours with just my brush and easel for company.

topic vocab.meaning: Activities done for fun or interest, not for work or study.
topic vocab.example: When I was growing up, my parents encouraged me to get involved in extracurricular activities at school, but I was mostly interested in playing video games by myself.

topic vocab.meaning: To relax.
topic vocab.example: No matter how busy my day has been, I try to find time before I go to bed to unwind.

topic vocab.meaning: Extremely boring.
topic vocab.example: Many of my friends love watching shopping livestreams, but I must admit that I find them mind-numbingly dull.

topic vocab.meaning: To watch something for multiple hours in one sitting. Often used when talking about a particular TV show. Also sometimes expressed simply as ‘binge’.
topic vocab.example: I try not to binge-watch shows that are very high quality, because it’s good to leave time to digest them fully before watching the next episode.

topic vocab.meaning: A large park with many attractions including rollercoasters and other types of rides.
topic vocab.example: I’ve always loved going to amusements parks, although sadly there aren’t any good ones close to me.

topic vocab.meaning: The relationship between time spent working (or studying) and relaxing or having fun.
topic vocab.example: I think that the internet has brought many benefits, including the opportunity to play video games against people from across the world, but it has also harmed our work-life balance in some ways. 6667

topic vocab.meaning: A game played with physical pieces, often on a table, and usually with other people.
topic vocab.example: When I was young, I used to play board games with my family all the time – my favorite was Werewolves of Miller’s Hollow.

topic vocab.meaning: A live broadcast shared on social media, either by a celebrity or normal person. Also written as 2 words (live stream)
topic vocab.example: One of my favorite ways to unwind in the evening is watching a livestream.

topic vocab.meaning: A difficult choice, or situation that requires a choice.
topic vocab.example: The question of whether to execute or rehabilitate violent prisoners is a moral dilemma.

topic vocab.meaning: A fair or morally right result, particularly after something bad has happened or people have been in conflict about something.
topic vocab.example: One issue with modern society is that the richest and most powerful people very rarely face justice, even if they have committed terrible crimes.

topic vocab.meaning: To recognize the suffering of other people and want to or try to help.
topic vocab.example: If people could show compassion for each other rather than constantly judging, the differences between cultures and generations would be far easier to solve.

topic vocab.meaning: Being honest and having the habit of acting in a moral way.
topic vocab.example: I believe that, by acting with integrity, we can improve our relationships with everyone we encounter.

topic vocab.meaning: Completely without morals, acting in an immoral way. Describes a person or organisation.
topic vocab.example: Some people would argue that big tech companies like Facebook are morally bankrupt and, as such, can’t be trusted to make ethical decisions.

topic vocab.meaning: Your own personal sense of right and wrong, plus your feelings about your own past behaviour.
topic vocab.example: I always try to follow my conscience when making moral decisions, but it isn’t an easy thing to do!

topic vocab.meaning: Unwilling to accept differences, for example in behaviour or appearance.
topic vocab.example: Although many older people can be intolerant of different lifestyle choices, society in general is becoming more liberal.

topic vocab.meaning: To be intolerant of a specific group of people or ideas.
topic vocab.example: Despite society becoming more liberal, there are still significantly large groups of people who are racially prejudiced.

topic vocab.meaning: An action/decision/situation that is neither completely morally right (white) or morally wrong (black).
topic vocab.example: I think that the choice between protecting the environment and promoting economic growth is something of a moral grey area.

topic vocab.meaning: A set of guidelines to help people make moral decisions. Often used in companies or other organisations.
topic vocab.example: Developing and following a code of ethics is not just necessary for companies. Individual people should do the same.

topic vocab.meaning: An activity that takes a large amount of effort.
topic vocab.example: Medical professional suggest that people should do strenuous exercise 4-5 times per week in order to stay healthy and avoid illness.

topic vocab.meaning: To exercise enough to start sweating.
topic vocab.example: My friend can climb twenty flights of stairs without breaking a sweat, but I’m soaked after climbing two flights!

topic vocab.meaning: A task or activity that is fairly difficult or challenging from the start, and stays difficult.
topic vocab.example: I’ve always found sticking to exercise an uphill struggle. I do it for a few days, and then give up!

topic vocab.word: Push yourself to the limit (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: To put in as much energy and effort as you possibly can in order to achieve something.
topic vocab.example: You don’t have to push yourself to the limit every single day when you exercise, but at least try to do something rather than sitting on the sofa all day.

topic vocab.meaning: Strong stomach muscles that can be clearly seen as six individual parts.
topic vocab.example: I’ve always wanted to have a six-pack, but I can’t seem to lose my love handles.

topic vocab.meaning: Excess fat on either side of a person’s hips, above the waistline.
topic vocab.example: I’m not too motivated to exercise, but I do want to keep my love handles in check.

topic vocab.meaning: A strenuous exercise involving a push-up and a jump. Usually done in sets of 10+ as a way to improve cardiovascular fitness or lose weight.
topic vocab.example: Many people dread doing high-intensity exercises like burpees, but they are a very effective way of losing weight.

topic vocab.meaning: Related to the heart’s ability to pump blood (and oxygen) to the different muscles around the body.
topic vocab.example: Many doctors say that thirty minutes of cardiovascular exercise a day can make a big difference to a person’s quality of life and general health. 7475

topic vocab.meaning: A chemical released in the body as the result of intense exercise, which gives the temporary feeling of tiredness or burning in the muscles.
topic vocab.example: I don’t like doing really strenuous exercise because I hate that feeling of lactic acid in my muscles.

topic vocab.meaning: To lift weights as a form of exercise, usually at a gym.
topic vocab.example: My brother goes to the gym every day and loves pumping iron, but I’m more into doing cardio outdoors.

topic vocab.meaning: Used to describe a characteristic, trait or health condition of someone that is shared by other members of the family
topic vocab.example: My grandad and dad also love extreme sports. I guess it runs in the family!

topic vocab.meaning: To be similar to or copy the behaviour of another family member, usually older.
topic vocab.example: People always say I take after my father, because we look alike, but personality-wise, I think I’m actually closer to my mother.

topic vocab.meaning: A parent who doesn’t work, and instead is responsible for looking after the children and the home.
topic vocab.example: It’s still pretty unusual to be a stay-at-home dad in my country, as we are quite traditional.

topic vocab.meaning: A member of a family who is considered very different to the rest, and/or a source of shame for the family.
topic vocab.example: I even get on well with my cousin, who has always been the black sheep of the family.

topic vocab.meaning: A family which has serious problems including behaviour and conflict.
topic vocab.example: For children who come from dysfunctional families, it can be harder to fit in with their schoolmates.

topic vocab.meaning: The feeling of competition and/or jealousy between brothers and sisters (and can also be used for cousins).
topic vocab.example: I must admit that there is a pretty strong amount of sibling rivalry between me and my brother.

topic vocab.meaning: To take the same path (e.g. in studies or career) as an older member of the family.
topic vocab.example: My mother is a successful research scientist and I plan to follow in her footsteps.

topic vocab.meaning: The male leader of a family (or group)
topic vocab.example: Many families in my country are still dominated by a patriarch, although this is gradually starting to change.

topic vocab.meaning: A word that includes people like grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins, but not close family like parents or siblings.
topic vocab.example: I usually spend New Year with my extended family, even though I’m not on speaking terms with all of them!

topic vocab.meaning: A member of someone’s family, usually close family.
topic vocab.example: People often behave differently towards their own flesh and blood, in both good and bad ways.

topic vocab.meaning: Foods that a person cannot eat or must eat, usually for health reasons.
topic vocab.example: It’s always polite to enquire about your guest’s dietary requirements when hosting a dinner party.

topic vocab.meaning: An item (usually a type of food) that is used (eaten) very regularly by people in a certain place. For
topic vocab.example: A staple crop of many Asian countries is rice.

topic vocab.meaning: A popular and/or expensive food, which is usually special in some way.
topic vocab.example: In many countries, guinea pigs are kept as pets, but they are considered a delicacy in Peru.

topic vocab.meaning: A fruit or vegetable that grows at certain times of the year, but not all year. Also used as a way of saying, ‘The fruits and vegetables that are growing now in this part of the world.’
topic vocab.example: Eating seasonal fruits and vegetables is a great way to both stay healthy and protect the environment.

topic vocab.meaning: Food that has been produced without the use of chemicals such as pesticides.
topic vocab.example: Some believe that the government should support organic farmers and encourage everyone to eat only organic produce.

topic vocab.meaning: To carefully monitor the number of calories a person eats, often by using an app. Usually done in order to lose weight.
topic vocab.example: Many people believe that counting calories is a good way to lose weight, but not all doctors agree.
