topic vocab.meaning: Try to avoid doing something that you want to do but know is not a good choice. Often used in the negative. Example – Eating a chocolate cake when you are trying to lose weight.
topic vocab.example: I always find it hard to resist temptation when I pass by a bakery and see all the desserts in the window.

topic vocab.meaning: A food that has a lot of flavour.
topic vocab.example: I love foods that are packed with flavour, particularly if they are also a little spicy.

topic vocab.meaning: The food you eat has a strong relationship with your health. Usually used in relation to eating healthily. Often used in a sentence by itself.
topic vocab.example: People are always telling me, ‘You are what you eat,’ but I think life’s too short so I tend to eat whatever I want.

topic vocab.meaning: The benefit that someone can get from eating or drinking a certain item.
topic vocab.example: If people understood more about the nutritional benefits of different products, they could make better dietary decisions.

topic vocab.word: Two peas in a pod (Metaphor, noun)
topic vocab.meaning: Two people who are very similar in looks or personality, and (usually) have a very close relationship.
topic vocab.example: My younger sister Sarah and I have always been like two peas in a pod.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who is only your friend in good times, and disappears or won’t help you during bad times.
topic vocab.example: It’s important to be able to tell the difference between a true friend and a fair-weather friend.

topic vocab.word: To get on like a house on fire (idiom, verb)
topic vocab.meaning: To get on well, have a really good relationship. Usually used for friends/family rather than romantic relationships.
topic vocab.example: I love hanging out with John. We get on like a house on fire.

topic vocab.meaning: Get on well with someone the first time you meet that person.
topic vocab.example: I was worried about whether I would get on well with my girlfriend's father, but we hit it off straight away.

topic vocab.meaning: To have good periods and bad periods in a friendship or romantic relationship. It can also refer to good and bad periods in someone’s life.
topic vocab.example: My friend Jimmy and I have definitely been through some ups and downs together, but whenever we do fall out, we bury the hatchet very quickly and move on.

topic vocab.meaning: To forgive someone for doing something wrong, and try to be friends/partners again.
topic vocab.example: I think being able to bury the hatchet when you have a falling out is one of the key parts of a strong relationship.

topic vocab.word: A shoulder to cry on (idiom, noun)
topic vocab.meaning: A friend that can comfort you when you are sad.
topic vocab.example: She’s always very sympathetic and is a shoulder to cry on whenever I need it.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone that you trust deeply and can tell secrets to, knowing that they will keep those secrets.
topic vocab.example: One of the key attributes of a friend is someone who you can trust to be your confidante.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone you know but who isn’t a friend. It could be that you don’t like them, or you just don’t know them very well yet.
topic vocab.example: You wouldn’t tell your deepest secrets to someone who is just an acquaintance, but you should be able to tell your best friend.

topic vocab.meaning: To argue with a friend/partner and damage your relationship, either temporarily or permanently.
topic vocab.example: One challenging thing about friendships is being honest about a difficult topic without falling out with each other.

topic vocab.meaning: The details of a group of people, for example the population of a country. It includes age, level of education, family background and other details. It can also refer to a specific group of people (e.g. people aged 24- 35)
topic vocab.example: Countries with aging populations and low birth rates are generally considered to be sitting on a demographic timebomb.

topic vocab.meaning: The height above the sea that a place is located. For example, Tibet is at a high altitude.
topic vocab.example: One of the challenges of living at high altitude is that the air is thinner, leading to shortness of breath when exercising.

topic vocab.meaning: A large body of ice that stays frozen for the whole year. Usually found on mountains or near the poles.
topic vocab.example: Scientists are concerned that the melting of glaciers is increasing as the world gets warmer.

topic vocab.meaning: A large part of the world. Usually divided into northern and southern hemispheres (above and below the equator) and western and eastern hemisphere (the dividing line is in the UK).
topic vocab.example: It’s often said that the southern hemisphere is significantly less wealthy than the northern hemisphere.

topic vocab.meaning: When a piece of dry land which previously was not a desert becomes a desert.
topic vocab.example: One of the steps that countries can take to prevent desertification is to plant more trees.

topic vocab.meaning: The reduction in size or complete destruction of forests.
topic vocab.example: The Amazon rainforest has suffered enormously from deforestation in the past few decades, and has reduced in size by up to 20% according to some estimates.

topic vocab.meaning: The areas of low-lying land beside a river, at the same or similar altitude, which can be easily flooded.
topic vocab.example: Houses built on a floodplain are more at risk of extreme weather events like flooding.

topic vocab.meaning: A natural disaster in which a large amount of earth and rocks fall down the side of a mountain, usually as a result of heavy rainfall.
topic vocab.example: A landslide can be a devastating natural disaster that causes a huge amount of damage and endangers lives.

topic vocab.meaning: A generic word that includes seas, oceans, rivers, lakes, ponds, and streams.
topic vocab.example: Elephants can travel for hundreds of miles in search of a body of water.

topic vocab.meaning: A temporary sleep disorder caused by traveling across many time zones. For example, someone who travels from China to the USA will most likely have trouble sleeping during the night and not be able to stay awake during the day during the first few days after arrival. Note – also written as jet lag.
topic vocab.example: I suffer terribly from jetlag whenever I travel abroad, so I always try to sleep on the plane.

topic vocab.meaning: Employ people in other countries to do the work previously done by employees in a company’s home country. Usually done to cut costs, sending the jobs to countries with lower cost of labour.
topic vocab.example: An increasing number of multinational companies have outsourced production of their products to developing countries.

topic vocab.meaning: The average price of hiring and paying employees in a city or country.
topic vocab.example: A major reason that companies decide to outsource production to developing countries is the relatively high cost of labour in developed countries.

topic vocab.meaning: The series of supplier companies who produce the various parts that go together to make a final product. For example, companies that make the chips and the screen for an iPhone are part of the supply chain.
topic vocab.example: Many companies rely on global supply chains for important parts of the products they sell.

topic vocab.meaning: A factory where manual workers are employed, and usually paid very low wages working in poor/dangerous conditions.
topic vocab.example: The concern that many people have about buying so called ‘fast fashion’ is that many of the items they buy will have been produced in sweatshops.

topic vocab.meaning: Low-quality but good-looking clothes which are produced at low cost and are kept for a short period of time before being thrown away.
topic vocab.example: Globalization made the rise of the fast fashion industry possible.

topic vocab.meaning: To be able to rely on oneself, for example emotionally or for the things needed to survive.
topic vocab.example: The global pandemic led to a rise in countries aiming to become self-sufficient in many areas, including medical technology and energy production.

topic vocab.meaning: Something that exists or can be seen everywhere.
topic vocab.example: Given how ubiquitous American brands like McDonald’s and Disney are, it’s no surprise that America is still a very influential country.

topic vocab.meaning: Several groups becoming one group, or one smaller group joining a larger group.
topic vocab.example: While many people do live abroad nowadays, they still face challenges regarding cultural integration into the local community.

topic vocab.meaning: Many cultures becoming less different and moving closer to each other.
topic vocab.example: Many people see cultural convergence as a good thing, as it tends to result in people from one country feeling closer to people from another country.

topic vocab.meaning: To include or have a range of differences in a group or situation. For example, people from many ethnic backgrounds and nationalities living in one big city.
topic vocab.example: It is often believed that a lack of diversity in a company’s employees leads to less creativity than in companies with greater diversity.

topic vocab.meaning: Write and pass a law or series of laws.
topic vocab.example: The government recently passed legislation that allows the use of guns for certain activities in rural areas.

topic vocab.meaning: To ban something or make it illegal.
topic vocab.example: In the 1920s, the American government prohibited the production and sale of alcohol.

topic vocab.meaning: All organisations that are owned by the government, including public hospitals, public schools, and government departments.
topic vocab.example: One of the government’s biggest responsibilities is making decisions about the levels and allocation of public sector funding.

topic vocab.meaning: System of financial protection for citizen, including pension and disability benefits. Usually paid for by the government, using money taxed from citizens or businesses.
topic vocab.example: An important role that the social security system plays is to provide a safety net for the most vulnerable people in society.

topic vocab.meaning: A situation in which society has broken down and laws are no longer being enforced, often due to the lack of a controlling power e.g. a central government.
topic vocab.example: It’s important to enforce the law, in order to avoid sliding into anarchy.

topic vocab.meaning: The idea that all people should have an equal chance to be successful in life, and that their success should be based on their own work and performance rather than inherited wealth or other unequal factors.
topic vocab.example: Most people agree that equality of opportunity is something that every government should strive for, but how it can be achieved is more contentious.

topic vocab.meaning: The amount of crime recorded in a city or country.
topic vocab.example: Keeping the crime rate as low as possible is one of the biggest responsibilities of any government.

topic vocab.meaning: To make decisions at a high or central level, rather than making them individually at lower levels.
topic vocab.example: When governments take a top-down approach to tackling a problem, they can coordinate their approach across multiple regions of a country.

topic vocab.meaning: A government’s (or company’s) approach or attitude towards a particular problem or situation.
topic vocab.example: The German government’s open-door policy on immigration led to a loss of support.

topic vocab.meaning: Words spoken about a topic. For example, in a speech.
topic vocab.example: The speaker used some beautiful rhetoric, but now we need to see action.

topic vocab.meaning: A feeling of shame or disgrace connected to a situation e.g. having a mental health condition.
topic vocab.example: Although there is no longer much stigma associated with things like getting divorced and being a single parent, mental health issues still have a lot of stigma associated with them.

topic vocab.meaning: Unacceptable behaviour that causes damage to oneself or others. The damage can be both physical and emotional. For example, illegal drug abuse.
topic vocab.example: Destructive behaviour is often, but not always, the direct result of childhood traumas.

topic vocab.meaning: A very unpleasant or disturbing experience, which can cause mental health issues in the future.
topic vocab.example: To attempt to avoid the trauma of killing someone, soldiers in execution squads are usually not told whether their guns are loaded.

topic vocab.meaning: A condition in which the patient’s brain gradually stops functioning. Symptoms can include memory loss and confusion. Often referred to as simply Alzheimer’s.
topic vocab.example: A cure for Alzheimer’s disease will be hard to find, but is very necessary to improve the quality of life of many elderly people.

topic vocab.meaning: The acronym for Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder. A psychological condition, which affects both children and some adults, 101which causes the patient to have lots of energy, to have trouble focusing and to often make poor decisions without thinking first.
topic vocab.example: In America, more and more children are taking medication for ADHD.

topic vocab.word: To be out of one’s mind (informal idiom, adjective)
topic vocab.meaning: To be insane. Usually used in informal situations. For example, friends making fun of each other, or two people arguing.
topic vocab.example: I said to him, ‘You must be out of your mind if you think that I’m going to lend you money!’

topic vocab.meaning: A situation that doesn’t appear too serious now but will have serious consequences in the future if not dealt with.
topic vocab.example: Psychologists say that the emotional impact of the coronavirus pandemic is a ticking time-bomb, and that we will see a big increase in mental disorders in the future.

topic vocab.meaning: A sudden feeling of intense fear, including symptoms like difficulty breathing and chest pain.
topic vocab.example: I tend to get stressed in certain situations, but luckily, I’ve never had a full-blown panic attack.

topic vocab.meaning: A feeling (or psychological condition) where a person feels very sad.
topic vocab.example: People who suffer from chronic depression often have to battle with it for their whole lives.

topic vocab.meaning: To talk to a professional psychiatrist or other qualified professional about mental health issues or other challenges e.g. marital problems.
topic vocab.example: Even though many people suffer from mental health conditions, the stigma that is still attached to them often prevents people from undergoing counselling.

topic vocab.meaning: To visit a doctor for a general health check, without having any symptoms.
topic vocab.example: I think it’s important for everyone to go to the doctor for a regular check-up, because you never know what they might find.

topic vocab.meaning: A long-lasting disease that cannot be cured but isn’t necessarily fatal e.g. diabetes.
topic vocab.example: Obesity is a major cause of people developing chronic diseases like diabetes.

topic vocab.word: As fit as a fiddle (idiom, adjective)
topic vocab.meaning: In very good physical health
topic vocab.example: My dad was always as fit as fiddle, so we were shocked when he developed a chronic condition.

topic vocab.meaning: To feel ill, but not seriously ill.
topic vocab.example: I generally stay in bed and drink plenty of fluids whenever I feel under the weather.

topic vocab.meaning: A body’s ability to fight off diseases, infections, bacteria, viruses.
topic vocab.example: We can strengthen our immune system by eating healthily and avoiding smoking and drinking alcohol.

topic vocab.meaning: The drugs or medicine that a person is given.
topic vocab.example: A serious danger for patients with chronic conditions is that they can become addicted to their pain medication.

topic vocab.meaning: The medicine recommended by a doctor, including an official piece of paper giving the patient the right to buy the medicine.
topic vocab.example: The doctor gave me a prescription for some strong painkillers, and that helped a lot.

topic vocab.word: Over-the-counter (adjective, also written as ‘over the counter’ when used as a location)
topic vocab.meaning: Something that is available to buy without a prescription.
topic vocab.example: When I’m a little bit under the weather, I usually just try to buy some over-the-counter medication rather than going to see a doctor. 106107

topic vocab.meaning: A person’s health, including whether they get diseases as well as their lifestyle choices.
topic vocab.example: One role of the government should be to make people aware of the importance of their physical well-being, as this can prevent costly treatments down the line.

topic vocab.word: To put in the hard yards (phrasal verb, idiom)
topic vocab.meaning: To work hard in order to achieve something that isn’t easy. For example – losing weight.
topic vocab.example: When it comes to improving physical fitness, many people aren’t willing to put in the hard yards.

topic vocab.meaning: The countryside, far from the city or central areas. Informal idiom.
topic vocab.example: I’ve always preferred to be based downtown rather than live out in the sticks.

topic vocab.meaning: The expansion or widening of a city and residential areas, usually further out into what was previously countryside.
topic vocab.example: Many areas of countryside have been ravaged by urban sprawl, and as a result, are suffering from a number of environmental issues.

topic vocab.meaning: In very bad condition, usually referring to a building or whole area.
topic vocab.example: While some parts of my hometown are a bit dilapidated, other areas have been recently developed and look fantastic.

topic vocab.meaning: Parts of a city that include nature, such as parks and gardens. Often maintained by the government for use by local people.
topic vocab.example: Residents of cities consistently say that the availability of green spaces is one of the biggest factors that affect the liveability of a city.

topic vocab.meaning: A place that is enjoyable and comfortable to live in. Also, a way to judge a city’s suitability for residents. Usually focused on factors including green spaces, pollution, cost of living, transport and other local facilities.
topic vocab.example: Except for the cost of buying a house, my hometown is considered one of the most liveable cities in my country.

topic vocab.meaning: A change where a previously poorer part of a city becomes more prosperous and expensive. Can be a positive or negative thing.
topic vocab.example: The gentrification of once-poor neighbourhoods can lead to new economic opportunities, but also make it hard for existing residents to make ends meet.

topic vocab.meaning: A collection (or the availability) of bars, nightclubs and other night-time activities. Often used as a way of judging a city.
topic vocab.example: My hometown doesn’t have much in the way of nightlife, but there are plenty of other things to do.

topic vocab.meaning: The special or unique feeling from being in a small town compared to a big city.
topic vocab.example: Many people eventually move out of cities because they miss the small-town vibe that they enjoyed growing up.

topic vocab.meaning: Something that is expensive and luxurious, designed to appeal to wealthier people.
topic vocab.example: As a result of gentrification, my hometown has a few new upmarket areas which, twenty years ago, were rather dilapidated.

topic vocab.meaning: To appear suddenly or unexpectedly. Often used for new buildings, businesses or other developments.
topic vocab.example: In recent years, a lot of new restaurants and bars have sprung up all over the city.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who prefers to have few possessions, including clothes and furniture.
topic vocab.example: I consider myself to be a minimalist, but I still would like to get a really nice coffee machine for my house!

topic vocab.word: Get on the property ladder (phrasal verb)
topic vocab.meaning: The first time that someone buys their own home.
topic vocab.example: Due to rising house prices, it is increasingly difficult for my generation to get on the property ladder.

topic vocab.meaning: To move from a larger to a smaller home. Often done by older people whose children have left home.
topic vocab.example: Many older people are willing to downsize in order to free up some of the value of their larger home.

topic vocab.meaning: To significantly improve something old and in poor condition, in order to make it like new again.
topic vocab.example: I like to keep things modern, so my ideal home would have to be recently renovated.

topic vocab.meaning: Light from the sun that enters a building from windows, rather than from electric lights.
topic vocab.example: My house is south-facing, so we get plenty of natural light.

topic vocab.meaning: A loan given by a bank to allow someone to buy a house.
topic vocab.example: Many people who don’t have a steady income are unable to take out a mortgage, and as such, cannot buy their own home.

topic vocab.meaning: Searching for a house to buy or rent.
topic vocab.example: I’m not a big fan of house-hunting, so I prefer to stay in my current apartment rather than moving house.

topic vocab.meaning: A generation of people who can’t afford to get on the property ladder due to high house prices.
topic vocab.example: The prospect of owning a home is very low for members of Generation Rent.

topic vocab.meaning: To have a comfortable and safe feeling. Not always in a person’s own home – it can also be in a different place e.g. university, a new job, a friend’s house. 114115
topic vocab.example: One of the key requirements for a house is that you can always feel at home there.

topic vocab.word: Home is where you hang your hat (phrasal verb, informal)
topic vocab.meaning: You can feel at home and accept being anywhere, instead of missing your family home.
topic vocab.example: Some people get homesick really easily when they move house, but I’m a big believer that home is where you hang your hat.

topic vocab.meaning: To give aid to someone or something e.g. a country.
topic vocab.example: Sometimes all that poorer countries need in order to achieve success is an initial helping hand.

topic vocab.meaning: Make sure that your own house, city or country is without problems before giving aid to others.
topic vocab.example: The old saying, ‘charity begins at home’, is a good guide to dealing with the difficult decision of whether to offer other countries a helping hand.

topic vocab.meaning: A term that refers to the main group of rich, Western countries including USA, UK, France, Germany and others. Note – not ‘geographical’ north as it includes countries such as Australia and New Zealand.
topic vocab.example: Countries in the global north have a moral responsibility to act in support of those in the global south, particularly when it comes to issues such as global warming.

topic vocab.meaning: Trouble or difficulties.
topic vocab.example: It is hard not to be moved by the plight of refugees made homeless by war, famine or climate instability.

topic vocab.meaning: A situation in which food has run out and many people are starving to death.
topic vocab.example: Countries that have recently been at war are far more likely to be plagued by famine as a result.

topic vocab.meaning: To illegally and secretly take a percentage of money that one hasn’t earned. For example, secretly taking 10% from the donations made to a charity.
topic vocab.example: A fear that many people have about providing aid to other countries is whether there are middle-men skimming off the top.

topic vocab.meaning: To cut spending on something (e.g. international aid) in a big or severe way.
topic vocab.example: There is often disagreement amongst people about whether the government should boost or slash spending on foreign aid.

topic vocab.meaning: Ideologies that are very strong or extreme, including terrorism and other violent acts.
topic vocab.example: One big benefit of international aid is that, by supporting local communities in vulnerable countries, it can aid the fight against extremism.

topic vocab.meaning: Being in a situation of danger or without protection.
topic vocab.example: Countries with limited rainfall and no access to reliable sources of fresh water are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change.

topic vocab.meaning: Associated with a number of countries, not just one or two countries. For example, political alliances or specific actions taken.
topic vocab.example: Taking a multilateral approach is usually a better way to solve pressing international issues, rather than acting unilaterally.

topic vocab.meaning: The very subtle or specific meanings that words or phrases can have.
topic vocab.example: Even for advanced speakers of a second language, it can be hard to understand all the nuances of the language.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who can speak several languages well (usually at least 4 languages).
topic vocab.example: I would love to be a polyglot, but learning English was hard enough by itself!

topic vocab.meaning: To use simple words in a second language to communicate with someone and allow the person to understand your meaning.
topic vocab.example: I am far from fluent in French, but I can make myself understood when I talk to people on the street.

topic vocab.meaning: To understand the general meaning of what someone is saying, without being clear about all the details.
topic vocab.example: A person who struggles with listening might only get the gist of what other people are saying, and miss a lot of the nuances.

topic vocab.meaning: To put oneself in a situation with almost complete exposure to a new language. For example, someone from China going to Japan and only using Japanese, not Chinese.
topic vocab.example: Immersing yourself in a language is definitely the quickest and most effective way to see big improvements quickly.

topic vocab.meaning: Have a good (but not perfect) level of ability in something, such as speaking another language.
topic vocab.example: He is a proficient speaker of several European languages including Portuguese and Italian.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who can talk very well, talks in an impressive way.
topic vocab.example: There is a big difference between making yourself understood in another language, and being eloquent in that language.

topic vocab.meaning: A feeling in which you feel nervous and find it difficult to say anything.
topic vocab.example: I always get tongue-tied when speaking a foreign language with native speakers, even when I know the language well.

topic vocab.meaning: The order or way in which sentences are created in a language.
topic vocab.example: One of biggest challenges for English native speakers learning Chinese is the completely different sentence structure.

topic vocab.meaning: Related to language.
topic vocab.example: It’s much easier to learn new languages that come from the same linguistic family as your mother tongue, such as French people learning Spanish.

topic vocab.meaning: A romantic action taken by someone. For example, buying roses, or making someone’s favorite meal.
topic vocab.example: A grand romantic gesture can be very effective if chosen and planned well, but can also backfire horribly!

topic vocab.meaning: When two people in a romantic relationship decide that they won’t have relations with anyone else. Considered by some people to be automatic at the start of a relationship, but sometimes by others as something that has to be verbally agreed by both parties.
topic vocab.example: One complication that can arise between new partners is the question of whether the relationship is exclusive or not.

topic vocab.meaning: To have agreed to marry someone, but not be married yet.
topic vocab.example: Some couples get married shortly after getting engaged, whereas others opt for a long engagement and take their time over their wedding plans.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone’s romantic partner. This can include a boyfriend/girlfriend, fiancé(e), or husband/wife.
topic vocab.example: Grandparents will often put pressure on their grandchildren by asking why they don’t yet have a significant other.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone that you were in a relationship with in high-school or earlier. The relationship could have continued, or ended. Someone met during university does not count as a childhood sweetheart.
topic vocab.example: As people travel more for university and migrate to bigger cities, marrying one’s childhood sweetheart is far less common than it used to be.

topic vocab.meaning: A meeting with someone that has the potential of being (or is already) one’s romantic partner. Classic examples include going to the cinema or to a restaurant.
topic vocab.example: Going on a first date can be nerve-racking experience!

topic vocab.meaning: The state of fame or being famous, or the focus of public attention.
topic vocab.example: He always hated the limelight and only wanted to make music for its own sake, not to become famous.

topic vocab.meaning: Photographers who follow celebrities and take photos of them during their normal life.
topic vocab.example: Famous people often find that being pursued by the paparazzi is one of the curses of fame.

topic vocab.meaning: Very luxurious, elaborate or expensive. Often used as a negative word.
topic vocab.example: Ordinary people often both envy and despise the opulent rich.

topic vocab.meaning: A situation of fame when almost everyone in a country knows a particular famous person.
topic vocab.example: People who become household names find it hard to live a normal life, because they are constantly in the limelight.

topic vocab.meaning: Unconfirmed information about a topic that is spread around and widely discussed.
topic vocab.example: Famous people often find that their private lives are the subject of considerable speculation.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who has a very family-friendly, innocent public image, and usually behaves in a legal and respectable way. Can be used as a positive adjective, but also can mean ‘boring’.
topic vocab.example: Disney likes their child stars to be wholesome, family friendly products they can easily package and sell, but quite often they grow up to be hellraisers!

topic vocab.meaning: The level to which something is (or seems) real, rather than manufactured or acted. Often used about the way in which celebrities or social media creators behave on camera.
topic vocab.example: Authenticity is one of the biggest factors today in deciding whether a social media channel becomes popular or not.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone/something that was famous and/or successful for a very short period of time.
topic vocab.example: That TV show seemed like it would be very successful and continue for a long time, but in the end that first season was just a flash in the pan.

topic vocab.meaning: 1) General meaning = Products created and sold by a company; 2) Media/Fame meaning = Products created by a company that are related to a piece of popular culture. For example, T-shirts from a band or lunchboxes with a Disney princess on the cover.
topic vocab.example: Large media companies make sure to profit as much as possible from merchandise and other product lines related to their cultural content.

topic vocab.meaning: Someone who controls the money they spend very carefully.
topic vocab.example: While it’s important to be frugal most of the time, there are times in which it is wise to loosen the purse strings a little.

topic vocab.meaning: give up control of something; leave
topic vocab.example: Charles was abandoned by his father at the age of three.

topic vocab.meaning: Continuing in the same way; lasting; enduring
topic vocab.example: Three abiding American values are life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.

topic vocab.meaning: To end a law, system, institution, custom or practice
topic vocab.example: Abraham Lincoln abolished slavery with the Emancipation Proclamation.

topic vocab.meaning: Many; a large amount; wealth
topic vocab.example: Africa has an abundance of natural resources, including gold, petroleum, diamonds, and coffee.

topic vocab.meaning: Easy to approach; capable of being used or seen
topic vocab.example: It’s important when building an office to make all floors accessible to wheelchairs.

topic vocab.meaning: to bring about harmony; to cause an agreement
topic vocab.example: My son’s school accommodated his instruction because of his learning disability.

topic vocab.meaning: to finish successfully; to complete
topic vocab.example: The Mt. Everest climber accomplished what no one else had when she climbed Everest two times in one week.

topic vocab.meaning: Harmony; agreement
topic vocab.example: The two countries signed an economic accord after the summit.

topic vocab.meaning: In natural sequence; consequently; so
topic vocab.example: Stan appreciates the danger of the ocean, and acts accordingly.

topic vocab.meaning: To increase the amount of something; to gather
topic vocab.example: Richard wishes to accumulate a large sum of money before buying a house.

topic vocab.meaning: exactly; precisely; without error
topic vocab.example: It’s difficult to accurately predict who the next president will be.

topic vocab.meaning: To get; to gain, usually by one’s own effort; to take on as part of a business deal
topic vocab.example: The corporation acquired two smaller companies after the merger.

topic vocab.meaning: To fit or suit; to modify for a different purpose
topic vocab.example: Lizards adapt to their surroundings by changing temperature.

topic vocab.meaning: To talk in front of a group
topic vocab.example: The Prime Minister will address the United Nations this afternoon.

topic vocab.meaning: Next to
topic vocab.example: Our house has an adjacent garage.

topic vocab.meaning: to organize, supervise, or give
topic vocab.example: The nurse administered the shots Sarah needed for her trip to the Philippines.

topic vocab.meaning: to allow them to enter an area or a building
topic vocab.example: The security guard admitted four people at a time to visit the governor.

topic vocab.meaning: Attachment or love for something or someone
topic vocab.example: My affection for mountain biking has grown over the years.

topic vocab.meaning: Person or thing that takes an active role in changing something
topic vocab.example: Universities are often agents of societal change.

topic vocab.meaning: To make something worse
topic vocab.example: The doctor said eating too much would aggravate his condition.

topic vocab.meaning: set aside for a purpose
topic vocab.example: Each month, we allocate a set amount of money for groceries.

topic vocab.meaning: To accomplish; to achieve
topic vocab.example: Every gymnast's dream is to attain the dream of a gold medal.

topic vocab.meaning: A characteristic or quality of a thing
topic vocab.example: A file with the read-only attribute set cannot be overwritten.

topic vocab.meaning: A structure that stops passage; an obstacle
topic vocab.example: The police put up barriers in preparation for the Thanksgiving Day parade.

topic vocab.meaning: To exchange goods or services without involving money
topic vocab.example: She bartered a hibiscus plant for one of the rare books in my library.

topic vocab.meaning: Prejudiced; favoring one thing or person over another
topic vocab.example: The newspaper gave a biased account of the incident.

topic vocab.meaning: The dividing line or location between two areas
topic vocab.example: The boundary between Kentucky and Indiana is mainly a river.

topic vocab.meaning: Having a quantity or amount that is generous or plentiful
topic vocab.example: They enjoyed a wet summer and a bountiful harvest.

topic vocab.meaning: Short; concise; of few words
topic vocab.example: His speech of acceptance was brief but moving.

topic vocab.meaning: Full of liveliness and activity; quick
topic vocab.example: We took a brisk walk yesterday.

topic vocab.meaning: Being large in size, mass, or volume (of goods, etc.)
topic vocab.example: Our family likes to purchase groceries in bulk.

topic vocab.meaning: A heavy load; responsibility of something; a cause of worry
topic vocab.example: I felt a huge burden when the teacher announced the 10-page research paper.

topic vocab.meaning: To determine the value of something or the solution to something by a mathematical process
topic vocab.example: Calculate the square root of 3 to 10 decimal places.

topic vocab.meaning: Disguise or cover up; blend into the background
topic vocab.example: Iguanas can camouflage themselves by changing the color of their scales.

topic vocab.meaning: The ability to hold, receive or absorb
topic vocab.example: Our capacity as humans to communicate is unique in the animal kingdom.

topic vocab.meaning: To profit or to obtain an advantage
topic vocab.example: The home team took several shots on goal but was unable to capitalize until late in the game.

topic vocab.meaning: A title or brief explanation attached to an illustration, cartoon, user interface element, etc.
topic vocab.example: Read the caption to understand more about Picasso's painting.

topic vocab.meaning: Disastrous; causing much harm
topic vocab.example: The catastrophic hurricane took 24 lives.

topic vocab.meaning: To invite someone to take part in a competition; To dispute something
topic vocab.example: We challenged the boys next door to a game of football.

topic vocab.meaning: The physical confine of a river or stream, consisting of a bed and banks
topic vocab.example: The water coming out of the waterwheel created a standing wave in the channel.

topic vocab.meaning: Extremely disorganized
topic vocab.example: Shopping at Wal-Mart on Black Friday is chaotic and overwhelming.

topic vocab.meaning: Being a distinguishing feature of a person or thing
topic vocab.example: We inherit different characteristics from each parent.

topic vocab.meaning: The principal part or top of anything; the leader of an organization or group
topic vocab.example: All firefighters report to the fire chief.

topic vocab.meaning: A written account of events and when they happened, ordered by time
topic vocab.example: The local newspaper keeps a chronicle of all high school sports scores.

topic vocab.meaning: To make clear
topic vocab.example: I should clarify my previous statement, because I don't want you to be confused.

topic vocab.meaning: To identify by or divide into classes; to categorize
topic vocab.example: Should we classify "make up" as an idiom or as a phrasal verb?

topic vocab.meaning: Relating to the part of mental functions that deals with logic, as opposed to affective, which deals with emotions
topic vocab.example: After Glenn had a stroke, doctors found that various cognitive functions were damaged.

topic vocab.meaning: State of working together
topic vocab.example: Unit cohesion is important in the military.

topic vocab.meaning: A smaller, self-contained part of a larger entity
topic vocab.example: A monitor is a component of a computer.

topic vocab.meaning: To be made up of; to consist of
topic vocab.example: A team is comprised of its members.

topic vocab.meaning: Having some logical sequence
topic vocab.example: When creating a password, be sure to avoid consecutive numbers, such as 123456.

topic vocab.meaning: A result of actions, especially if such a result is unwanted or unpleasant
topic vocab.example: I'm warning you. If you don't get me the report on time, there will be consequences.

topic vocab.meaning: From another point of view; on the other hand
topic vocab.example: We're not going to have enough wheat to last the year, while corn, conversely, are in a major surplus.

topic vocab.meaning: Rubble, wreckage, scattered remains of something destroyed
topic vocab.example: After the earthquake, debris piled up on the streets.

topic vocab.meaning: To get worse; to lose strength or health; to decline in quality
topic vocab.example: The cat's body decayed rapidly.

topic vocab.meaning: To fall; to worsen
topic vocab.example: My grandfather's health declined last winter.

topic vocab.meaning: An individual step, or stage, in any process or scale of values; The amount that an entity possesses a certain property
topic vocab.example: To what degree do the two accounts of the accident concur?

topic vocab.meaning: To consider carefully; to weigh well in the mind
topic vocab.example: It is now time for the jury to deliberate the guilt of the defendant.

topic vocab.meaning: To prepare and arrange for use, especially in military terms
topic vocab.example: "Deploy two units of infantry along the enemy's flank," the general ordered.

topic vocab.meaning: To lay down; to place; to put; To put money or funds into an account
topic vocab.example: A crocodile deposits her eggs in the sand.

topic vocab.meaning: To obtain or receive from something else; To come from
topic vocab.example: Our family name derives from a Greek word.

topic vocab.meaning: To make worse; to make inferior in quality or value
topic vocab.example: Sandra's mental health deteriorated after the death of her daughter.

topic vocab.meaning: To set the boundaries or limits of; to decide the course of
topic vocab.example: The lead professor will determine who can attend her special symposium.

topic vocab.meaning: An unforeseen event causing great loss
topic vocab.example: Floods in northern India have brought disaster on an enormous scale.

topic vocab.meaning: To make decisions based on prejudice
topic vocab.example: The law prohibits discriminating against people based on their skin color.

topic vocab.meaning: To throw into confusion or disorder.
topic vocab.example: Protesters disrupted the man's speech.

topic vocab.meaning: Not similar; different
topic vocab.example: The writers have dissimilar backgrounds.

topic vocab.meaning: Capable of being perceived very clearly; different from one another
topic vocab.example: Her voice was distinct despite the heavy traffic.

topic vocab.meaning: A field or sphere of activity, influence or expertise; A geographic area owned or controlled by a single person or organization
topic vocab.example: Dealing with complaints isn't really my

topic vocab.meaning: An amount of time or a particular time interval
topic vocab.example: The duration of the test is 60 minutes.

topic vocab.meaning: Comfort; a state or quality lacking difficulty
topic vocab.example: The pension set her mind at ease.

topic vocab.meaning: to expand in detail
topic vocab.example: Could you elaborate on the plot for your novel for me?

topic vocab.meaning: To completely destroy (something) so that it no longer exists; to exclude
topic vocab.example: Bill was eliminated as a suspect when the police interviewed witnesses.

topic vocab.meaning: To accept; to take on certain ideas or principles
topic vocab.example: Natural philosophy embraces many sciences.

topic vocab.meaning: To stress, give emphasis
topic vocab.example: His two-fingered gesture emphasized what he had told his boss to do with his job.

topic vocab.meaning: To make somebody able to do, or to be, something
topic vocab.example: Mark's parents enabled him to go to university.

topic vocab.meaning: To put in danger
topic vocab.example: Driving drunk endangers yourself and everyone else on the road.

topic vocab.meaning: A sincere attempt toward a specific goal
topic vocab.example: I wish you luck in all your future endeavors.

topic vocab.meaning: The surroundings of, and influences on, a particular item of interest; The natural world or ecosystem
topic vocab.example: Janelle was raised in a religious environment.

topic vocab.meaning: A time period of indeterminate length, generally more than one year
topic vocab.example: In a politically divided era, it's smart to avoid conversations of politics in the workplace.

topic vocab.meaning: To eject something violently (such as lava or water, as from a volcano or geyser)
topic vocab.example: The volcano erupted, spewing lava across a wide area.

topic vocab.meaning: Very important; necessary
topic vocab.example: Taxes pay for essential public services.

topic vocab.meaning: stop talking because you have forgotten what you were going to say: quên lời
topic vocab.example: I hope I don’t dry up in the middle of my speech.

topic vocab.meaning: Very specific, clear, or detailed
topic vocab.example: I gave explicit instructions for him to stay here, but he followed me anyway.

topic vocab.meaning: One among many similar or related, yet still distinct things
topic vocab.example: The child's learning disability was only one facet of the problems contributing to his delinquency.

topic vocab.meaning: To help bring about; to preside over a meeting or seminar
topic vocab.example: The counselor facilitated the father and son’s first meeting in a year.

topic vocab.meaning: Lacking strength; weak
topic vocab.example: There was a faint red light in the distance.

topic vocab.meaning: that can be done in practice; able to be done
topic vocab.example: His plan to rid Trafalgar Square of pigeons was not feasible.

topic vocab.meaning: A drawing or diagram conveying information
topic vocab.example: Refer to the information in Figure 3 to learn more.

topic vocab.meaning: The management of money
topic vocab.example: Who's really in charge of the company's finances?

topic vocab.meaning: To thrive or grow well
topic vocab.example: The barley flourished in the warm weather.

topic vocab.meaning: subject to change
topic vocab.example: Economics is a messy

topic vocab.meaning: first
topic vocab.example: Our foremost priority is to stabilize the economy.

topic vocab.meaning: Something that stimulates, encourages or maintains an action
topic vocab.example: Money is the fuel for the economy.

topic vocab.meaning: A leading or primary principle, rule, law, or article, which serves as the groundwork of a system; an essential part
topic vocab.example: One of the fundamentals of real estate success is the ability to adapt.

topic vocab.meaning: To measure or determine
topic vocab.example: I wasn't able to gauge his reaction based on her expression.

topic vocab.meaning: To bring into being
topic vocab.example: The discussion generated an uproar.

topic vocab.meaning: very beautiful
topic vocab.example: The sunsets in Hawaii are gorgeous.

topic vocab.meaning: To make and administer the public policy and affairs of; to control the actions or behavior of
topic vocab.example: Govern yourselves like civilized people.

topic vocab.meaning: Proceeding or advancing by small, slow, regular steps or degrees
topic vocab.example: True education is a gradual increase of knowledge over a long period of time.

topic vocab.meaning: So difficult or taxing as to make one exhausted
topic vocab.example: The Boston Marathon is a grueling race.

topic vocab.meaning: To reach a partly (or totally) unqualified conclusion; to suppose
topic vocab.example: He who guesses the riddle will win the prize.

topic vocab.meaning: Conditions suitable for an organism or population of organisms to live
topic vocab.example: This park offers important amphibian habitat and breeding areas.

topic vocab.meaning: Unpleasantly rough to the senses
topic vocab.example: Iceland is a beautiful country with harsh weather conditions.

topic vocab.meaning: from here; therefore
topic vocab.example: I shall go to Japan and hence will not be here in time for the party.

topic vocab.meaning: Diverse in kind or nature; composed of different parts
topic vocab.example: He had a large and heterogeneous collection of books.

topic vocab.example: Skyscrapers started to appear in the 1930s.

topic vocab.meaning: something large such as a building or bridge built from different parts; cấu trúc
topic vocab.example: The large structure outside town is going to be the new stadium.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to an area on the edge of a city; ngoại ô
topic vocab.example: Many people would love to live in suburban areas but can’t afford it.

topic vocab.meaning: all things present in a place that form the experience of being there; môi trường xung quanh
topic vocab.example: I wish I lived in more pleasant surroundings.

topic vocab.meaning: relating to towns and cities; thành thị
topic vocab.example: There needs to be more investment in urban areas.

topic vocab.meaning: to accept or admit that something exists or is true; công nhận, thừa nhận
topic vocab.example: He never acknowledges his mistakes.

topic vocab.meaning: to thank someone for something they have done; bày tỏ lòng biết ơn
topic vocab.example: We gratefully acknowledge the contributions of everyone who helped us.

topic vocab.meaning: to show you have seen someone, for example by smiling; tỏ ra đã nhận ra
topic vocab.example: They barely acknowledge each other in public.

topic vocab.meaning: to spend a long time worrying or being upset about something; chịu lo lắng, khổ sở
topic vocab.example: For years I agonised over whether I could have helped my daughter.

topic vocab.meaning: a feeling of having no interest or enthusiasm; sự lãnh đạm
topic vocab.example: Few people voted in the election, presumably just because of apathy.

topic vocab.meaning: to try to prevent something from happening; ngăn ngừa
topic vocab.example: Try to avoid confrontation.

topic vocab.meaning: to try not to go near someone or something; tránh xa
topic vocab.example: We went early to avoid the crowds.

topic vocab.meaning: to choose not to do something to achieve a better result; nên tránh
topic vocab.example: When taking this medication it is advisable to avoid alcohol.

topic vocab.meaning: the way that someone behaves; hành vi
topic vocab.example: Anna was sick of her brother’s behaviour.

topic vocab.meaning: a quiet laugh; nụ cười thầm
topic vocab.example: There were a couple of chuckles from one member of the audience.

topic vocab.meaning: to laugh quietly; cười thầm
topic vocab.example: As she read her book, she chuckled softly.

topic vocab.meaning: a physically relaxed state, without any pain or unpleasant feelings; sự an nhiên
topic vocab.example: The airline is keen to improve passenger comfort.

topic vocab.meaning: a feeling of being less sad or worried about something than before; sự an ủi
topic vocab.example: My mother was always there to offer comfort.

topic vocab.meaning: a pleasant way of life in which you have everything you need; sung túc
topic vocab.example: Now he can live in comfort for the rest of his life.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone feel less sad, worried or disappointed; an ủi
topic vocab.example: He went upstairs to comfort the baby.

topic vocab.meaning: the way someone behaves in relation to particular rules; cách đạo đức
topic vocab.example: Two players were sent off for violent conduct.

topic vocab.meaning: to do something in an organised way; thực hiện
topic vocab.example: The agreement doesn’t allow you to conduct business from your home.

topic vocab.meaning: a result or effect of something; hậu quả
topic vocab.example: She said exactly what she felt, without fear of the consequences.

topic vocab.meaning: the happiness you feel when you have everything you want; sự mãn nguyện
topic vocab.example: He has found contentment and satisfaction in his work.

topic vocab.meaning: angry; bực mình, cáu
topic vocab.example: The neighbours got cross every time we put our music on.

topic vocab.meaning: impressive behaviour of someone who controls their emotions; phẩm giá
topic vocab.example: She faced all her problems with dignity.

topic vocab.meaning: a very strong feeling of not liking something; sự ghê tởm
topic vocab.example: The idea of eating meat fills me with disgust.

topic vocab.meaning: to make someone angry and upset; làm ghê tởm
topic vocab.example: Your whole attitude disgusts me.

topic vocab.meaning: disappointed because something is not as good as you believed; vỡ mộng
topic vocab.example: Voters are very disillusioned with the democratic process.

topic vocab.meaning: annoyed or bored with something you have accepted for too long; chán ghét
topic vocab.example: I’m fed up with this job.

topic vocab.meaning: a high laugh, especially a nervous or silly one; cười khúc khích
topic vocab.example: The sound of giggles came from the girls’ room.

topic vocab.meaning: to laugh in a nervous or silly way; cười khúc khích
topic vocab.example: The children whispered and giggled all the way through the film.

topic vocab.meaning: a quick look at someone or something; cái liếc mắt
topic vocab.example: She had a quick glance at the newspaper as she gulped down her coffee.

topic vocab.meaning: to look somewhere quickly then look away; liếc
topic vocab.example: He glanced over his shoulder nervously.

topic vocab.meaning: an occasion when you see someone or something for a moment; cái nhìn thoáng qua
topic vocab.example: The crowd were anxious for a glimpse of the President.

topic vocab.meaning: to see someone or something for a moment or not completely; nhìn thoáng qua
topic vocab.example: He glimpsed a short white-haired figure heading for the back gate.

topic vocab.meaning: to show you are happy and proud at someone else’s failure; hách dịch
topic vocab.example: He was there to gloat over their defeat.

topic vocab.meaning: to stop something from happening or stop someone from doing something; cản, ngăn
topic vocab.example: Regular cleaning may help prevent infection.

topic vocab.meaning: to feel very happy about something; vui mừng
topic vocab.example: Montenegro seemed to rejoice in the humiliation of others.

topic vocab.meaning: to experience anger or bitterness because you think you have been treated unfairly; bực tức
topic vocab.example: The family resented all the attention their pets were getting.

topic vocab.meaning: to formally decide; kiên quyết
topic vocab.example: We’re resolved to win the contract.

topic vocab.meaning: an unpleasant way of smiling because something bad has happened to someone else; nụ cười nhếch mép
topic vocab.example: Wipe that smirk off your face!

topic vocab.meaning: to smile in an unpleasant way because something bad has happened to someone else; cười nhếch mép
topic vocab.example: I know you’ve won, but there’s no need to smirk.

topic vocab.meaning: to suddenly lose control and speak or act angrily; nổi cáu
topic vocab.example: ‘What do you want now?’ he snapped angrily.

topic vocab.meaning: to speak to someone in a sudden angry way; quát tháo
topic vocab.example: The governor’s tactics involved snapping at those who were too liberal.

topic vocab.meaning: a particular method or plan for achieving something; chiến thuật
topic vocab.example: The governor’s tactics involved a mix of discipline and support.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong feeling of fear; sự kinh hoàng
topic vocab.example: Thousands of residents fled in terror yesterday as the volcano erupted.

topic vocab.meaning: violence used for making people very frightened in order to achieve political aims; sự khủng bố
topic vocab.example: This is a deliberate campaign of terror.

topic vocab.meaning: to give someone a drug or medical treatment; phát thuốc
topic vocab.example: The drugs are administered intravenously.

topic vocab.meaning: to take someone into hospital for medical treatment; tiếp nhận vào viện
topic vocab.example: After collapsing, she was rushed to hospital, where she was admitted.

topic vocab.meaning: great pain; cơn đau đớn
topic vocab.example: William fell to the ground, writhing in agony.

topic vocab.meaning: a strong and unpleasant feeling, especially great worry or sadness; sự đau khổ
topic vocab.example: Waiting for the results was agony.

topic vocab.meaning: a substance that prevents a poison from having bad effects; thuốc giải độc
topic vocab.example: It’s a snake bite. Quick — get the antidote!

topic vocab.meaning: a senior doctor in a hospital who is an expert in a particular medical subject; bác sĩ tham vấn
topic vocab.example: She’s a consultant cardiologist.

grammar.meaning: The passive is used when the doer is unknown, obvious, unimportant, or to create a formal tone. (Câu bị động dùng khi không rõ, không quan trọng hoặc không muốn nhắc tới chủ thể hành động)
grammar.example: The car was stolen at approximately 1.30 am. / The XL500 was designed with young families in mind. / This type of submarine was developed during WWII. / We were surprised by the number of people trying to leave the city. / All passengers are required to present their ticket.

grammar.meaning: Used to express general beliefs, expectations, or assumptions. Often starts with 'It is thought...', 'Tourism is expected to...', etc. (Dùng bị động vô danh để nói về suy nghĩ/quan điểm chung)
grammar.example: Tourism is expected to become a major part of the country’s economy. / It is thought that the new railway will provide employment opportunities. / There are reported to have been a record number of accidents.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Direct and indirect object
grammar.meaning: Some verbs allow two objects (person + thing). In passive, either object can become subject. (Dùng bị động với câu có 2 tân ngữ — trực tiếp và gián tiếp)
grammar.example: Michael gave the plane tickets to Jill. / Jill was given the plane tickets (by Michael). / The plane tickets were given to Jill (by Michael). / How to drive the train was explained to me.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Avoiding the passive
grammar.meaning: Used when passive is awkward or not natural in continuous/perfect tenses. We use prepositional phrases instead. (Tránh dùng bị động bằng cách dùng cụm giới từ phù hợp hơn)
grammar.example: Preparations for the flight will be in progress as the President arrives. / At the end of this year, I will have been in training as a pilot for four years. / Vintage cars have been on display in the town centre. / The problem had been under consideration. / The railway station has been under construction for two years now.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get/have something done
grammar.meaning: Used when someone arranges for someone else to do something for them. (Cấu trúc nhờ ai đó làm gì cho mình)
grammar.example: Did you finally get your bike fixed? / I heard that Susie had her motorbike stolen. / I’d like those cars washed by this evening. / We’ll set off as soon as I’ve got the car fixed.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get sb to do / have sb do
grammar.meaning: Used to say someone persuades or arranges for someone else to do something. (Dùng khi khiến ai đó làm việc gì)
grammar.example: Did you get Alex to drive you all the way to London? / I had my assistant book the tickets.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get/have sb doing
grammar.meaning: Used to say someone starts someone else doing something. (Dùng khi khiến ai đó bắt đầu làm gì đó)
grammar.example: Don’t worry. We’ll soon have your car running like new. / That film got me thinking about my childhood.

grammar.meaning: The passive is used when the doer is unknown, obvious, unimportant, or to create a formal tone. (Câu bị động dùng khi không rõ, không quan trọng hoặc không muốn nhắc tới chủ thể hành động)
grammar.example: The car was stolen at approximately 1.30 am. / The XL500 was designed with young families in mind. / This type of submarine was developed during WWII. / We were surprised by the number of people trying to leave the city. / All passengers are required to present their ticket.

grammar.meaning: Used to express general beliefs, expectations, or assumptions. Often starts with 'It is thought...', 'Tourism is expected to...', etc. (Dùng bị động vô danh để nói về suy nghĩ/quan điểm chung)
grammar.example: Tourism is expected to become a major part of the country’s economy. / It is thought that the new railway will provide employment opportunities. / There are reported to have been a record number of accidents.
