grammar.meaning: Some verbs allow two objects (person + thing). In passive, either object can become subject. (Dùng bị động với câu có 2 tân ngữ — trực tiếp và gián tiếp)
grammar.example: Michael gave the plane tickets to Jill. / Jill was given the plane tickets (by Michael). / The plane tickets were given to Jill (by Michael). / How to drive the train was explained to me.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Avoiding the passive
grammar.meaning: Used when passive is awkward or not natural in continuous/perfect tenses. We use prepositional phrases instead. (Tránh dùng bị động bằng cách dùng cụm giới từ phù hợp hơn)
grammar.example: Preparations for the flight will be in progress as the President arrives. / At the end of this year, I will have been in training as a pilot for four years. / Vintage cars have been on display in the town centre. / The problem had been under consideration. / The railway station has been under construction for two years now.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get/have something done
grammar.meaning: Used when someone arranges for someone else to do something for them. (Cấu trúc nhờ ai đó làm gì cho mình)
grammar.example: Did you finally get your bike fixed? / I heard that Susie had her motorbike stolen. / I’d like those cars washed by this evening. / We’ll set off as soon as I’ve got the car fixed.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get sb to do / have sb do
grammar.meaning: Used to say someone persuades or arranges for someone else to do something. (Dùng khi khiến ai đó làm việc gì)
grammar.example: Did you get Alex to drive you all the way to London? / I had my assistant book the tickets.

grammar.word: Passives n Causations - Causative: get/have sb doing
grammar.meaning: Used to say someone starts someone else doing something. (Dùng khi khiến ai đó bắt đầu làm gì đó)
grammar.example: Don’t worry. We’ll soon have your car running like new. / That film got me thinking about my childhood.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Overview and structure
grammar.meaning: Modals (will, would, can, could, may, might, shall, should, must) have only one form and are followed by bare infinitives. Semi-modals (need to, ought to, had better, have to) behave similarly but may vary in structure. (Tổng quan về động từ khiếm khuyết và bán khiếm khuyết, cấu trúc theo sau là động từ nguyên mẫu)
grammar.example: Modals: could + do, be doing, have done, have been doing. / Passive: could + be done, have been done. / Semi-modals: need to, ought to, had better, have (got) to.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Criticising past behaviour
grammar.meaning: Used to express disapproval of something that happened in the past. (Dùng để chỉ trích hành vi đã xảy ra trong quá khứ) Modals: should have, shouldn’t have, ought to have, oughtn’t to have.
grammar.example: You shouldn’t have spoken to Mrs Todd like that.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Expressing annoyance at past behaviour
grammar.meaning: Used to express irritation or frustration about something that happened. (Dùng để thể hiện sự khó chịu với hành vi trong quá khứ) Modals: could have, might have.
grammar.example: You could/might have told me you were going to be late!

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Criticising general behaviour
grammar.meaning: Used to describe repeated or habitual negative behaviour. (Chỉ trích hành vi lặp lại hoặc quen thuộc) Modal: will.
grammar.example: He will slam the door every time he goes out.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Criticising a specific example of someone's general behaviour
grammar.meaning: Used to highlight a particular instance of a known habit or behaviour. (Dùng để chỉ trích một ví dụ cụ thể về hành vi quen thuộc) Modal: would.
grammar.example: You would take the car just when I wanted to go out.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Suggesting criticism with might as well
grammar.meaning: Might as well can be used sarcastically to suggest someone doesn’t care. (Might as well có thể dùng mang hàm ý phê phán hoặc chua chát)
grammar.example: I might as well be dead for all you care.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Current or general obligation
grammar.meaning: Used to describe what is necessary or required in general. (Dùng để chỉ nghĩa vụ hoặc yêu cầu chung) Modals: must, mustn’t, have (got) to, need (to).
grammar.example: You have to be a good communicator to be a press spokesperson.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Lack of current or general obligation
grammar.meaning: Used to say something is not necessary or required. (Dùng để nói điều gì đó không bắt buộc) Modals: don’t have to, haven’t got to, needn’t, don’t need (to).
grammar.example: You don’t always need to have a degree to become a journalist.

grammar.meaning: Used to talk about something that must be done in the future. (Dùng để nói về nghĩa vụ trong tương lai) Modals: will have to, must, mustn’t, have (got) to, will need (to).
grammar.example: You’ll have to do quite a lot of research before you write this report.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Lack of future obligation
grammar.meaning: Used to talk about things that will not be necessary. (Dùng để nói về điều không bắt buộc trong tương lai) Modals: don’t/won’t have to, haven’t got to, needn’t, won’t need (to).
grammar.example: I’m glad we won’t have to write any more essays on this course.

grammar.meaning: Used to describe something that had to be done in the past. (Dùng để nói về nghĩa vụ trong quá khứ) Modals: had to, needed (to).
grammar.example: We had to come up with three questions each.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Lack of past obligation
grammar.meaning: Used to say that something wasn’t necessary in the past. (Dùng để nói rằng điều gì đó đã không bắt buộc trong quá khứ) Modals: didn’t have to, didn’t need (to), needn’t have.
grammar.example: In the past, politicians didn’t have to deal with being in a 24-hour media spotlight.

grammar.meaning: Modals like can, could, be able to express current, past, future, or hypothetical ability. (Dùng để diễn tả khả năng hiện tại, quá khứ, tương lai hoặc giả định)
grammar.example: You can’t really speak seven languages fluently, can you? / There’s no way you could read when you were two! / One day, maybe, all adults will be able to read and write. / I couldn’t go on a quiz show – I’d be too nervous. / They could have asked the Prime Minister much more searching questions.

grammar.meaning: Modals such as can, could, may, might are used to ask for or give/refuse permission. (Dùng để xin hoặc cho phép làm điều gì đó)
grammar.example: Can I finish watching this before I go to bed? / No, you can’t. / Mum said we could buy one comic each. / We were allowed to buy one comic each.

grammar.meaning: Modals like should, ought to, had better are used to give advice or make suggestions. (Dùng để đưa ra lời khuyên hoặc gợi ý)
grammar.example: You should try to get that poem published. / Hadn’t you better check these facts are actually true? / We may as well watch this as there’s nothing else on.

grammar.meaning: Modals are used to criticize past actions or express annoyance. (Dùng để chỉ trích hành động trong quá khứ hoặc thể hiện sự khó chịu)
grammar.example: You shouldn’t have spoken to Mrs Todd like that. / You could/might have told me you were going to be late! / He will slam the door every time he goes out. / You would take the car just when I wanted to go out. / I might as well be dead for all you care.

grammar.meaning: Modals such as must, have to, need to are used to express present, future or past obligation. (Dùng để nói về nghĩa vụ ở hiện tại, tương lai hoặc quá khứ)
grammar.example: You have to be a good communicator. / You don’t always need to have a degree. / You’ll have to do quite a lot of research. / I’m glad we won’t have to write essays. / We had to come up with three questions each. / In the past, politicians didn’t have to deal with 24-hour media.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Certainty about now, the future or generally
grammar.meaning: Used to express strong certainty or near-certainty about something now or in the future. (Dùng để diễn tả điều gần như chắc chắn ở hiện tại hoặc tương lai) Modals: will, would, must, can, can’t, could, couldn’t.
grammar.example: There’s someone at the door. / That’ll be the postman. / It can’t be. He’s already been.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Certainty about the past
grammar.meaning: Used to express strong certainty or deduction about a past event. (Dùng để suy luận chắc chắn điều gì đã xảy ra trong quá khứ) Modals: will have, won’t have, would have, wouldn’t have, must have, can’t have, couldn’t have.
grammar.example: They won’t have heard the news, will they? / They must have heard by now, surely.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Probability about now, the future or generally
grammar.meaning: Used to express something likely to happen or probably true now or in the future. (Dùng để nói điều có khả năng xảy ra hoặc đúng ở hiện tại/tương lai) Modals: should, shouldn’t, ought to, may/might well, could well, might easily.
grammar.example: The weather should be good tomorrow, shouldn’t it? / Actually, the forecast said it may well rain.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Probability about the past
grammar.meaning: Used to say what was probably true or likely in the past. (Dùng để diễn tả điều có lẽ đúng trong quá khứ) Modals: should have, shouldn’t have, ought to have, oughtn’t to have, may/might well have, might easily have.
grammar.example: Jan should have finished writing her article by now, shouldn’t she? / She may well have done, but I haven’t seen it yet.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Possibility about now, the future or generally
grammar.meaning: Used to express a possible situation in the present or future. (Dùng để nói về một khả năng có thể xảy ra ở hiện tại hoặc tương lai) Modals: could, may, might, may/might/could just.
grammar.example: I might (just) have time to get to the library before it closes.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Possibility about the real past
grammar.meaning: Used to express a real past possibility that might or might not have happened. (Dùng để nói về khả năng thực tế trong quá khứ) Modals: could have, may have, might have.
grammar.example: Jim might not have checked his email yet.

grammar.word: Modals n semi-modals - Overview and structure
grammar.meaning: Modals (will, would, can, could, may, might, shall, should, must) have only one form and are followed by bare infinitives. Semi-modals (need to, ought to, had better, have to) behave similarly but may vary in structure. (Tổng quan về động từ khiếm khuyết và bán khiếm khuyết, cấu trúc theo sau là động từ nguyên mẫu)
grammar.example: Modals: could + do, be doing, have done, have been doing. / Passive: could + be done, have been done. / Semi-modals: need to, ought to, had better, have (got) to.

grammar.word: Adjectives n Adverbs - Position of adjectives
grammar.meaning: Adjectives usually appear before a noun, or after verbs such as appear, become, feel, get, grow, look, seem, smell, sound, taste, and turn. (Tính từ thường đứng trước danh từ hoặc sau một số động từ chỉ trạng thái)
grammar.example: I love your new house. / The material this dress is made out of feels rough. / She looked angrily at the man behind the counter.

grammar.word: Adjectives n Adverbs - Position of multiple adjectives
grammar.meaning: When more than one adjective is used before a noun, they appear in the order: opinion, size, age, shape, colour, origin, material, purpose. (Thứ tự tính từ khi có nhiều tính từ đi trước danh từ)
grammar.example: We've got a lovely little wooden cabin in the mountains. / You love your long, red, Chinese, silk curtains. / What you need for your living room is a large oak dining table.

grammar.word: Adjectives n Adverbs - Adjectives used as nouns
grammar.meaning: Adjectives can function as nouns to refer to social groups, specific groups, or nationalities. (Tính từ có thể dùng như danh từ để chỉ nhóm người hoặc quốc tịch)
grammar.example: We need to provide better housing for the poor. / When the building collapsed, the injured were rushed to hospital. / The French have introduced new housing regulations in Paris.

grammar.word: Adjectives n Adverbs - Position of adverbs
grammar.meaning: Adverbs can appear at the beginning, middle, or end of a clause. Their position varies by type. (Trạng từ có thể đứng đầu, giữa hoặc cuối mệnh đề tùy loại)
grammar.example: They built the house very quickly. / Our house will probably have been decorated by the time you get there. / I'm rarely in the city centre. / I rarely go to the city centre. / We bought it as an investment; then, all the property prices in the area fell.

grammar.meaning: Comparatives and superlatives are used to compare people or things. (Dùng để so sánh các người hoặc vật)
grammar.example: Your flat is much bigger and more comfortable than ours. / Mexico City is probably my least favourite city. / I think my home town is the best place in the world.

grammar.word: Adjectives n Adverbs - Comparative and superlative modifiers
grammar.meaning: Modifiers such as quite, far, much, easily, etc., can strengthen comparatives and superlatives. (Các từ bổ nghĩa dùng để nhấn mạnh tính từ so sánh)
grammar.example: This area has become considerably more crowded and far noisier in the last ten years. / If you ask me, Ladybridge is easily the nicest area of town to live in.

grammar.word: Adjectives n Adverbs - Structures used to make comparisons
grammar.meaning: We can use structures like 'as ... as', 'not nearly as ... as', 'the ... the ...', etc. to express comparisons. (Các cấu trúc so sánh phức như the more ... the more ... hoặc not nearly as ...)
grammar.example: Platinum is about twice as expensive as gold. / Iron is not nearly as hard as diamond. / Iron is nothing like as hard as diamond. / The taller the building, the greater the fire risk.

grammar.word: Adjectives n Adverbs - Gradable and ungradable adjectives
grammar.meaning: Gradable adjectives can vary in degree and take modifiers like 'very'; ungradable adjectives express extremes and take words like 'absolutely'. (Tính từ chia làm loại có mức độ và loại tuyệt đối)
grammar.example: Pete was a bit tired after working on the building site all day, but it wasn’t too bad. / After working on the building site all day, Tim was absolutely exhausted. / The balconies are quite splendid.

grammar.meaning: Some words have forms that look like both adjectives and adverbs (e.g., fast, hard, late), or take -ly with different meanings. (Một số từ có thể là cả tính từ và trạng từ, đôi khi nghĩa khác nhau)
grammar.example: Sandstone is not a very hard material. ✓ Hit it too hard and you’ll break it. ✗ Hit-it-too-hardly-and-you’ll-break-it. / I could hardly hear the music. / She looked at me in a very friendly way.

grammar.word: Clauses - Relative pronouns in relative clauses
grammar.meaning: Relative pronouns are used to link a relative clause to a noun. (Đại từ quan hệ dùng để nối mệnh đề quan hệ với danh từ chính) Includes: who, which, whom, that, when, where, why, whose, what.
grammar.example: There are a lot of people who hate having injections. / This is the prescription which the doctor gave me. / That’s the consultant with whom I spoke. / This is the prescription that the doctor gave me. / I’ll never forget the day when I broke my finger. / Harley Street, where she was born, is famous for its clinics. / That’s the reason why I wanted to become a vet. / There are several kids in my class whose parents are doctors. / What I don’t understand is why she didn’t take her pills.

grammar.word: Clauses - Defining and non-defining relative clauses
grammar.meaning: Defining clauses identify which person/thing is meant; non-defining add extra information. (Mệnh đề quan hệ xác định và không xác định)
grammar.example: Defining: The doctor who did Karen’s operation. / I’ll never forget the day when I broke my arm. Non-defining: Dr Lake, who has been working here for over ten years, is a very experienced surgeon. / Harley Street, where she was born, is famous for its clinics.

grammar.meaning: Used to replace relative clauses or add information using -ing, past participle, or having + V3. (Mệnh đề rút gọn dùng phân từ hiện tại/quá khứ)
grammar.example: After giving blood, I went home. / Being frightened of needles, Tony was not looking forward to the injection. / Given the chance, I’d definitely study pharmacology.

grammar.meaning: Infinitive clauses can express purpose or follow certain verbs like 'be'. (Mệnh đề với động từ nguyên mẫu dùng để thể hiện mục đích hoặc theo sau một số động từ nhất định)
grammar.example: To be a successful surgeon is the dream of many young children. / My job was to give the patients their lunch.

grammar.meaning: Concession clauses express contrast or unexpected results. (Mệnh đề nhượng bộ dùng để diễn tả sự trái ngược hoặc bất ngờ) Common phrases: although, even though, in spite of, despite, while, however, much as, etc.
grammar.example: Even though she’d put on sun cream, Tamsin got burnt. / In spite of the fact that she put on sun cream, Tamsin still got burnt. / However hard he tried, he couldn’t put up with the pain.

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Time
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: in an hour, in a second; Definite article: in the 1840s, in the winter, in the afternoon; Zero article: in 2010, in winter, in December, on Tuesday, at night

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For People and Work
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: have a job, work as a teacher, I met a very nice American last night; Definite article: the King, the Principal, the President, the British; Zero article: Russians, become President, go to work, be at work, have work to do

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Places
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: Is there a beach near here?; Definite article: the Himalayas, the Pacific Ocean, the Seine, the Earth, the Antarctic, the USA, the UK, the Scilly Isles; Zero article: Mount Everest, Berlin, America, Antarctica, Jupiter, Fleet Street, Lake Michigan, Mykonos

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Public Buildings
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: Is there a bank near here?; Definite article: the bank, the post office, go to the hospital/prison/school (as a visitor); Zero article: go to school/hospital/prison (as a student/patient/prisoner)

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Entertainment and Sport
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: Play us a song!, I’ve got a tennis ball; Definite article: play the guitar, the media, on the radio, go to the cinema, watch the TV; Zero article: play tennis, play guitar, listen to music, on television, watch TV

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Organisations
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: Does Switzerland have an army?; Definite article: the BBC, the police, the emergency services, the United Nations; Zero article: NATO

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Education
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: have a lesson, take an exam; Definite article: be in the first year; Zero article: geography, be in class/year/form 5

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Travel
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: take a taxi, catch a bus/train; Definite article: in the car/taxi, on the bus/plane; Zero article: on foot, go home, go by car/plane

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Articles by category and set phrases (usage) - For Health
grammar.meaning: Certain categories have typical article usage. (Một số danh từ theo nhóm có quy tắc dùng mạo từ đặc trưng)
grammar.example: Indefinite article: have a cold/cough/headache/toothache/stomach ache; Definite article: have the flu/measles; Zero article: have flu/measles/toothache/stomach ache

grammar.meaning: Countable nouns have both singular and plural forms, and can be used with a/an or numbers. (Danh từ đếm được có dạng số ít và số nhiều, dùng với a/an hoặc số đếm) Examples: painting, paintings, idea, books. Some have irregular plurals (e.g. people, mice, men).
grammar.example: That painting is amazing. / Those paintings are dreadful. / The sheep are in the field. / The government is/are not doing anything to help the arts.

grammar.meaning: These nouns only have a singular form and take singular verbs. (Danh từ không đếm được chỉ có dạng số ít và đi với động từ số ít) Includes: advice, blood, bread, furniture, hair, information, jewellery, knowledge, luggage, money, news, permission, respect, water.
grammar.example: Is the information reliable? / The table is made of wood. / It's a picture of a local wood.

grammar.meaning: These uncountable nouns have a plural form and take plural verbs. (Một số danh từ không đếm được có dạng số nhiều và đi với động từ số nhiều) Includes: arms, binoculars, clothes, congratulations, earnings, glasses, goods, groceries, jeans, pajamas, scales, surroundings, scissors, trousers, etc.
grammar.example: The scissors aren't on the table. / A pair of binoculars is on the desk.

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Quantifiers for countable and uncountable nouns (usage)
grammar.meaning: Some quantifiers are used only with countable nouns, others with uncountable, and some with both. (Một số từ chỉ định lượng chỉ dùng với danh từ đếm được, không đếm được, hoặc cả hai)
grammar.example: A few friends (countable) / A little milk (uncountable) / A lot of people (all nouns) / Only a few of them came. / Only a little of it was useful.

grammar.meaning: Used with singular countable nouns to refer to something not specific or mentioned for the first time. (Dùng với danh từ đếm được số ít, để nói về một vật chưa xác định hoặc mới nhắc đến lần đầu)
grammar.example: I'd like to go to a concert tonight. / I've had a great idea! / A poet sees the world differently.

grammar.meaning: Used to refer to specific things or when both speaker and listener know what is being talked about. (Dùng để nói về điều đã biết hoặc xác định được)
grammar.example: Is that the band you were talking about? / The scales are balanced to symbolise equality. / The young often rebel against the old.

grammar.word: Noun phrase - Zero article: no article at all (usage)
grammar.meaning: Used with plural or uncountable nouns when talking generally or in idiomatic expressions. (Không dùng mạo từ khi nói chung hoặc trong các cụm thành ngữ)
grammar.example: Don't let your young child use scissors unsupervised. / An artist always needs inspiration.

grammar.meaning: Certain verbs are followed by the -ing form. (Một số động từ đi với dạng V-ing) Verbs include: admit, adore, advocate, appreciate, avoid, can't help, carry on, compare, consider, contemplate, delay, deny, detest, discuss, dislike, endure, enjoy, escape, face, fancy, feel like, finish, foresee, give up, include, involve, justify, keep (on), mention, mind, miss, postpone, practise, put off, recommend, resent, resist, risk, suggest, take up.
grammar.example: Sue admitted feeling rather upset. / Damien insisted on going to the party. / I'm looking forward to meeting your brother.

grammar.meaning: Some verbs take an object followed by an -ing form. (Một số động từ đi với tân ngữ + V-ing) Verbs include: catch, find, glimpse, hear, notice, observe, overhear, see, smell, watch.
grammar.example: They caught him taking money from the till.

grammar.meaning: Many verbs are followed by the full infinitive (to + V). (Nhiều động từ đi với to + V nguyên mẫu) Verbs include: afford, agree, aim, appear, apply, arrange, aspire, attempt, beg, cease, choose, claim, come, dare, decide, demand, deserve, desire, expect, fail, happen, help, hesitate, hope, learn, manage, need, neglect, offer, plan, prepare, pretend, promise, refuse, resolve, rush, seek, seem, strive, tend, undertake, volunteer, vote, wait, want, wish, would like, yearn.
grammar.example: Can you afford to buy that car? / I hope to pass the exam. / They promised to call later.

grammar.word: Verbal complements - Verb + object + full infinitive (structure)
grammar.meaning: Some verbs require both an object and a full infinitive. (Một số động từ cần cả tân ngữ và to + V) Verbs include: advise, allow, ask, assist, authorise, beg, cause, challenge, choose, command, compel, convince, dare, decide, defy, desire, employ, enable, empower, encourage, expect, force, free, help, hire, inspire, instruct, intend, invite, lead, motivate, move, need, nominate, order, permit, persuade, pick, prepare, prompt, qualify, raise, recommend, recruit, request, require, select, send, signal, teach, tell, tempt, trust, want, warn.
grammar.example: My sister advised me to tell Jim the truth.

grammar.word: Verbal complements - Verb + object + bare infinitive (structure)
grammar.meaning: Verbs like let, make, help are followed by object + bare infinitive (V without to). (Một số động từ theo sau là tân ngữ + V không 'to') Verbs include: help, let, make, feel, hear, notice, overhear, see, watch.
grammar.example: The teacher let the class leave early.

grammar.word: Verbal complements - Verb (+ object) + infinitive or -ing form with little or no change in meaning (structure)
grammar.meaning: Some verbs can be followed by either an infinitive or -ing form without significant change in meaning. (Một số động từ đi với to V hoặc V-ing mà không thay đổi nghĩa nhiều) Verbs include: begin, bother, can't bear/stand, continue, hate, intend, like, love, prefer, start.
grammar.example: I love to read. / I love reading. / They continued to work. / They continued working.

grammar.word: Verbal complements - Verb (+ object) + infinitive or -ing form with a change in meaning (structure)
grammar.meaning: Some verbs change meaning depending on whether they are followed by an infinitive or -ing. (Một số động từ thay đổi nghĩa tùy thuộc vào to V hay V-ing theo sau) Verbs include: consider, forget, go on, hear, imagine, like, mean, regret, remember, see, stop, try.
grammar.example: I forgot to ask Brian. / I’ll never forget asking Helen. / I stopped to think. / Please stop telling me what to do. / Try to not forget her birthday. / You could try buying her some flowers.

grammar.meaning: Some verbs like find, think, and consider can use 'it' as preparatory subject. (Dùng 'it' như chủ ngữ giả với các động từ như find, think, consider) Common verbs: find, think, consider, make, believe, feel.
grammar.example: I consider it incredible that James and Alice are still together.

grammar.meaning: Used in that-clauses after verbs suggesting necessity or importance; uses base form of verb (no -s in 3rd person). (Câu giả định dùng để diễn tả điều cần thiết, quan trọng hoặc mong muốn, dùng động từ nguyên mẫu) Typical verbs: suggest, recommend, insist, demand, ask, require, propose, important that..., essential that..., vital that..., necessary that....
grammar.example: The doctor suggested that Sam take some time off work. / It’s very important that Greg not know about this. / It’s absolutely essential that I be informed.

grammar.meaning: a sentence that expresses a condition and its result, often used for hypothetical or unlikely situations. (câu điều kiện)
grammar.example: If I had known, I would have taken some dollars with me.

grammar.meaning: to think about something that is not real or is unlikely to happen. (tưởng tượng)
grammar.example: Suppose you were given ten million euros, what would you spend it on?

grammar.meaning: to assume something is true for the purpose of argument or explanation. (giả sử)
grammar.example: Suppose you had won the lottery last night. What would you have done?

grammar.meaning: used to describe a situation that is not true or real. (như thể là)
grammar.example: She acts as if she were a millionaire.

grammar.meaning: used in the same way as 'as if', to make unreal comparisons. (như thể là)
grammar.example: Tony looks as if someone had just handed him a million euros.

grammar.meaning: Used to make requests and questions sound more polite. (Cách nói lịch sự hơn khi yêu cầu hoặc đặt câu hỏi)
grammar.example: I was wondering whether you might be able to give me some advice.

grammar.meaning: Used to suggest that something should be done now or in the immediate future. (Đã đến lúc làm điều gì đó)
grammar.example: It’s (high/about) time we were leaving.

grammar.meaning: Used to express current, general or future preference, or past preference. (Diễn tả sự ưu tiên, mong muốn)
grammar.example: We’d rather/sooner you hadn’t lent Kurdip the money.

grammar.meaning: Used to express regrets or unreal desires about present or past situations. (Ước hoặc tiếc nuối về điều không có thật ở hiện tại hoặc quá khứ)
grammar.example: If only I was earning a reasonable salary.

grammar.word: Unreal time - Other structures with wish / if only (phrase)
grammar.meaning: Structures used to express criticism, inability, formal desires, or to wish someone success. (Các cấu trúc dùng với wish để phê phán, thể hiện ước muốn hoặc chúc ai đó)
grammar.example: I wish I could find a job that pays well.

grammar.meaning: When the reporting verb is in the past, we usually shift the original tense back. (Khi động từ tường thuật ở thì quá khứ, thì của câu gốc thường bị lùi lại một thì)
grammar.example: Sam doesn’t play hockey → Fiona said that Sam didn’t play hockey.

grammar.meaning: When reporting speech with modals, some modal verbs change form. (Một số động từ khuyết thiếu thay đổi trong câu tường thuật)
grammar.example: 'I could swim,' she said → She said she could swim.

grammar.word: Reporting - Modal and semi-modal change table (reference)
grammar.meaning: Detailed list of modal/semi-modal verb changes in reported speech. (Danh sách các động từ khuyết thiếu thay đổi trong câu tường thuật)
grammar.example: will/shall → would; can → could; must → had to / be to / should; have to → had to; don’t/doesn’t have to → didn’t have to; mustn’t → mustn’t / were not to / shouldn’t; may → might; am/is/are going to → was/were going to. Example 1: 'I will call you,' she said. → She said she would call me. Example 2: 'You must finish the work,' he said. → He said I had to finish the work.

grammar.meaning: ‘Must’ becomes ‘had to’, ‘were to’, or ‘should’ when expressing obligation. ‘Mustn’t’ becomes ‘mustn’t’, ‘were not to’, or ‘shouldn’t’. (Must → had to / should; Mustn’t → mustn’t / shouldn’t)
grammar.example: ‘You mustn’t cheat,’ said the coach. → We were told that we mustn’t / were not to / shouldn’t cheat.

grammar.meaning: Pronouns and determiners often change to reflect the new speaker or perspective. (Đại từ và từ xác định thường thay đổi để phản ánh người nói mới)
grammar.example: It’s my turn. → Eddie pointed out that it was his turn.

grammar.meaning: Time/place words are often shifted back in reported speech. (Các từ chỉ thời gian/địa điểm thường bị lùi lại)
grammar.example: We’ll meet here tomorrow. → He said they would meet there the next day.

grammar.meaning: Questions lose question marks and follow normal word order. (Câu hỏi gián tiếp không dùng dấu hỏi và theo trật tự câu khẳng định)
grammar.example: ‘What time did the match start?’ → Jimmy asked what time the match had started.

grammar.meaning: Commands use tell/order/ask + to-infinitive in reported speech. (Mệnh lệnh và yêu cầu dùng tell/order/ask + to V trong câu tường thuật)
grammar.example: Put the cricket bats away! → Alex told me to put the cricket bats away.

grammar.meaning: Different reporting verbs follow different grammatical patterns. (Các động từ tường thuật khác nhau đi với các cấu trúc ngữ pháp khác nhau)
grammar.example: Verbs include: accuse, admit, advise, agree, deny, explain, insist, suggest, tell, warn.

grammar.word: Reporting - Modal and semi-modal change table (reference)
grammar.meaning: Detailed list of modal/semi-modal verb changes in reported speech. (Danh sách các động từ khuyết thiếu thay đổi trong câu tường thuật)
grammar.example: will/shall → would; can → could; must → had to / be to / should; have to → had to; don’t/doesn’t have to → didn’t have to; mustn’t → mustn’t / were not to / shouldn’t; may → might; am/is/are going to → was/were going to. Example 1: 'I will call you,' she said. → She said she would call me. Example 2: 'You must finish the work,' he said. → He said I had to finish the work.

grammar.meaning: Used to emphasize a particular part of a sentence by placing it at the beginning. (Dùng để nhấn mạnh một phần nào đó trong câu)
grammar.example: All that Keith wanted was to get his money back. / The person who stole the money was Thomas. / The day when this government came to power was 2006.

grammar.meaning: Used for emphasizing a person or thing responsible for an action. (Nhấn mạnh người hoặc vật thực hiện hành động)
grammar.example: It was Carol who called the police. / It was the year in which this government came to power. / It was me that stole the money.

grammar.word: Complex sentence - So / Such / Too / Enough (adverbial structure)
grammar.meaning: Used to express degree or intensity, often followed by a result clause. (Dùng để diễn tả mức độ và kết quả)
grammar.example: There is so much crime around here that I’m thinking of moving. / It was such a terrible crime that the judge sentenced him to life in prison. / The police didn’t respond quickly enough to catch the burglar.

grammar.meaning: Used to express intensity and result. (Dùng để nhấn mạnh mức độ dẫn đến kết quả)
grammar.example: It all happened so quickly that I didn’t have time to see the man’s face. / This problem has gone on for so long that I don’t think they’ll ever find a solution.

grammar.meaning: Used before nouns to emphasize extreme characteristics. (Dùng trước danh từ để nhấn mạnh)
grammar.example: It was such a terrible crime that the judge sentenced him to life in prison. / There is such a lot of crime around here that I’m thinking of moving.

grammar.meaning: Used to indicate more than what is wanted or needed. (Dùng để chỉ mức độ vượt quá)
grammar.example: I had too little time to get a good look at his face. / The police responded too slowly to have any chance of catching the burglar.

grammar.meaning: Used to show a sufficient degree or amount. (Dùng để chỉ mức độ hoặc số lượng đủ)
grammar.example: There just aren’t enough police officers on the streets. / The police weren’t quick enough to catch the burglar.

grammar.word: Complex sentence - Inversions with negative adverbials (structure)
grammar.meaning: Used for emphasis, these begin with negative adverbs and require subject-verb inversion. (Cấu trúc đảo ngữ với trạng từ phủ định để nhấn mạnh)
grammar.example: Hardly had the new law been introduced when the mistake was realised. / Barely had we solved one problem when another one arose. / Never had I heard such a ridiculous suggestion.

grammar.word: Complex sentence - Not until / Only when / Only after (inversion)
grammar.meaning: Inversion is used after time clauses with ‘not until’, ‘only when’, or ‘only after’. (Dùng đảo ngữ sau các cụm thời gian để nhấn mạnh)
grammar.example: Not until the next election will we know how the public feel about this news. / Only when we agree what measures are needed will we be able to solve the problem.

grammar.word: Complex sentence - Inversions with place expressions (+ verb of movement) (structure)
grammar.meaning: Used when place expressions begin the sentence, followed by inversion. (Đảo ngữ khi câu bắt đầu bằng cụm chỉ nơi chốn và động từ di chuyển)
grammar.example: Here comes the Minister now. / At the top of society are the aristocracy. / Running down the road was a young man with a woman’s handbag under his arm.

grammar.meaning: Used in short answers and with phrases like ‘neither/nor’, ‘so’, ‘such’, etc. (Các kiểu đảo ngữ khác với so/such/neither/nor)
grammar.example: ‘Did you?’ – So did I. / ‘I don’t believe a word this government says.’ – ‘No, neither do I.’ / So rare is burglary here that many people don’t lock their doors.

grammar.meaning: Used for predictions, future facts, decisions made at the moment, promises, offers, and requests. (Dùng cho dự đoán, sự thật tương lai, quyết định tức thì, hứa hẹn, đề nghị, và yêu cầu). Will is generally more formal than going to.
grammar.example: It looks as if Jake will lose his job. / The factory will open in July. / I’ll ask for a pay rise tomorrow. / I’ll help you with the advertising campaign. / I promise you won’t lose your job. / Will you give a presentation on the sales figures? / No, I won’t give a presentation on the sales figures.

grammar.meaning: Used to express predictions based on present evidence and intentions already formed. (Dùng để dự đoán có cơ sở hiện tại và diễn đạt ý định đã có sẵn). Less formal than 'will'.
grammar.example: Look at that wall. It looks as if it’s going to fall down. / I’m going to get my degree, then get a well-paid job.

grammar.meaning: Used to describe definite arrangements and scheduled events in the near future. (Dùng cho các kế hoạch cụ thể sắp diễn ra). Often used with a time reference (e.g. tomorrow, on Friday).
grammar.example: I’m meeting Fiona on Friday to discuss the advertising campaign. / I’m asking for a pay rise tomorrow.

grammar.meaning: Used for fixed future events such as timetables and schedules. (Dùng để nói về lịch trình hoặc sự kiện cố định trong tương lai). Often used in official contexts.
grammar.example: The shop closes at 3 pm next Saturday. / The bus departs at 8:00 AM sharp.

grammar.meaning: Describes actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future or situations continuing up to that point. (Dùng cho hành động hoàn tất hoặc tiếp diễn đến một thời điểm xác định trong tương lai).
grammar.example: It looks as if Jake will have lost his job by the end of the week. / This time next month, I’ll have worked at the company for exactly 25 years.

grammar.meaning: Focuses on the duration of actions continuing up to a point in the future. (Nhấn mạnh khoảng thời gian của hành động kéo dài đến tương lai).
grammar.example: This time next month, I’ll have been working at the company for exactly 25 years.

grammar.meaning: Used for actions in progress at a specific future time, or regular events that are expected in the future. (Dùng cho hành động đang diễn ra hoặc thói quen dự kiến ở tương lai).
grammar.example: This time next week I’ll be travelling round Russia on business. / The company Chairperson will be arriving on Thursday. / More people will be commuting to work by plane in the future.

grammar.meaning: Used after time expressions (when, as soon as, until, before, after, once, etc.) to describe conditions for future actions. (Dùng mệnh đề thời gian để mô tả điều kiện cho hành động tương lai).
grammar.example: I’ll give you a pay rise when you start working harder. / I’ll give you a pay rise once you’ve proved you’re a hard worker. / I’ll give you a pay rise as soon as you’ve brought in three new customers. / I won’t give you a pay rise until you’ve been working here for three years.

grammar.word: Future Time - Other ways to express the future
grammar.meaning: Additional future expressions using phrases like 'be about to', 'be due to', and modal verbs. These convey plans, near-future actions, formality, obligations, or probability. (Các cấu trúc diễn tả tương lai gần, kế hoạch, nghĩa vụ, hoặc khả năng xảy ra).
grammar.example:
• I'm just about to ask for my pay rise. / She's about to leave for the airport. 
• I'm just on the point/verge of asking for my pay rise. / He was on the verge of quitting. 
• I'm due to meet my boss at eleven o’clock. / The train is due to arrive in ten minutes. 
• You're to get those reports written before Friday! / The Prime Minister is to visit Japan next week. 
• I might ask for a pay rise tomorrow. / They may announce the results tonight. / The conference could be postponed due to weather.

grammar.word: Future Time - Future in the past
grammar.meaning: Used when describing past thoughts or statements about the future. (Dùng khi nói về điều trong quá khứ được xem là tương lai). Will becomes would, and present tenses shift to past tenses.
grammar.example: Then: I think the factory will open in September. → Now: I thought the factory would open in September. / Then: I’m in a rush because the train leaves at 4. → Now: I was in a rush because the train left at 4.

grammar.meaning: Used for completed actions, habits, general truths, permanent situations, or background in stories. (Dùng cho hành động hoàn tất, thói quen, sự thật, tình huống cố định trong quá khứ)
grammar.example: Sony and Philips invented the CD in the early 1980s. / We moved house a lot when I was a kid. / Early clocks were usually very unreliable. / Frank turned on the TV and sat on the sofa. / I’d rather Michael didn’t waste so much time playing video games.

grammar.meaning: Used to stress or emphasise actions or contrast with other past situations. (Dùng để nhấn mạnh hoặc đối lập hành động quá khứ)
grammar.example: Perhaps our grandparents didn’t have e-mail, but they did have the telephone. / I did enjoy our visit to the Science Museum last summer.

grammar.word: Past Time - Past simple vs Present perfect simple
grammar.meaning: Past simple is for finished time periods; present perfect is for recent actions or time periods that continue. (So sánh giữa hành động đã hoàn tất và hành động liên quan đến hiện tại)
grammar.example: I sent my first e-mail six months ago. / Have you ever sent an e-mail before? / There have been many technological advances in recent years. / Did the ancient Egyptians have more advanced technology?

grammar.meaning: Used for actions in progress at a time in the past, background events, temporary actions, and repeated actions. (Dùng cho hành động đang diễn ra hoặc lặp lại trong quá khứ)
grammar.example: Were you chatting to Matt online at midnight last night? / I was working for a large software company. / She was always taking things apart to see how they worked. / It was raining outside and people were making their way home. / While I was playing a computer game, my brother was doing his homework.

grammar.word: Past Time - Past continuous vs Past simple
grammar.meaning: Past continuous describes background in progress; past simple describes main events. (Dùng past continuous cho bối cảnh, past simple cho hành động chính)
grammar.example: We were talking about MP3s when Andrea mentioned her new music website. / When I was a child, I visited my grandmother every week.

grammar.word: Past Time - Past continuous vs Present perfect continuous
grammar.meaning: Past continuous is used for past progress; present perfect continuous links past to present. (So sánh hành động quá khứ đang diễn ra và hành động kéo dài đến hiện tại)
grammar.example: We were working on my computer for four hours yesterday. / We have been working on my computer for four hours so far.

grammar.meaning: Describes actions completed before another point in the past. (Dùng cho hành động hoàn tất trước một hành động khác trong quá khứ)
grammar.example: Had you had your computer long before it broke down? / When Dimitra called, I had managed to fix her computer. / By the time of his death, Thomas Edison had invented a number of things. / I beat Jason because I’d played a lot with my brother.

grammar.meaning: Describes actions or states continuing up to a point in the past. (Dùng cho hành động kéo dài đến một thời điểm trong quá khứ)
grammar.example: She’d been writing computer games for over ten years before she had a hit.

grammar.meaning: Used to describe repeated actions in the distant past. (Dùng để diễn tả thói quen đã xảy ra trong quá khứ)
grammar.example: The ancient Greeks would rely on the power of slaves. / Whenever I went to James’s house, he would usually be playing on his computer.

grammar.meaning: Used to describe past habits or states that are no longer true. (Dùng cho hành động hoặc trạng thái đã từng xảy ra trong quá khứ)
grammar.example: It used to seem strange to be able to communicate over long distances. / At first, people found it strange sending messages by mobile, but now everyone’s used to it. / We got used to travelling by train quickly.

grammar.meaning: Used for general truths, habits, permanent states, live commentary, instructions, newspaper headlines, reviews, and scheduled events. (Thì hiện tại đơn dùng cho sự thật, thói quen, tình trạng cố định, tiêu đề, lịch trình)
grammar.example: The left-hand side of the brain controls the right-hand side of the body. / I don’t always go to lectures that are early in the morning. / Angie teaches French at a local adult education centre. / So, a man goes to see his psychiatrist. / HAWWKING WINS NOBEL PRIZE. / The film ends with us not knowing the result. / Tom turns left at the end of the road. / Term ends on 21st December. / I’ll be so relieved when I finish this crossword.

grammar.meaning: Used to express strong emotion or to contrast with another idea. (Dùng để nhấn mạnh cảm xúc hoặc sự tương phản)
grammar.example: Adam doesn’t know much about psychiatry but he does know quite a lot about psychology. / I do like playing word games!

grammar.meaning: Used for actions happening now, changing situations, temporary states, fixed future plans, and habits with always. (Dùng cho hành động đang xảy ra, tình huống thay đổi, sắp xếp tương lai, hoặc thói quen gây phiền)
grammar.example: The boys are doing their homework right now. / What book are you doing in English? / We aren’t having any exams while the lecturers are on strike. / More and more people are recognising the advantages of learning a foreign language. / Dan’s always coming up with the craziest ideas! / He’s carrying a bag full of honey. / When are you taking your driving test? / I’ll probably be a bit scared when I’m waiting outside for the exam.

grammar.meaning: Used for actions/states from past to present, recent actions, experiences, and present results. (Dùng cho hành động từ quá khứ kéo dài tới hiện tại, hoặc ảnh hưởng tới hiện tại)
grammar.example: I’ve been a member of MENSA for over five years. / She’s done a BA, an MA and a PhD. / Have you ever read any books by Edward De Bono? / She’s been awarded a scholarship to Harvard. / I’ve just received my exam results. / Tell me when you’ve finished the report. / US: I already found the answer. UK: Have you found the answer yet?

grammar.meaning: Used for actions in progress from the past up to now, especially to emphasize duration. (Dùng cho hành động đang diễn ra từ quá khứ và nhấn mạnh thời lượng)
grammar.example: We’ve all been wondering what to get Tony for his birthday. / I won’t take my driving test until I’ve been having lessons for at least two months. / I’ve worked here for five years. / I’ve been working here for five years.

grammar.word: Present Time - Stative and non-stative verb uses
grammar.meaning: Stative verbs (describe states, not actions) are usually not used in continuous tenses. (Động từ chỉ trạng thái thường không dùng ở thì tiếp diễn)
grammar.example: I think it’s important to know how to use a computer. (state: think = believe) / I’m thinking about going on a computer course. (action: think = consider)

phrases, collocations.meaning: pay dearly for, pay sb a compliment, pay your way, pay your respects, pay the price, pay rise
phrases, collocations.example: He paid dearly for his mistake. She paid me a compliment on my work. I always pay my way when dining out. We went to pay our respects at the memorial. He paid the price for ignoring the warning. He asked for a pay rise.

phrases, collocations.meaning: peer group, peer pressure
phrases, collocations.example: Teenagers are easily influenced by their peer group. He started smoking due to peer pressure.

phrases, collocations.meaning: put pen to paper, the pen is mightier than the sword, pen-pusher
phrases, collocations.example: She finally put pen to paper and wrote the letter. The pen is mightier than the sword. He’s just another pen-pusher in the office.

phrases, collocations.meaning: do sth in person, meet sb in person
phrases, collocations.example: You’ll need to apply in person. I’d love to meet the author in person someday.

phrases, collocations.meaning: put into perspective, from the perspective of, a sense of perspective
phrases, collocations.example: The tragedy really put things into perspective. From the perspective of a teacher, the system needs reform. Losing gave me a better sense of perspective.

phrases, collocations.meaning: change/swap places with, take the place of, take sb’s place, put in place, in place of, out of place, place of work/residence/birth
phrases, collocations.example: I wouldn’t change places with him for anything. Machines have taken the place of many workers. Can you take my place at the meeting? The new rules are now in place. Use vinegar in place of lemon juice. He looked out of place at the party. Please write your place of residence.

phrases, collocations.meaning: play against/for, play a part/role in, play the fool, play along, play by the rules, play fair
phrases, collocations.example: They played against Brazil in the finals. He played a key role in negotiations. He was just playing the fool to avoid blame. I decided to play along with the prank. In business, we play by the rules. Let’s play fair and square.

phrases, collocations.meaning: point at/to/towards, get to the point, make a point of doing sth, beside the point, up to a point, make your point, see/take sb’s point, there’s no point in
phrases, collocations.example: She pointed towards the building. Let’s get to the point. He made a point of checking everything twice. That’s beside the point. I agree with you up to a point. You’ve made your point clear. I take your point, but I disagree. There’s no point in arguing further.

phrases, collocations.meaning: polite to sb, polite of sb to do, just/only being polite, polite conversation/society
phrases, collocations.example: Please be polite to the guests. It was polite of her to say thank you. He was only being polite. They had some polite conversation over dinner. He’s not used to polite society.

phrases, collocations.meaning: come a poor second, poor loser, poor girl/boy/etc, poor relation, poor health, the rich and the poor
phrases, collocations.example: He came a poor second in the race. Don’t be a poor loser. The poor boy had no shoes. The charity is a poor relation of bigger ones. She has suffered from poor health. The gap between the rich and the poor is widening.

phrases, collocations.meaning: take/seize/hold/exercise/exert/wield/abuse power, power to do, power over, beyond sb’s power, the powers that be, power structure/base
phrases, collocations.example: The army seized power overnight. He exercised his power wisely. She has the power to make that decision. He holds power over the region. It’s beyond my power to change it. The powers that be decided to cancel the project. The power structure is too rigid.

phrases, collocations.meaning: praise sb for doing, win/receive/earn praise, full of praise for, in praise of
phrases, collocations.example: She praised him for helping. The project received a lot of praise. Everyone was full of praise for her speech. The painting was created in praise of freedom.

phrases, collocations.meaning: prefer sb to do, prefer sth to, prefer doing, would prefer
phrases, collocations.example: I’d prefer him to call later. I prefer coffee to tea. She prefers working alone. I would prefer to stay home tonight.

phrases, collocations.meaning: have principles, against sb’s principles, principle of sth, a matter/issue of principle
phrases, collocations.example: He’s a man of strong principles. It’s against my principles to lie. The principle of gravity is universal. I can’t agree, it’s a matter of principle.

phrases, collocations.meaning: print sth out/off, in print, out of print
phrases, collocations.example: Please print out the tickets. The book is still in print. That novel is out of print now.

phrases, collocations.meaning: go to prison, serve a sentence, prison term, prison reform, prison officer
phrases, collocations.example: He went to prison for theft. He’s serving a ten-year sentence. It was a long prison term. The law aims at prison reform. The prison officer escorted the inmate.

phrases, collocations.meaning: in the process of doing, peace/election/judicial/legal process, due process
phrases, collocations.example: We’re in the process of hiring. The peace process has stalled. The election process is underway. He didn’t receive due process.

phrases, collocations.meaning: provoke sb into doing, provoke a reaction/protest/outcry
phrases, collocations.example: His insult provoked her into quitting. The speech provoked a strong reaction. It provoked widespread protest.

phrases, collocations.meaning: serve a purpose, purpose of doing, on purpose, for the purpose of, escape sb’s purpose
phrases, collocations.example: This feature serves no purpose. The purpose of doing this is safety. I did it on purpose. He was hired for the purpose of expanding the team. Her point escaped my purpose.

phrases, collocations.meaning: high/good/top quality, poor/bad/low quality, personal/professional qualities, quality of life/time
phrases, collocations.example: They produce high-quality goods. The video was poor quality. His honesty is one of his best qualities. We want to improve quality of life. I enjoy spending quality time with my kids.

phrases, collocations.meaning: beg the question, a/no question of, in question, out of the question, without question, beyond question, some question over/as to/about, awkward question
phrases, collocations.example: This begs the question—why now? There’s no question of him resigning. His future is in question. It’s out of the question to cancel now. He’s guilty without question. Her loyalty is beyond question. There’s some question over the deal. That was an awkward question.

phrases, collocations.meaning: rain hard/heavily, pour with rain, heavy/light rain, get caught in the rain
phrases, collocations.example: It rained heavily last night. It’s pouring with rain today. We had light rain this morning. I got caught in the rain on the way home.

phrases, collocations.meaning: raise your hand, raise sth with sb, raise an objection, raise your voice/eyebrows, raise a child/family, raise sb’s hopes/expectations, raise awareness, raise money
phrases, collocations.example: Please raise your hand to speak. She raised the issue with her manager. I’d like to raise an objection. He raised his voice in anger. They raised four children. That comment raised everyone’s hopes. The ad campaign raised awareness about the issue. We raised money for the shelter.

phrases, collocations.meaning: react by doing, react accordingly/inappropriately, react to sth, react against
phrases, collocations.example: He reacted by slamming the door. They reacted accordingly to the new rules. She reacted strongly to the news. The crowd reacted against the unfair policy.

phrases, collocations.meaning: cause/produce/provoke/trigger a reaction, reaction against, reaction to
phrases, collocations.example: The announcement triggered a strong reaction. The book is a reaction against modern trends. Her reaction to the surprise was priceless.

phrases, collocations.meaning: read sb’s mind, read sb like a book, read between the lines, read out loud, read from cover to cover
phrases, collocations.example: She can read your mind. I can read him like a book. You need to read between the lines here. Please read this paragraph out loud. I read the novel from cover to cover.

phrases, collocations.meaning: escape from reality, face reality, in reality, reality TV
phrases, collocations.example: Some people drink to escape from reality. You must face reality at some point. In reality, the plan was flawed. She appears on a reality TV show.

phrases, collocations.meaning: keep/maintain/copy a record of, set/break a record, on record, off the record
phrases, collocations.example: We keep a record of all payments. She broke the world record in 100m. The hottest year on record was 2016. He spoke off the record.

phrases, collocations.meaning: a relative of yours, distant/close relative, a relative newcomer/unknown, relative clause/pronoun
phrases, collocations.example: She’s a close relative of mine. That man is a distant relative. He’s a relative newcomer to politics. The sentence contains a relative clause.

phrases, collocations.meaning: respect sb for sth, lose/win sb’s respect, have/show respect for, in this/that respect, with respect to
phrases, collocations.example: I respect her for her honesty. He lost everyone’s respect after the scandal. We should show respect for elders. In this respect, I agree. With respect to your concerns, we’re working on it.

phrases, collocations.meaning: response to sth, in response to, no response
phrases, collocations.example: His response to the news was calm. In response to your request, we will issue a refund. There was no response after we called.

phrases, collocations.meaning: rest on/against, rest assured that, take/have a rest, come to rest
phrases, collocations.example: He rested his head on her shoulder. Rest assured that we will deliver on time. I need to take a rest after that hike. The car came to rest in a ditch.

phrases, collocations.meaning: rich in, filthy/stinking rich, rich and famous, the rich and the poor
phrases, collocations.example: Avocados are rich in healthy fats. They became stinking rich overnight. She dreams of becoming rich and famous. The film contrasts the lives of the rich and the poor.

phrases, collocations.meaning: have a/the/no/every right to do, give sb the right to do, right and wrong, right in doing, right of sb to do, human/animal rights
phrases, collocations.example: You have every right to speak up. The law gives us the right to vote. Kids must learn right and wrong. He was right in refusing the offer. It’s not right of you to blame her. They campaign for human rights.

phrases, collocations.meaning: run the risk of doing, risk sth on, pose a risk to, at the risk of doing, put sth at risk, take a risk, at risk
phrases, collocations.example: He ran the risk of losing his job. She risked everything on one bet. Smoking poses a risk to your health. At the risk of sounding rude, I disagree. You put our plans at risk. We took a risk investing early. The species is at risk.

phrases, collocations.meaning: break/follow/bend the rules, against the rules, rule of law, rule book, rule out the possibility, rule of thumb
phrases, collocations.example: You must follow the rules. It’s against the rules to cheat. Democracy relies on the rule of law. He lives by the rule book. They ruled out the possibility of fraud. As a rule of thumb, don’t spend more than you earn.

phrases, collocations.meaning: run a business/campaign, run wild, run riot, run sb a bath, run on, run through sth, run the risk of doing, run into trouble
phrases, collocations.example: She runs her own business. The children ran wild at the park. Emotions ran riot after the game. He ran me a warm bath. The meeting ran on for hours. Let’s run through the plan. You run the risk of failure. We ran into trouble halfway.

phrases, collocations.meaning: rush to do, rush sb into, in a rush, rush hour, do sth in a rush
phrases, collocations.example: Don’t rush to conclusions. Don’t rush me into a decision. I’m in a rush, sorry! Traffic’s bad during rush hour. I packed everything in a rush.

phrases, collocations.meaning: have your say, say the word, say for certain, say your piece, nothing to say
phrases, collocations.example: Everyone will have their say. Just say the word and I’ll help. I can’t say for certain. She said her piece and left. I have nothing to say about that.

phrases, collocations.meaning: give/take a second to do, a split second, second hand, second best
phrases, collocations.example: Give me a second to think. It happened in a split second. He bought a second-hand bike. I don’t want to settle for second best.

phrases, collocations.meaning: make sense of, see sense, have the sense to do, common sense
phrases, collocations.example: I can’t make sense of these instructions. I hope he’ll see sense and apologize. She had the sense to leave early. Use your common sense in emergencies.

phrases, collocations.meaning: pass sentence on, serve a sentence, prison/jail sentence, death/life sentence
phrases, collocations.example: The judge passed sentence on the thief. He served a five-year sentence. The crime led to a jail sentence. She received a life sentence.

phrases, collocations.meaning: get/stay in shape, take shape, out of shape, in the shape of
phrases, collocations.example: I exercise to stay in shape. Plans are starting to take shape. I’m so out of shape lately. The island is in the shape of a star.

phrases, collocations.meaning: share with/between/among, shareholder, share index, share option
phrases, collocations.example: He shared the cake with his friends. The shareholders met yesterday. The share index rose sharply. She received share options at her job.

phrases, collocations.meaning: keep a sharp eye on, sharp rise/drop/increase, sharp criticism
phrases, collocations.example: Keep a sharp eye on your belongings. There was a sharp rise in prices. His speech drew sharp criticism.

phrases, collocations.meaning: run short, short-term/notice/while/period/spell, be short of sth, short-list
phrases, collocations.example: We’re running short on time. It’s a short-term fix. She was hired on short notice. Stay for a short while. I’m short of cash right now. They short-listed five candidates.

phrases, collocations.meaning: become law, break/follow/uphold the law, pass/amend/repeal a law, lay down the law, law and order, against the law, under the law, follow the law
phrases, collocations.example: The bill became law last year. He broke the law and was fined. Police must uphold the law. Parliament passed a new traffic law. The law was amended last session. Parents can't just lay down the law. The protest was against the law. Everyone is equal under the law. You must follow the law.

phrases, collocations.meaning: lead sb into, lead the way, lead the world in, lead sb to believe, take/hold the lead, follow sb’s lead, in the lead
phrases, collocations.example: He led us into a dangerous area. She will lead the way on climate reform. This firm leads the world in biotech. He led me to believe we had a deal. She took the lead early in the race. We followed his lead and stopped arguing. Our team is currently in the lead.

phrases, collocations.meaning: have the leisure to do, at your leisure, leisure centre, leisure time/pursuits
phrases, collocations.example: She doesn’t have the leisure to read these days. Please complete this at your leisure. We joined the local leisure centre. Watching movies is my favourite leisure pursuit.

phrases, collocations.meaning: go to great lengths, run the length of, in length, of (un)equal length, length of time
phrases, collocations.example: He went to great lengths to impress her. The pipe runs the length of the building. The documentary was 45 minutes in length. These tables are of equal length. It took a long length of time to finish.

phrases, collocations.meaning: get/receive a letter from, write/send sb a letter, letter bomb
phrases, collocations.example: I got a letter from my cousin. I wrote a letter to the council. Police intercepted a letter bomb at the embassy.

phrases, collocations.meaning: put sb’s life at risk, bring sth to life, come to life, save sb’s life, take sb’s life, lose a life, quality of life
phrases, collocations.example: Speeding puts lives at risk. The story was brought to life on stage. The city centre came to life at night. The doctor saved his life. The suspect took his own life. The crash claimed three lives. They enjoy a high quality of life.

phrases, collocations.meaning: lightning bolt/flash, struck by lightning, lightning speed
phrases, collocations.example: A bolt of lightning hit the tree. He was struck by lightning during the storm. She responded with lightning speed.

phrases, collocations.meaning: like doing/to do, anything/nothing like, alike/in like manner, just like, be like sb to do
phrases, collocations.example: I like playing guitar in my free time. There’s nothing like a warm bath. They look alike. She sings just like her mother. It’s like him to show up late.

phrases, collocations.meaning: link to/with, find/prove/establish a link, click/follow a link
phrases, collocations.example: This disease is linked to poor diet. They found a link between stress and heart disease. Click this link to join the call.

phrases, collocations.meaning: live a life of crime/luxury, live to do, live and let live, live in hope/fear, live to tell the tale
phrases, collocations.example: He lived a life of crime before reform. She lives to help others. I say live and let live. We live in hope that things improve. He survived the crash and lived to tell the tale.

phrases, collocations.meaning: load sth with/into, take a load off, a (whole) load of, loads of, a heavy load to bear/carry
phrases, collocations.example: She loaded the cart with groceries. Sit down and take a load off your feet. We had a whole load of laundry. He’s got loads of work today. Caring for his family is a heavy load to carry.

phrases, collocations.meaning: lock sth in/behind/under, lock horns with, locksmith
phrases, collocations.example: He locked the files in a drawer. They locked horns during the debate. Call a locksmith if you're locked out.

phrases, collocations.meaning: last long, take a long time, all day long, long way, long distance, at long last, long and hard, long time ago
phrases, collocations.example: The meeting didn’t last long. It took a long time to recover. They talked all day long. He walked a long way home. They maintained a long-distance relationship. At long last, they found peace. She thought long and hard about it. That happened a long time ago.

phrases, collocations.meaning: a lot of, lots of, a lot on, a lot to do with, the lot
phrases, collocations.example: There are a lot of options. We have lots of time. He’s got a lot on his mind. Her mood has a lot to do with stress. They ate the lot in one sitting.

phrases, collocations.meaning: love doing/to do, fall in love with, be in love, love affair, love for

phrases, collocations.meaning: push your luck, be in luck, lucky charm, bring/leave luck, wish sb luck

phrases, collocations.meaning: mark sb/sth on, leave a mark, mark the occasion, make a mark on, be quick/slow off the mark, hit the mark
phrases, collocations.example: The teacher marked us on clarity. The war left a mark on him. We planted a tree to mark the occasion. He made his mark on politics. She’s always quick off the mark. Her speech really hit the mark.

phrases, collocations.meaning: related by marriage, marriage guidance, marriage vows

phrases, collocations.meaning: material goods/possessions, material wealth, material resources, raw materials
phrases, collocations.example: He owns few material possessions. They pursued material wealth above all. The region has limited material resources. The factory imports raw materials from abroad.

phrases, collocations.meaning: a matter of, in a matter of (days/etc), to make matters worse, to no matter, no matter what/how/etc, no laughing matter, a matter of opinion, a matter of urgency
phrases, collocations.example: It’s a matter of principle. In a matter of days, everything changed. To make matters worse, it rained. It’s over—no matter. No matter what happens, I’ll stay. This is no laughing matter. Whether it's art is a matter of opinion. This is a matter of urgency.

phrases, collocations.meaning: take medicine, alternative/complementary medicine, herbal medicine

phrases, collocations.meaning: make a mental note, mental arithmetic, mental illness/health
phrases, collocations.example: I made a mental note to call her. He’s good at mental arithmetic. She’s recovering from a mental illness.

phrases, collocations.meaning: precious metal, metal detector
phrases, collocations.example: Gold is a precious metal. The metal detector beeped at the airport.

phrases, collocations.meaning: call in sick, feel sick, make sb sick, sick as a parrot, sick and tired of, sick with fear/worry/etc, sick at heart, sick bag
phrases, collocations.example: He had to call in sick today. I feel sick after that ride. That movie made me sick. She was sick as a parrot when she lost. I'm sick and tired of cleaning up after them. She’s sick with worry about her exam. He was sick at heart after the news. Please use a sick bag during turbulence.

phrases, collocations.meaning: side with sb, take sides, see both sides of an argument, the other side, on either side, on the plus/minus side, side by side
phrases, collocations.example: She always sides with her brother. Don’t take sides in their argument. Try to see both sides of the argument. I’ll be waiting on the other side. Houses stood on either side of the street. On the plus side, it’s cheaper. They walked side by side in silence.

phrases, collocations.meaning: that’s about the size of it, cut sth to size, in size, of a certain size, increase/reduce in size

phrases, collocations.meaning: feel small, in a small way, it’s a small world, small talk, small change, small number/amount/etc, small business

phrases, collocations.meaning: smooth the way for, smooth-talking, smooth sailing

phrases, collocations.meaning: social conditions, social contact, social security, social services, social call, social worker

phrases, collocations.meaning: make a good/bad/etc start, get off to a good/flying/head/etc start, head start, start from scratch, for a start, right from the start, from the start of

phrases, collocations.meaning: steady yourself, steady your nerves, hold sth steady, steady relationship, steady growth, steady look, steady pace

phrases, collocations.meaning: style sth/yourself as, in style, style of, out of style, with style

phrases, collocations.meaning: sun yourself, in the sun, in the shade/sunlight/sunshine, sunset
phrases, collocations.example: He lay on the beach to sun himself. We sat in the sun all day. They stayed in the shade. The room was full of sunlight. They watched the beautiful sunset together.

phrases, collocations.meaning: support doing sth, support sb, support sth, support sb financially/emotionally/etc, support a team

phrases, collocations.meaning: set/clear/lay the table, table a proposal, table manners, on the table, under the table

phrases, collocations.meaning: talk sb into/out of doing, talk sense, talk the same language, talk is cheap, talk your way into/out of

phrases, collocations.meaning: develop/have/acquire a taste for, in good/bad taste, sense of taste
phrases, collocations.example: He developed a taste for jazz. That joke was in bad taste. I lost my sense of taste when I was sick.

phrases, collocations.meaning: tell the truth/a lie, tell yourself, tell the difference, tell sb to do sth, tell sb what, be told, tell that, tell on

phrases, collocations.meaning: in the long/short term, term of/in office, prison/jail term, fixed term, term time, long/short-term

phrases, collocations.meaning: have thin skin, thin on top, thin on the ground, out of thin air, into thin air

phrases, collocations.meaning: pass the time, spend time doing, make time, find time, take time, in time, on time, time limit

phrases, collocations.meaning: want (sb) to do, want sth done, for want of

phrases, collocations.meaning: get in sb’s way, know the way, lose your way, get sth out of the way, in the way, on the/your/their way, in this way, way of doing

This information is top secret.

phrases, collocations.example: I take the view that honesty is best. I have a poor view of that policy. The mountains came into view. In view of the situation, we canceled the event. What’s your view on this issue? I’d like to take a longer view. In her view, we acted rightly. The view from here is amazing. His viewpoint is always interesting.

phrases, collocations.meaning: make up your mind (quyết định), cross/slip your mind (quên), bear/keep in mind (nhớ trong đầu), have a one-track mind (luôn nghĩ về một thứ), in two minds about (phân vân), on your mind (bận tâm), take your mind off (nghĩ sang chuyện khác), bring to mind (gợi nhớ), never mind (đừng bận tâm), narrow/broad/open/absent-minded (đầu óc hẹp hòi/rộng mở/lơ đãng)

phrases, collocations.meaning: take/be a moment (mất chút thời gian), just/wait a moment (chờ một chút), at the moment (hiện tại), at this/that moment in time (ngay lúc này), in a moment (trong giây lát), the moment of truth (thời khắc quyết định), for (the) moment (tạm thời)

phrases, collocations.meaning: mother of (mẹ của), single/working mother (mẹ đơn thân/làm việc), mother-to-be (mẹ tương lai), mother figure (người mẹ tinh thần), mother country/tongue (mẫu quốc/tiếng mẹ đẻ), in-law (mẹ chồng), Mother Nature (Mẹ Thiên nhiên)

phrases, collocations.meaning: the nature of sth (bản chất của...), in nature (về bản chất), Nature (Mẹ Thiên nhiên), human nature (bản chất con người), second nature (trở thành thói quen tự nhiên)

phrases, collocations.meaning: new to (chưa quen), brand new (mới toanh), whole new (hoàn toàn mới), good as new (như mới), new to sb (ai đó mới với cái gì), new look (diện mạo mới), new age/music/etc (phong cách hiện đại)

phrases, collocations.meaning: nice to sb (tốt với ai), nice of sb to do (ai đó tốt khi làm gì), nice for sb to do (ai đó tốt khi làm gì), nice to meet/hear/see/sb (rất vui gặp/nghe/thấy ai), nice and clean/safe/warm/etc (rất sạch/safe/ấm...)
